The young gentlemen who was providing the Trabant was very enthusiastic about his car, and we could see that he was taking much care and pride in maintaining the antique in good shape. We went to the castle and Andras explained us lots of interesting facts about the Hungarian history. After they took us to a tour around the city, and a stop in a very nice café which is an Art nouveau furniture museum at the same time. As an industrial designer, I found this visit quite interesting, to see all these different kinds of rare furniture.  Then, Andras took us to his parent’s home, which was a lovely home located in a residential neighborhood. I found it nice to see how it looks like outside the city center. Andras’s parents made everything to make us feel like at home, and let me tell you how much we have eaten as if we were kings! I wish I could have seen Andras’s Mom cooking, so that to learn some of her secrets!  After, Andras and his father brought us to Szentendre, where we visited the lovely village. Afterwards began some moments that I will never be able to forget! We went to a ceramic workshop in Szentendre and met with some very friendly people (Gabriella and Laszlo), who were patient enough to teach us the basics of pottery making; my husband and I both had the opportunity to try a ceramic piece of art each. It was such a sensual and technical experience! We had so much fun trying to do our ceramic piece! It is a pitty that we live so far away from Hungary as we both felt that we could become good friends with them!  We ended our day with a private piano concert, in a famous pianist’s appartment, Mr. Fellegi. This was, in my opinion, a MAGIC moment, something I will still remember when I will be an old lady (!) It is hard to explain the feeling of being «inside» the music and not only listening to the classical music on a CD or the radio. Mr. Fellegi really made us feel comfortable and we were in the right atmosphere to enjoy the piano concert.  The second day was even more unforgettable: Andras and his father took us to the city of Eztergom, we had the opportunity to cross the Danube to see Slovakia, and we also visit Hungary’s largest church, which is on top of a hill with a beautiful view on the Danube and Slovakia. We also had lunch in a great restaurant (here my husband will recommend the Transylvania soup that is incredibly tasteful and delicious!)  We visited the country side and we ended our day in a vineyard. I believe this was my husband’s favorite part! The lady, Vali Hernyák took the time to explain us about her familly’s winery business and made us taste many different wines (all very - very nice!) We could see how much love she puts in her art and we very much appreciated the time she spent with us. We also had a plate of local home-made cold cuts and cheese (again, incredibly delicious with the last wine we have tasted). Again, and sorry for repeating myself! we felt that we could have become good friends with this lovely lady and husband as we share the same vision of work and life.  Everyone we have met with Andras were friendly and warm in a genuine way. We feel that we have some friends now in Hungary and almost a familly there!  Not only that, but we were never rushed through the events and location, giving ample time to enjoy the activities in a tailored fashion. Also Andras was very organised and everything run smoothly during the 2 days.  Needless to say at this point that we highly recommand the personnal tour provided by Andras and let us tell you that it is worth every penny invested.  Regards from Canada,  Caroline and Françoys  P.S. We read an other comment on this site that we can barely understand! The car that was supplied to do the tour was a Corolla in very good condition, and pretty recent. Why would some members of TripAdvisor use this site to put down in an exagerated way some facts? Opinions are opinions but facts should be based on reality, so that Trip Advisor can continue to be a reliable tool.

This is a tour well above and beyond expectations!. As a frequent solo traveler, I have often found standard group tours to be impersonal and uniform. Admittedly, I am a tour guide and that sometimes makes it hard to concentrate on the tour & not the tour guide’s technique. After reading previous reviews, MyPersonalBudapest seemed to exactly fit my needs and wants. I contacted Andras and arranged for a personal two-day tour, including airport transfers.My two day tour went by quickly... almost too quickly. Looking back, I realize that I never felt that I was on an actual tour. It was, as if, a trusted friend had invited me to visit Budapest, then proceeded to show off its greatest attributes. Andras provides a warm and gracious welcome to Budapest’s best charms... the food, history, architecture and most importantly the local hospitality. On the first tour day, I was greeted by Balazs, a Trabant owner/driver. The driving tour was wonderful with Andras giving details on what we saw, explaining the history of where we were, plus we stopped several times for better views and history focus. Balazs is a very sweet, friendly man who kindly (and humbly) answered all my Trabant questions, allowing me to check out the engine, and even told me about his weekend stunt driving activities. Yes, I am somewhat fascinated by older cars.Afterwards, Andras & I visited Szentendre where local ceramic artists introduced me to molding clay into functional art. I never imagined that I would actually touch the clay, not to mention make something! It was hard work, but a really fulfilling experience. I may have to sign up for classes in the future. The first day ended with the local pub night, which was a lot of fun. We were joined by a few of Andras’ friends, which only made the experience more authentic. What’s drinking at the pub without a few friends? We visited three distinctly different (non-touristy) pubs & I never felt out of place or even noticed... excellent. The second day began walking around the city, as Andras pointed out hidden treasures not mentioned in guide books. I particularly liked this part of the tour; because I’m pretty sure I would not have found these places. After lunch we visited Etyek, spending time at a family run winery. Instead of listening to a lecture or presentation, there was a conversation explaining what they do and what they hope to do. I was introduced to how the family produces their wine, the different ages of their vines, the makeup of the region’s soil & their future foray into brandy making. I left Etyek much more knowledgeable about the Hungarian wine making process, with a great bottle of wine and a full stomach. On both days, lunch was a meal brilliantly cooked by Andras’ mother. Andras’ parents are a welcoming, funny and engaging couple. Upon entering the house, I was greeted with hugs & plum palinka (yum). The excellent food was served at the family dining table surrounded by family photos and books. Afterwards, coffee was enjoyed out on the terrace while soaking up the sun’s rays. On the second day, Andras’ mother could not be there, but she thoughtfully prepared the meal before leaving for the day. Andras’ father was wonderful as he presented & served his wife’s efforts. Just imagine visiting an aunt & uncle that you haven’t seen in a long time, and being welcomed with home cooking and good conversation.Because I opted for a personal tour, Andras offered to include or substitute places/activities, depending on my preference. I declined as I was perfectly happy with the agreed upon tour. I would not have changed a detail of this unique Budapest tour, except maybe to add another day. MyPersonalBudapest provided me with fabulous memories, well above and beyond my expectations. I can easily recommend taking this tour & I whole-heartedly encourage other Budapest visitors to sign up for this one-of-a-kind experience. Andras is the perfect host to introduce the wonders of Budapest.

Rich, unique experience - we just loved it!. We are very experienced travelers and have high expectations when we use our (precious) time to discover a new location. Budapest has been on my 'travel wish list' for years, and for this reason, I wanted this trip to be perfect ... and it was! A couple of weeks before our arrival, I had a long E-Mail exchange with András regarding the preparation of the trip - we finally choose a quite rich program : Day 1: We started with a city tour was very interesting and gave us a first overview of Budapest and the places to see. The 'Hungarian' lunch was delicious and it was very interesting to visit a genuine Hungarian home (OK, the trip was a bit long, but finally worth it). Finally, a treasure hunt made us raise our heads and notice funny details we would never have discovered alone …Day 2We started at 9 with an Art-Déco tour in two vintage cars (a Citroën Traction from 1954 as well as a Rolls Royce Silver Spur) - this was just gorgeous, and we discovered numerous partly incredible treasures - with very competent guides (we had almost a ratio of 1:1 between guides and tourists ;-). We then had lunch in what András called the "best pancake bar in town" - this was not extraordinary, but correct. In the afternoon, we enjoyed a relaxing tour on the Danube and then headed to the climax of the stay: a private concert given by a famous Hungarian pianist at his home. This was gorgeous, especially for me as an amateur pianist - and we were so pleased that we invited the pianist to play for our friends when he will next come to Switzerland - which will be in two months. If you are looking for a way to "deep dive" into the Hungarian Culture and the architectural, cultural and social heritage of Budapest, then I can recommend András without any reserve. Although some of the reviewers find that the trip is expensive, I do not share this position - we came back with tons of beautiful images and interesting information - and this is something money finally can't buy! Thanks András, we really enjoyed our discovery of Budapest!

Andras is awesome. If you're trying to take a day tour of Budapest and really see what the city has to offer, definitely go with this tour. You start off with a great view of the city, get to see all the famous historical sites, and learn a ton of information from a native Budapester. The best part is.. for lunch you actually go to his parents house and get a home cooked meal! That alone makes it worth it, you can't get something unique like this unless you have family there or know someone. In the afternoon, you play an Amazing Race style game where you run around Budapest gathering information about different landmarks and hopping on busses and metros in the process. It forces you to interact with the locals while learning cool stuff, and the competition is also a lot of fun. Nothing like seeing your friends running in the distance towards the bus you caught in the nick of time. The day ends with a night cruise, which gives a whole different perspective on the city. I wish they would do this kind of thing in more cities..

Food, wine, sights and sounds...MyPersonalBudapest showed us all of them. I just wanted to write and say thanks for the excellent tour you arranged for us in June. Having never visited Budapest, or Hungary for that matter, my partner and I knew little of it apart from what we had read but many websites focussed on the city's obvious USP's (unique selling points) like the cave system and the spas and less so on the wonderful hospitality and the sights and sounds of the contrasting areas of Buda and Pest. Many websites also concentrated on restaurant reviews, however we found a gem that most people never know about, unless they had contacted you. Our second stop on our tour, if you recall, after visiting the beautiful riverside town of Szentendre was for a genuine home cooked family meal. At that point I knew we'd booked something truly special that a large tour operator could only wish to replicate, and fail. Not only was the food delicious but the hospitality was amazing and we left feeling very full!All of the travel was taken care of which was fantastic and we were given plenty of opportunities to explore the town for ourselves. you found the right balance between being a tour guide and letting ourselves wander. You also organised our cruise of the Danube and took us to a fun ceramic making session where Alexandra and I still argue about who made the best plate. For the record, it was me! If that wasn't enough we also had time to squeeze in a visit to a family vineyard where after sampling lots of wine we were able to sit, eat and reflect on a great four days in your country.So, to us, the people are what made Budapest the great holiday it was and we would like to thank you Andras. Best wishes to your family also. I thoroughly recommend you and mypersonalbudapest to anyone who's looking to do something different on their vacation and have completely unique stories to tell when you come home. Please feel free to use my comments on your own website and I wish you the best of luck for the future - until we return for more.Kind regardsKarl & Alexandra

personalized tour guide in Budapest. If you are interested in a personal tour in Budapest, look no further...whether you are traveling with children(we had three children ages 3. 7, and 9) or with elderly we had my mother age 75, My Personal Budapest tours provide a unique and personalized service that you will not likely find anywhere else. We are Americans who have lived in Europe for three years, traveling to many countries, Budapest has always been one of those cities that we wanted to check off but was afraid it may be too adult. Are worries were unfounded with this service as Andras personalized our tour to make it fun and enyoyable for all ages. I highly recommend his service. He and his family who cooked a homemade hungarian dinner for us made us feel like family and provide with an experience of a lifetime. Thank you Andras and best wishes with your company, I know you will do well.

An unforgettable winter experience in beautiful Budapest!. Our group--20 of us from Singapore looks back very fondly on our time at Budapest with Andras! Andras is a very patient and dedicated tour guide who had time for everyone in the group and who made sure that everyone was comfortable and enjoying their trip. I have requested a specially tailored itinerary to our needs and wishes months before our trip and Andras was the only local guide that rendered very detailed advises and assistance in all ways to make sure that our trip is an enjoyable one not restricted only in budapest but other leg of our europe trip as well. And everyone enjoyed the programme to the fullest--kids and adults alike! He made sure we got to see, taste, smell and feel the best of Budapest in just 4 days. Andras was also very knowledgeable and passionate about spreading the Hungarian culture, history and way of life, and it was extremely enriching and truly eye-opening as we learnt about Budapest and Hungary from him. It was really an unforgetable experience to have lunch at his house, where we had the rare chance to taste true Hungarian cuisine and to interact with his parents to get to know the true Hungarian way of life! Not forgetting his mother, a true warrior, during the snow war with all the kids. They really enjoyed it! All in all, it was a most memorable and enjoyable time in Budapest with Andras, and definitely a very unforgettable stay that captured the essence of Budapest!

Great way to experience the real Budapest. This is a very nice tour. Our guide, Attila, was prompt, and very helpful and knowledgeable. The Trebanta cars that use were a fun way to get around the city. A half day is plenty to see all the sites. Lunch was excellent at our host’s home – real nice lad named Marta - and it was cool to see how real residents of the city live. And we enjoyed the thermal baths as well, which was the last top. All in all, a superb way to see Budapest, despite the cold weather. Excellent service!

The true essence of budapest!. We were blessed with many opportunities to see, taste, smell and feel the best of Budapest in just 4 days. We especially loved having lunch at a Hungarian home, where we had the rare chance to taste true Hungarian cuisine and to interact with his parents to get to know the true Hungarian way of life! All in all, it was a most memorable and enjoyable time in Budapest with Andras!

A perfect way to discover authentic local ambience. Andras provides valuable service for visitors to Budapest in a most original and passionate way. Reliable, helpful and very implicated we had been taken in charge after he perfectly understood our expectations. I am not complicated and so looking only after pure and authentic local ambience at reasonable but affordable price that can save us time and disillusions. Andras managed on a 2 day notice to understand how different my expectations are. We asked for more city aspects than only the main general attractions and to have a tour in a way we can get the flavour of the past years including underground, gastronomy, ethnical, cultural and night life. Andras managed in 24 hours with 2 Trabants and a magnificent timing to bring us in places you can not even imagine. And the most appreciable was the lunch that his mother prepared in their house. Thank you to all his family and friends that supports him to organise the poetic way of looking at Budapest. We recommend to everybody interested to see through Hungarian eyes this third capital on the Danube.Maryse and GeorgeBelgium

Unique, Unforgettable almost feel like a local!. We were looking for a tour to familiarize ourselves with Budapest and its sites but wanted to feel we were visiting family who was showing us around. Andras delivered just that. We contact him prior to arrival to arrange the Trabant sightseeing tour with the lunch at a Hungarian Home. The Trabants are very unique. People could not help look at us in these little weightless cars. They drove through very narrow streets even backroads we are sure the tour buses can't. The drivers who own the Trabants actually collect them and race them on 2 wheels! Amazing. The tour was at a great pace and reduced quite a bit of the walking which waas great for us. My friend Marta had just broken her foot and removed the cast right before the trip so she was concerned she would not be able to see everything or keep up walking but Andras kept the pace and the cars really made it all work. Make sure to share with Andras as much as possible about your interests so he can make additional suggestions for a truly unique experience. The Lunch was amazing and felt like we were part of the family. We kept comparing the Bean Goulash Soup we had at the home but none was better! As we toured with Andras, we shared about our love for wine and our interest to visit a local winery. He was so good to immediately check into it and he made arrangements with Hernyak Winery. I was left speechless once we arrived and tasted the wines. They are all handmade and the winemakers are so personable and friendly. We ate in the vineyard and remember the sun going down and the dining table getting dark just lit by the light of the fireplace... we could have been there exchanging stories for hours! Simply priceless folks.

A wonderful day!. We had a wonderful day with Andras on 23 October. My husband had recently had surgery, so we could not do a lot of walking. However, Andras crafted a full day. 3-hour Trabant tour of the city, a marvelous meal at his parents' home and an amazing private concert of Hungarian composers by a concert artist in the pianist's own home. The music was the perfect end to a delightful day, and the meal and the music certainly put us in touch with a more personal view of Hungary and Budapest. The Trabant ride was spectacular (and tight!) for those with an interest in historic cars...driven by true Trabant lovers and collectors. The day was indeed expensive, but the personal nature of the tour AND the private concert made it worth every penny.

Individual and personal tour - as it should be. This tour is definately recommendable - András, the guide, was higly comitted to deliver a satisfactionable tour. The tour started with a tasty Hungarian Lunch at András' parents house - very charming people. The Budapest tour afterwards was tailored as I had spent a day in Budapest already - which is a great advantage over a standard tour. Only one issue: Fans of super luxury cars will definately not like the tour - as it is done with a Trabant. All others will for sure enjoy that nostalgic vehicle - as I did!

What a great tour. I have contacted Andras and he arranged a Trabant tour according to our schedule. Balazs was our driver and came to pick us up at our hotel. The tour was great. There was another couple in another trabant and Andras was giving us all information by walkie talkie. The tour last 3 hours and it was worth every cent!! We highly recommend this tour if you are looking for something off the beaten path. This is really unique and so much fun. Thanks Andras!Michèle - Paris - France

Exactly what we wanted, at very short notice. We have just returned home from a wonderful trip to Budapest - what a beautiful city! We contacted Andras after arriving in Budapest and he very willingly arranged, on very short notice, a personal tour of the highlights of this wonderful city. He went out of his way to show us things of interest that we would have found difficult to visit ourselves without a car. He has a very obvious passion for his work and for the city and country within which he lives. Our visit to the beautiful artists' village of Szentendre was wonderful, but my personal favorite was having fish, chips and local beer at an outdoor restaurant sitting right next to the Danube. This was obviously the real Budapest, and not a place that tourists would ever know to visit.

Great Experience.....especially if you like something different.. My wife and I had a tour with Andrej today. He is genuine and enthusiastic about Budapest. It shows. The history is a given in broad strokes, but the details that matter to me are in the interchange of questions about culture, people, and issues of today. Facts cannot be easily forgotten, but to me the most memorable and endearing way to know Hungary is to take a trip with Andrej. Lunch with his parents is a true highlight. They too are warm, sincere, and genuine. The food is homely. It is a personal and unique experience. The 'treasure hunt' of the second half of the tour is an independent interactive questionaire. The 'treasure' is in walking a city, learning the facts, and meeting the people. Great idea. This the reward of an experience that will leave an unforgettable memory in our hearts and mind.

A historical way to see a historic city. Riding in the Trabants around Budapest was an incredible way to see the city. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and through the use of 2-way radios, our large group was able to hear all the history of the city as well as communicate with each other. The Trabants are very unique and were quite the show stopper throughout the city. If you are looking for a unique way to see this amazing city, there is no other way to go. I've been fortunate enough to travel all across Europe and go on many different tours of cities. This is by far the best experience of a tour I've ever had.

Adventurous day in Budapest.. The tour was a great way to spend the day! We had a lot of fun riding in the trabants. Andras has a wealth of knowledge regarding Budapest's history and was able to point out interesting buildings while on the way to stops. I would recommend this ride to any travelers that are looking for a day to learn, relax, have fun and enjoy a little adventure.

A must do for your Budapest adventure!!!. I've been to Budapest three times and Andras gave the best tour! He reserved Trabants for my group of 16 people! He had walkie talkies for each car so we were able to have some fun communication the entire tour along with all the historical information! We hit every site in style and was able to walk around and enjoy everything! The best way to see the city and have memorable footage! Sooo worth it!!! DO IT!

Best Experience Yet!!. I have been to Budapest 3 years in a row! And never experienced and had such an amazing time until I went on this tour! We had a group of 17 and there was 6 trabant cars waiting to take us around the city! Our team split into each car, and each car had a walkie talkie radio, to communicate between the cars, and to hear facts and history about the different places we were driving too. It was a blast, people in the streets where staring, taking pictures, filming, and waving!! We got to stop at all the hot spots in Budapest! And the drivers were amazing too!!! If a fun unique tour of Budapest is what you want, then GO FOR THIS ONE!!!!!

Trabant Tour - A Truly Unique and Fantastic Experience. We recently had a chance to experience the beautiful sights of Budapest on the truly unique Trabant Tour. This tour in the authentic Communist-era vehicles was perfect for our large group of 17 travelers looking for a differentiated way of experiencing the city. Andras did a fantastic job of providing insight throughout the tour, and his provision of two-way radios also made for fun and informative dialogue between the multiple cars. The sight of our six Trabants together was quite a sight, and often drew the attention (and pictures) of travelers throughout the city. I highly recommend this tour for both groups or individuals looking for a fun and unique way to experience Budapest!

What a fabulous way to spend a day in Budapest!". What a fabulous way to spend a day in Budapest! Andras and his family provide a unique opportunity to discover the city -- its history, culture, food and enterainment. The tour definitely lives up to the "personal Budapest" title. This all day adventure includes a fabulous Hungarian meal prepared by Andras' mother and served in their home. You will enjoy the "big picture" view of Budapest: walking through the shops of Fisherman's Bastion and stroll along the Bastion itself with its specatular views of the river and city. You will see Castle Hill along with other spectacular views of Budapest and the Danube River. Wear your walking shoes. Bring your camera. Prepare for a memorable day -- up close and personal in Budapest.

Wonderful cultural experience. My husband and I enjoyed Agnes teaching us Hungarian vegetarian cooking- that in itself is a challenge in meat loving Hungary. Our jointly cooked lunch was indeed delicious- ragout soup, paprika potatoes on little dumplings, and homemade apricot jam filled pancakes for dessert. What was special was our sharing of cooking, vegetable markets, wine preferences, working Mom's schedules, Grandparent roles and so on. This was our most intimate experience on Hungarian life, and we loved our visit to Budapest so much more because of our wonderful cooking class.

Having Fun Cooking Hungarian Food. My husband and I loved this class! We made Goulash Soup, Chicken Paprika, and Hungarian Apple Cake. Andrew was patient, funny, and informative. He taught us some new knife skills in addition to how to cook three delicious recipes. It was a private lesson in Andrew's clean and comfortable home. We did not the do the market tour. This was the highlight of our five days in Budapest. Take this class!

The most memorable part of our two week trip!. Andrew was delightful - friendly, knowledgeable, engaging. The meal we cooked together was terrific. Well worth both the time and the money! Don't pass up the opportunity Agnes and Andrew offer to experience, up close, the tastes of another culture.

One of the highlights of our Central European Trip. While in Budapest, our four-hour cooking class was definitely one of the highlights. We weren't able to do the Market tour due to time constraints, but thoroughly enjoyed our chance to cook with Andrew. There are only so many museums and cathedrals we can absorb -- and it was a pleasure to be able to choose the menu, learn about ingredients and access a bit of Hungarian culture in this way. The cooking was fun, the conversation very interesting and the results -- oh, my, delicious. The recipes we have and the specific cooking techniques we learned will be our best souvenir. We are having family over this weekend to prepare these dishes together -- and I know my grandchildren will love making their own bread puddings!We took the subway back and forth to the class and that was fun, as well. I wish one could somehow insert smells and tastes into a review -- that would be all you would need to know!

A genuine taste of Hungary.. Our group were four, two who live in Hungary and two from the UK.The day delivered exactly what had been offered. The tour of the market and tastings of various Hungarian specialities led by our excellent guide Andrew was great and added to the knowledge of those that had visited the market before.The preparation and cooking of the chosen dishes was well tutored and good fun and the completed meal was enjoyed by all.The day is very well planned and executed. It is really good that the package price includes everything, the market tastings, the taxi and drinks as well as the meal.It is so good that I have already booked our next visitors in for the day.

Wonderful experience. We had such a great time with Andrew, our chef and tour guide. We got to try local favorite at the market as well as buy some souvenirs. We had a tight schedule but he was very accommodating. I can wait to make goulash at home.

A unique experience..... I was traveling with a friend and we wanted to experience something more in Budapest than the museums and spas. This proved to be the answer. Andrew met us at the market, which in itself is a 'must see'. Do not eat before your tour, he provides big of samples typical Hungarian breakfast foods. We toured the downstairs food area and the upstairs souvenir stalls. ( if you want to buy souvenirs buy them here rather than the high street) then we took a taxi to Agnes apartment in Buda. Andrew was very patient and explained all the food ingredients and cooking methods. We had chosen our menu in advance. We are not experienced cooks but he made us chop, dice and roll......the meal was delicious. Goulash soup, chicken crepes and Apple cake....plus wine and coffee. The best meal we had in Budapest. Andrew answered my copious questions about Hungary. All in all a very successful day. I would highly recommend this class.

Culinary Hungary Home Cooking Class. My sister and I had a wonderful time learning to cook the "real" Hungarian way. We throughly enjoyed our Chef Andrew and his many skills and the way he explained the ingredients. We not only smelled them, we heard them. He has a way of explaining each piece of food and its color, crispness, smell and feel and why some cuts are better than others. We loved it.

second time- no regrets!. Two years ago we traveled to budapest and did the market tour. We had such a great time and were jealous of the couple who also was on the tour with us who had signed up for the cooking class and were shopping for some of the ingredients. so when we went back to Budapest this summer we signed up for the cooking class. Andrew was our guide and cooking instructor and it was as great as we had hoped. Before you arrive you can choose from several appetizers, entrees and desserts. We debated over a few and settled on a sour cream soup, chicken with pasta and floating island bourbon vanilla custard dessert. Mostly we wanted things that would show us something new and that we might actually be able to make again at home. I would say we chose well! For the pasta we learned how to make the noodles over boiling water, something we had never done before but can be easily done at home. Also, the floating island custard was maybe not something we would make every day but it is great to have an impressive dessert if I need one and just making the custard (and freezing it into popsicles) was a great post-trip summer treat. Andrew is a fantastic host and teacher and they send the recipes and instructions again after your lesson! Loved the whole thing, will do a different menu next time we are in Budapest!

We loved it....and so will our friends back home.. I traveled to Budapest with my two twenty something nieces, we had a wonderful time and this class was certainly one of the highlights. Andrew was personable and great fun, the four hours flew by. Highly recommended.

Something unique to do in Budapest if you love food.... We really enjoyed the company and knowledge of Andrew on our market tour and cookery class. The market is excellent and we thorough enjoyed the cookery with Andrew. What a fun and pleasurable way to spend a day in Budapest.

fantastic - a must do experience. We did not have time to do the full market tour as well as the cooking class so just opted to do the evening cooking class with Andrew. It was fantastic - I would definitely say a must do whilst in Budapest for a really different experience for an evening meal and a great edition to log for dinner parties when home! You can choose the three course menu from a variety of dishes, around five different options for each course. A few great tips picked up - cooking wise as well as other areas and some great anecdotes shared. This is something quite different to do suitable for all ages and group sizes

Great choice for intimate and friendly cooking. Definitely agree with the reviews that say not to eat breakfast, as we were too full to completely enjoy all the nibbles during the 9am market tour. We had a great time learning about the various meats, vegetables and spices that we purchased. I personally enjoyed the wine, while Andrew and my husband did most of the preparation - and the food was fantastic. Andrew was great company. All in all, a very enjoyable class!

Very interesting, & delicious!. I would highly recommend the market tour and cookery class!We met Andrew at the central market where we walked around as he explained all about the market, local produce and traditional Hungarian dishes. I would strongly advise skipping breakfast before the market tour as the food and nibbles we tried at the market were wide ranging and very filling. We cooked goulash soup, spicy meatballs and apple tart. It was all extremely good but the goulash soup was the standout dish, it was amazing!Andrew was very friendly and knowledgeable. He spoke perfect English and his instructions were easy to follow. Even if you don't pay attention Agnes will email all the recipes so you can cook them again when you get home. This is a great way to spend a day of your trip to Budapest, go early though as it will give you some great insight into Hungarian food for the rest of your stay.

Delightful event. We met at the market sharp on time, and enjoyed a "sampling breakfast" until we wanted no more. Definitely: don't have breakfast before. The visit to the Central Market is optional, but it is highly recommendable. We then cooked at Agnes' home, with Andras, and we had a great time. We enjoyed every minute of it. It is an expensive alternative in Budapest, but worth it.

Cooking class & more!!. Our 4-hour cooking class with Andrew was fantastic!! We were able to sample (and helped create) some traditional Hungarian dishes. The dishes were simple to prepare; hearty Goulash & Chicken Paprika along with some very tasty crepes for dessert. All the dishes were extremely tasty...best to show up hungry!The added bonus was the 'flavor' Andrew added to our experience. He made sure each of us was involved and also gave some great insights into local culture and history. We felt at home - both the course & Andrew's easy-going manner helped this. The course is not inexpensive but all 4 in our group felt it was well worth it. We would recommend this to any travelers.

Cooking delight!. Today my husband and I had a wonderful day learning about Hungarian cooking! Our chef and tour guide, Andrew, was a delight! He showed us all around the food market and treated us to many different types of typical Hungarian food. We shopped for our ingredients and walked around all the souvenir shops. We then took a taxi to the apartment and relaxed a little while before we started cooking. Andrew had been to Texas and we enjoyed talking with him about his travels. Then the cooking began. Andrew was very patient and explained and showed us exactly what to do. We made delicious guylas, chicken paprika, and cottage and jam crepes! We loved everything! We were pleased with the little surprise at the end. That was very thoughtful! I would highly recommend taking this class! It was a wonderful experience!

Hungarian Culinary Experience. Thank you for a memorable experience in Hungarian life through food, conversation, and cultural interaction. It was an educational and fun opportunity to learn and share the rich Hungarian history.

Great Activity!. We signed up for this cooking class with our 3 young adult sons who originally weren't thrilled about it. We all agreed that it turned out to be one of the best activities we did in Budapest. Andrew and Istvan ran the class and not only did we learn how to make goulash soup, chicken paprika, spätzle, and apple cake, but we had a wonderful time getting to know them and learning about Budapest! We loved the intimate setting and the real glimpse into Hungarian life and culture! Perfect activity with a small group! Agnes sent the recipes and I recreated the chicken paprika and spätzle at home. SO FUN!

Cooking class. Thanks so much. We had a great time with you...great company and wonderful food. We learned not only about Hungarian cusine but also about its culture. We wouldnt have got that out of a standard tour!

Delicious vege food with great company. This was clearly a highlight in our great weekend away to Budapest for my friend Elena and I. Andrew welcomed us with homemade Palinka and open arms into the cosy kitchen and we chatted over coffee and hungarian pastries while we got to know each other before the class. The 4 hours flew by, as we learnt delicious traditional meals, drank hungarian wine together and spent a lot of time getting to know each other through stories and laughing. Andrew was more than happy to answer all our eager questions about Hungarian traditions and his life in general. Elena and I have already cooked the mushroom paprikash for friends at home! Highly recommended.

Absolutely Fantastic Time!. My husband and I decided to do this cooking class while on a trip to get in touch with my Hungarian roots. I know a handful of Hungarian recipes, but this seemed like the perfect opportunity to expand upon that and learn some more traditional recipes. I have to say, this was the highlight of a month long trek through Europe (which included 7 other cities and numerous TripAdvisor activities). We had booked this activity before leaving on our trip, and I’m incredibly glad we did it. Agnes was a breeze to communicate with, and her responses were always quick, and before we knew it we were meeting Andrew at the Market Place at 9! Definitely do not eat breakfast if you opt for the market tour. While on a food tour in Berlin, our guide had told us we absolutely must do a food tour in Budapest – which this basically is if you opt to take the market tour. We sampled so many fine foods and treats it was essentially the same as a food tour – so, you pretty much get two activities done in one. Perfect! Andrew was simply the best host. He was entertaining, knowledgeable, and hilarious. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Not only did we leave there with some hands on knowledge on how to make cabbage rolls and soup, but Andrew was able to teach me a few tricks on how to improve my culinary technique – and I’ve been cooking for 10 years. This is an absolute must if you’re coming to Budapest. I highly recommend this class. It’s definitely beginner friendly (my husband had no difficulty helping out) and there are even some things for seasoned cooks as myself to learn. You pretty much end up eating the whole day so you won’t have to eat anything for breakfast, lunch, or supper. Definitely a 5 star activity.

Highlight of our Budapest stay. We went on a family trip to Budapest - ages from 77 to 14 years - and I wanted to plan a variety of experiences to keep everybody happy and engaged.Booking the market and cooking experience with Agnes and Andrew was definitely the perfect choice. Seeing granddad chop onions alongside his grandchildren while grandma and I sipped homemade Palinka was a perfect way to spend the day. It was not easy to agree on the menu but we settled for ragout soup, chicken paprikash with noodles and for pudding pancakes with a delicious cottage cheese filling. Agnes made us feel very much at home in her Budapest appartment and Andrew patiently showed us useful tips and tricks which will enhance all our cooking.The market tour was great as well and early enough to beat the rush of the tourists.If you want to give your feet a rest from sightseeing and your brains from all the historical facts - this is a great choice to experience this beautiful city from a different perspective. A winner for all age groups!

fun class, great food. 2 colleagues and I made goulash soup, paprika chicken and floating island for dessert. Andrew is good at explaining the cooking steps and also very entertaining. We really enjoyed ourselves!

Unique local experience!. This is well-deserved, and long overdue, review of one of the highlights of our November 2015 visit to Budapest. We joined Agnes, our chef, for a tour of the market (trying, unsuccessfully, to limit our snacking along the way), then departed with her to her lovely kitchen. Aprons for all, a sip of local palinka, and the instruction and cooking begins! Agnes is a delight - as was her beautiful young family, whom we met at the end of the day - and her instruction on Hungarian cuisine is clear, pragmatic and insight-giving. And our class-prepared meal, delicious! Definitely a highlight of our trip.

Pretty good. We opted for the market tour and cookery class combined. The market tour gave us a chance to sample a variety of different foods and to shop for the ingredients we used in the cookery class. The cookery class itself was good. The instruction was good, and we enjoyed it. This course is on the more expensive end of cookery courses we have done, and takes place in a home environment. Our only criticism would be it was a bit expensive for what it was.

Highlight of My Trip. I opted for the combined market tour and cooking class and was glad I did. I had already made a quick visit to the market for lunch from one of the food stalls a couple of days earlier, but we ate our way through several different items that I would not have ordered because they were unfamiliar, and I liked all of them. It was also interesting to tour the market (one of my favorite things to do when traveling anyway) and have unfamiliar items identified for me.The cooking class was excellent. Andrew steered me toward recipes he thought I could reproduce with ingredients available in the US. We made sausage and potato soup (my favorite of the three), stuffed cabbage rolls, and poppyseed bread pudding. The class involved a good mix of observing and doing, and then the recipes were emailed to me afterwards.I think this day was the best one of my trip.

Fantastic evening with Andrew the Chef. I reserved a cooking class with Agnes and Andrew as a Christmas present for my boyfriend and I could not have been more pleased with the care and service throughout. Agnes always replied to emails the same day and was kind enough to let me give the choices for the food for the class after Christmas Day so my boyfriend could choose. As for the class itself Agnes and Andrew made us feel so welcome instantly and Andrew had us laughing all evening. Very easy and relaxed environment and the cooking was great fun. Most of all everything we cooked was delicious!! Would recommend to anyone who loves cooking and who wants to learn more about Hungarian food!

Making A famous Bean Soup in Budapest. We had a wonderful culinary Hungary Home Cooking experience in Budapest with Andrew. Agnes, the business owner, was traveling so our chef instructor was Andrew. He is a professional sous chef and has worked extensively in the US so he speaks perfect English, understands how Americans usually approach cooking and life in general, and is a patient guy with a passion for good food. It was especially fun to learn that he had managed a restaurant kitchen and club in New Jersey, near where our son lives now. What a small world.A quick summary of my recommendations, in case you don't want to read all the details that follow:- Talk to Agnes about your menu beforehand, to make sure you get the kind of experience you want. Gulas soup and chicken paprikash are not your only options.- Come seriously hungry as the day is filled with more good food than most human beings can eat. Skip breakfast before coming to the market.- Take a camera to capture what the food looks like at various stages and consider taking some notes as well, as there are some critical details in handling some things that are hard to get from a recipe. The details are important.- Come in a small group - 2 or 3 people maybe. They can handle larger groups but that kitchen was perfectly sized for 2 or 3 and more might be crowded.Details:The day began with a meeting at the main city market just off the Danube on the Pest side. We shopped for the ingredients for the meal and Andrew gave us a tour of the snack opportunities in the market for breakfast. It was really a huge amount of food and we couldn't eat all of it, so skip breakfast on the morning of your market visit. In fact, consider fasting for about 2 days before the day, just to give yourself enough appetite for everything you will encounter to eat. :)The teaching kitchen itself is in an apartment well up on the Buda side but the taxi ride was pretty quick (By Budapest standards - traffic is never light). We got there just in time for some tea and a shot of homemade Palinka (How you say "moonshine" in Hungarian, but actually what the French would call an eau de vie - fruit brandy.) It was good and warming and then we started cooking.We had already been living in Hungary for 3 months so we asked to learn more complex dishes beyond gyulas soup and chicken paprikash. If you are not sure about what you want to cook, I suggest chatting with Agnes first as there are a number of choices. We wanted some dishes that we had tried to cook ourselves already but were sure we did not get right. That proved correct as what we cooked with Andrew was much better than anything we had managed on our own. The difference seemed to be in both the selection of ingredients and in some specific techniques in cooking.There was plenty of hands on experience and good wine to drink as we went along. Hungarian food is tremendously wine friendly so enjoy it with a glass of something good. Cooking Hungarian food is also wine friendly so have two glasses.When you are finished, at about 3 PM, you will need to get down the hill and back to wherever you are staying in Budapest. They can certainly help you get a taxi or offer some ideas on public transport . There is a metro stop about 15 minutes walk down hill (Under construction at the moment but still operating) or you can walk a little more down to the Danube and have other choices. After that meal, a walk might feel good (it did to us).For dinner that evening, plan a light salad.

Highly Recommend . Six of us traveling together had a great time with Agnes and Andre. We loved the central market and they walked us around there giving us plenty of time to do a little shopping and tasting along the way. They were also helpful with bargaining and telling us which stalls to buy things. The cooking class was superb as they showed us what to do but let us do it. They made sure the local wine kept flowing and we kept enjoying our time in Agnes' home. The food was wonderful - thanks so much, Agnes and Andre, for a great day. Highly recommend.

Delightful day in Buda. I received a referral to contact Agnes from a posting placed in International Travel News Magazine. It was the best referral I received! After emailing Agnes, I received a prompt response and we set the class in motion. Agnes met me and two friends at the designated meeting spot for a tour of the market and to purchase our supplies for the class. As a special treat, she provided MANY taste treats along the way while shopping. (pay attention when she says have a light breakfast!) At the end of our market excursion, she called a cab and we were promptly whisked away to the Buda side of town for an adventure in culinary excellence. One of the really nice things about her class is that you get to choose the menu in advance, so you know it's something you are interested in and will most probably like. You will prepare and enjoy a 3 course meal that is fun, reasonably easy and delectable. My friends and I chose Bean and Sausage Soup, Stuffed Peppers and Poppyseed bread pudding. All of which were delicious and we can't wait to make ourselves, now that we've returned to the States. Agnes, THANK YOU for being so kind, welcoming and a chef extraordinaire!

A Budapest visit highlight. From Agnes' prompt reply to emails to book the market tour and cooking class to her warm welcome in her home, we had a wonderful experience. The time flew by as we learned about Hungarian cooking and traditions. The potato & sausage soup, chicken paprikash & apple cake were delicious. The market tour should not be missed. Many thanks to Agnes & family.

At home away from home. Agnes was an absolute wonderful host. She has a great love of life and food! When she tells you to eat a very light breakfast, don't eat a breakfast! The tour through the market was educational and delicious. I would probably have never tried the dishes that she got 'samples' from the various food vendors. The samples would probably feed 3 or 4 people but we had to save room for our meal that we were going to cook together. Her home is very welcoming and perfect for the event. She is very attentive to the different cooking skill levels and if you need a bit of coaxing there is palinka! I would recommend that if you only have time for one event in Budapest, then spending the day with Agnes is what it should be.

Get your apron on!. If you're looking for an informal and intimate cooking class this is the place. The big plus is that you have control over the menu based on a wide selection of choices from their website. The class will be at your pace and you will definitely leave satisfied. We spent about an hour in the Grand Market buying the groceries and sampling some classic Hungarian dishes. A short taxi ride to Anges' apartment is also a treat as you get to spend some time in Buda that is not part of the tourist area. You'll get a true sense of how the locals live. Unlike the more regimented cooking classes where you are one of 20 or more, this class is small and you never feel intimidated. Thank you Andrew for a memorable day! We left so full that we skipped dinner that night!!

Agnes...You have made my wife's day !!. I booked this cooking class for my wife as a surprise during our Trip to Budapest, and yes, I was afraid at first as this is our first time doing a cooking class at a house of a family we never knew before...but as soon as you walk through Agnes's door, and meet her lovely kids....you instantly feel as if you are just visiting a family member and hey...how about cooking ? Agnes is a serious cook, just like my wife :) and this is why they got along together big time !! we cooked Chicken Paprika, Potato Soup and a beautiful finish with puppy seed desert... it was a cooking class never to forget. thank you Agnes for your amazing and warm welcome... we appreciate your time and your work and the love you put into your food. looking forward to seeing you in Dubai whenever you fly here !!

A Taste of Budapest. What a fantastic way to spend a morning and experience the true taste of Hungary. My daughter and I are both keen cooks, so this was a perfect way to spend a morning. Andrew, our host, welcomed us with nibbles and Parlinka and then guided us through all the steps of the recipes whilst regaling us with stories of Hungarian food. Of course the highlight was actually eating our creations and if I say so myself, we did a rather good job. It was delicious and I can't wait to recreate the recipes at home. If you like food, this is the perfect activity for you. Don't forget to take a camera with you to capture some of the moments. Thank you Andrew, we had a fabulous time.

Everyone Loved this Authentic Experience!. We booked this class with Andrew just a few weeks before our trip to Budapest and with the hope that our teenage and young adult sons would enjoy touring the market place and learning more about cooking. We are from Seattle and have high expectations for a city market, but from the moment we stepped into Central Market, we were enthralled! Around every corner he shared a traditional food, goodie or treat. Upon entering the apartment, we spent a few minutes bonding before donning aprons and chopping away. Andrew was very instructive and entertaining. My boys learned so much from him! We spent about 4 1/2 hours with him total and as we left rolling down the street toward the metro stop, the boys proclaimed it was the best dinner they'd had on vacation. Well worth the price!

Great food, great company :) . Agnes was fast to respond to our request and we opted for the market and cooking class option. It costs more than I can typically afford but we were really impressed with what we'd heard about Agnes and Andrew so I figured I would give it a go. I'm very glad we did, there is something much more personal about being in another country and buying food in the market and then making their traditional dishes in comparison to simply eating it at a restaurant. It was a dreadfully hot day and we were all drenched with sweat but the food was delicious, every part of the tour was worth the cost and I feel like we get to take a piece of Hungary home. Yes of course you can visit a market on your own, but it is nice to have a grand tour and tips from someone friendly and in the know. You can look up recipes on the internet or visit a restaurant but Andrew is a qualified sous chef and he is so helpful and so friendly. The day flew by and it will definitely be a highlight of Budapest for us both. Thanks heaps to both Agnes and Andrew! Ps - the crepes option for mains is absolutely delicious, give it a go!

YUMMM!!!!. Andrew was able to fit us in for a cooking class very last minute and we were so thankful because it was one of our favorite parts of our trip to Budapest! We made chicken paprikash, goulash soup, spaetzle, and apple strudel. It was so delicious and we felt very comfortable as his directions were easy to follow and he helped show us efficient cooking and cutting methods. Plus, we got alot of attention and practice since it was only my husband, Andrew, and I there. The class was held in a local home and he sent us all the recipes so we could attempt to recreate them at home! We even got a special present at the end (but I don't want to spoil the surprise)!

Must Do!. If you enjoy food and cooking this is an absolute must. It was the best day I had in Budapest. My friends and I met our guide/chef Andrew at the grand market to sample various Hungarian cuisine and to buy our groceries for our meal. We then took a cab to an apartment to begin cooking our meal. Andrew taught us step by step what we needed to do to make our 3 course meal. He was friendly and easy to talk to making the experience comfortable. Not only did I learn about Hungarian food but I learned some kitchen skills as well. The food we made was delicious and I can't wait to replicate it again at home. Once the day was completed, we did receive an email with all of the recipes. Everyone should try this experience.

It's a must-do if you enjoy cooking!. What a great day! We decided to take a cooking class in Budapest since both of us have Hungarian roots and grew up eating the cuisine. We met Andrew at the market at 9am and had a full meal before we left while browsing the stalls and craft vendors and learning about Hungarian culture, history, and food. He is so friendly and knowledgeable (and speaks perfect English). Then we took a taxi to the apartment and began our cooking. He made it seem so easy and infused our lesson with cooking tips, info on Hungarian culture, etc. We made sour cherry soup, chicken paprika, and apple cake. It was all so delicious and we can't wait to try it at home.Agnes was very responsive via email and everything is just as she described. Definitely a must do in Budapest if you love food and/or cooking!

Wonderful morning full of food and culture. My friend and I had the great pleasure of learning to cook some Hungarian dishes with Agnes during our stay in Budapest. Agnes was warm and accommodating and taught us a lot about Hungarian food and culture. My favorite part of traveling is getting to know locals and what daily life is like. While cooking (which Agnes had perfectly planned and timed) we discussed life in the city and country, and what it was like during the Russian occupation. Agnes was open and willing to share about her life, which made the experience all the more special. We had the option to choose what we wanted to cook beforehand and it was all extremely delicious. Afterwards, Agnes sent us the recipes for the dishes we cooked, along with many other recipes. Since being back home, I have tried to cook the Hungarian Stuffed Cabbage Rolls per the recipe and they tasted just like in class! Agnes gifted us some ground caraway seeds, as they can be tricky to find elsewhere. I cannot rave enough about our wonderful experience. If I am every back in Budapest, I will be back to learn more!

A Wonderful Day. This was a great experience. My mom and I met Andrew at the Market. As others have said - skip breakfast. We had lots of samples of food in the market. We also bought our groceries for our cooking class. The coooking lesson was great fun. We made the fruit soup - which was very refershing on a hot day. Andrew was upbeat and very friendly. This was a great day and a great experience. My only suggestion is for Agnes to offer some suggested menus - we changed our menu and it was great.

A great day at the market. Whether you want to learn how to make local cuisine, meet local people or just get away from looking at monuments and museums, this is a wonderful way to spend a day. Andrew was a great host and cook, and we had a lot of fun. But don’t skip the market trip because it might be the best part of your day.

Definition of "Home" Cooking. Agnes was not there for our cooking class, but her colleague Andrew was fantastic. The entire afternoon was relaxed and friendly. My boyfriend and I are not skilled cooks but were taught how to prepare the dishes step by step. I felt completely at home in Agnes' humble apartment. Also, Agnes has been great to communicate with - very helpful and even sent me some extra vegetarian recipes after the class!

Great culinary and cultural experience of Budapest!. My friend and I booked ourselves onto this class on the first day of our Budapest trip. Unfortunately, we were not able to do the market tour as it was a bank holiday, but it didn't make the experience any less enjoyable. We were greeted by the very knowledgable and friendly chef, Andrew, who welcomed us with some background chat and a completmentary treat. (Hungarian sausage with bread, and a shot of home-made plum spirit; yes, the thought of doing shot at 10am is scary but it was very nice and really warms you up!!)Then we get down to the cooking; we picked the menu since it was just the two of us for the class; fruit soup, chicken parpirikash and floating island for deeset. We had tons of fun making all of these delicious but easy to make course, interjected by several fun stories or some history from the tutor (who used to be a sous chef in the US) There is no doubt that his perfect English, geat manner and culinary knowledge are the reasons why our lunch was enjoyable!! We left very full and satisfied in every aspects.On a separate note, Hungarian dishes can be rather filling, so be hungry and might be a good idea to plan your meal properly beforehand; and make no dinner booking!

A Must Do...... A trip to Budapest would not be complete without a true local experience. Learning how to cook traditional Hungarian food with Andrew was truly a delight. We made the Jokai Bean Soup, Stuffed Cabbage and Pancakes. Of course we had to make the very same meal for our family when we arrived back in the States while telling them about our wonderful Budapest trip. Thank you Agnes and thank you Andrew!!!

Enjoyable home cooking experience. My husband and I spent a very enjoyable day with Andrew preparing our lunch (and drinking wine of course). The dishes turned out great, and it was the best meal we had in Budapest. Just shows you don't need fancy equipment and fixtures to prepare a wonderful meal.Andrew is very nice and outgoing, and had everything set up before our arrival so we didn't waste any time. Agnes (who could not be there) answers emails quickly. A lovely day!

Wonderful home cooking class. Very nice experience. This was a good basic cooking class that gives you the real feel for traditional home cooking in Hungary. Agnes and Andrew were very flexible with scheduling, had great communication, overall it was a great experience. Andrew lead me through a private cooking class, with insight to local culture, foods and great conversation. I recommend this for anyone that wants to see what real home cooking is like in Budapest.

Very nice experience and introduction into Hungarian food & culture.. First, I was on a visit to Budapest and I wanted to learn about Hungarian cuisine. I must say that I was alone to participate in cooking classes. I met Andrew at The Great Market and it made me do a guided tour. The Great Market is a beautiful place, it's a place to discover. There was everything and more, you can make tasting. Importantly, do not overeat before going there. I have passed a very nice moment with Andrew to cook and talking about everything and take a glass of wine. That was very nice, I never met Agnes but she always answer me at all of my questions and she was very generous for Hungarian recipes. Her and Andrew was very professional.Thank you so much Andrew and Agnes

Absolutely amazing and a great insight into Hungarian culture/food. We did this cooking class with Andrew the second day we arrived into Budapest and it did not disappoint. We had a private class with just my husband and I and therefore the class was catered to us. We met Andrew at the big Central Market and were given a tour of the market and tastings of local food, all while buying produce for the class itself. We then went to cook the menu we had selected earlier upon making the booking. The menu was three courses, all vegetarian to cater for myself and it was amazing. What we loved even as much as the food was the chance to get to talk to Andrew and through this we feel we got a good understanding of Hungary and its culture. These cooking classes are amazing and we could not recommend them enough! Thanks so much Andrew (p.s we put the present to use tonight when cooking at home, thanks!)

Fun and Informative Time Learning How to Cook Hungarian With Andrew. A wonderful way to spend a day in Budapest. Andrew met us at The Great Market and invited us to try some Hungarian delicacies. He then gave us a tour while purchasing what we needed for our cooking lesson (bean soup, stuffed peppers and poppy seed bread pudding). Back at the apartment he taught us to prepare these dishes and also gave us a lesson in Hungarian customs and cooking traditions (always use lard). It was truly a great experience.

Fun cooking class. Both the market tour and cooking class were excellent. Thanks Andrew for a great day and thanks Agatha for the flexibility in setting it up. I will make a lot of Jókai been soup in the future.

Really great time. Learning how to properly use and cook with paprika was only one if the many highlights of the class. Our walk thru the market was interesting and informative. Agi was wonderful at leading us thru several traditional dishes. It was one if the best cooking classes I've taken on a vacation.

Fantastic day in Budapest!. We had such a great time touring the Central Market with Agi and cooking too! She went above and beyond altering our menu to satisfy my vegetarian diet but allowing my husband to enjoy meat dishes too. It was very interesting to visit a local apartment, immerse in the culture and spend a day shopping and cooking, just beware of getting very full!! We would definately do this again, and recommend this tour to any visitors to Budapest!

Our favorite activity in Budapest!. My sister and I took this cooking class together and it was our favorite thing we did the whole trip. Agi was very nice and explained things thoroughly as we went along. She was able to put together a delicious vegetarian menu for us of vegetable ragu, potato paprika and cottage cheese calls for dessert. Everything was so delicious! We even had hungarian wine and some brandy along the way. Highly recommend!

Wonderful cooking class, delicious recipes easily recreated at home!. We had a short time in Budapest, but read so many wonderful things about the cooking class wee decided it was a "must do." We were not disappointed. Agi and Andrew took us on a wonderful tour of the market and introduced us to many of the items we would be using in the dishes. We noshed on items from the upstairs food vendors and shopped for groceries to complete our meals. This was wonderful because it gave us an opportunity to discuss items that could be substituted for ingredients not available for us at home. Once back at the apartment the fun began. Agi and Andrew were patient in their teaching allowing us to be fully hands on. We talked, laughed, cooked and then enjoyed a fabulous lunch together. Eat light before you meet at the market. If we have the opportunity to return to Budapest we will definitely take another class.

Home cooking at its best. The welcome from Agi and Andrew was amazing. They opened their home and instructions were superb. I was born in Budapest but never learned the fine art of cooking Hungarian foods. It was the best morning I have spent, I was instructed with clarity and much humour. English was spoken if required. I learned a lot and enjoyed the fruits of my labour. The food was delicious. Agi even sent me off with a bag of homemade paprika which I now use to impress my friends with my culinary skills. I would definitely go back...if you want the real home cooking experience do not miss this. Thank you Agi and Andrew.

A delicious traditional Hungarian food experience. I have just returned from an amazing European trip with my hubby and our best friends and during our time in beautiful Budapest we booked a cooking class with Agi, as I have a small home-based food business in Australia (Canefields Kitchen) and wanted to learn how to cook some Hungarian food from the experts. Agi was on holiday so my friend Ros and I enjoyed a fabulous cooking experience with Agi's co-cook Andrew. It was a wonderful morning and we learnt so much about Hungarian food, culture and lifestyle. The class was held at Agi's apartment, that was easy to get to by the Metro, and was homely and comfortable to work in. The food was simple and delicious and we loved the commentary of Andrew who was a delightful young man with lots of interesting facts and information to share. The food was fun to cook and was very tasty. We also experienced the traditional drink Palinka and some very nice Hungarian wine.Thanks Andrew! we loved the whole experience. Deb & Ros

Very fun and great way to immerse yourself in the culture. My sister and I took this cooking class last month and we were really pleased! Agnes wasn't available so Andrew hosted our class in Agnes' flat and he did a great job of teaching/engaging us and is quite the conversationalist on many topics and he is also well travelled. All this really contributed to a great cultural immersion! Highly recommended.

Cooking my Mother's Recipes. I grew up eating Hungarian, but never did learn how to really make it taste like home. Books help, but nothing beats hands on learning from people who know and enjoy what they are doing.This was our third cooking class with Agnes and Andrew. And, it won't be the last.The best thing about our experience is that it was more like being invited to a friend's house to help cook a meal than it was a class. Great company sharing stories and tips.Oh, the food...we made a creamy, non dairy cauliflower soup, a main called vadas, which is slow cooked beef in a vegetable sauce and, since my wife is allergic to rising yeast, we made sweet walnut roll called beigli, but without yeast. The final grade for our class was A.Very highly recommended.John

Now we're talking "local" experience!!. Now we're talking!! Tired of the excessively "touristic" spots? Take the class! I've been travelling around and was a little bit tired of castles, monuments, walls, churches, etc. and decided to take a break from all that and do something really "local". It was quite a surprise to get inside someone else's home, take a chair, chat and cook! It was worthy! They spoke good English (just in case you are like me, speaking one or maybe two words in hungarian). Now I will take back to Brazil what I've learned from Andrew and will try this at home...

Don't hesitate- worth every penny!. My boyfriend and I were traveling to Budapest and were looking for some unique things to do that would give us a little more insight into the culture. the BF is more of a cook than I am and he found this cooking class/tour here on trip advisor. I must admit, I was not thrilled at the prospect since I am a terrible cook so we opted for the tour only. We showed up at the market, which is beautiful and were greeted by Agnes and Andrew. Another traveling couple who were doing the cooking portion also joined and I can honestly say that by about 10 minutes in, I fully regretted that we had not also signed up for the cooking. However, even just the tour was fantastic. Others on here say not to eat beforehand- listen to them!! You will be stuffed full of delicious food by the end of the tour. They took us through all levels of the building, buying foods and explaining them to us while we tasted them (A&A take care of the purchasing, all you have to do is choose when they give you options). My mind swims with the delicious, new things we tried. Agnes even had brought some homemade palinka. It is a bit silly, but I like to try alcohol in different countries that is less available in the US (e.g. Baijiu in China, becherovka in czech republic...) and palinka was on my list, alas my research had also said that most locals know someone who makes it and drink that rather than mass produced stuff. So I was delighted that we got a chance to try something I would have had no other option for as a tourist who knows no one in Hungary (it was quite good!). The food that you taste ranges from salty to sweet, extremely heavy to, well, less heavy but it is always good. My favorite had to be the chocolate cream cheese treat from the dairy part, my bf does not even like sweets but insisted we go back the next day and get some more. There is also a little tourist shopping area on the third floor. Agnes helped me figure out where to find a little clip-on leather coin purse that a friend who had been in budapest a few years before specifically asked me to bring her. Agnes and Andrew also gave us some tips on what to look for in some items when buying them for souvenirs. Other highlights of the market tour included seeing the mushroom sorting station that any local can bring in when they find mushrooms (the workers at the station take out all the poisonous ones, has a large area of models so you can see how to identify them), all of Agnes and Andrew's anecdotes about foods preparation of food, etc. and just getting to tag along as they selected the ingredients for the other couple's chosen meal. We even learned how to identify the different types of paprika and paprika peppers as well as how we might use any given animal part in a meal. Its one of those experiences that really sticks with you. We walked away full, happy with our delightful hosts, excited to venture into the city's restaurants and use our knowledge and overall just happy to have broadened what we know about the world in an interesting way. Next time I'm in budapest, I would do it again, but this time I would do the cooking too.

Great Experience!. My fourteen year old son and I took a class with Agi and Andrew in June. Emails were answered quickly and thoroughly. Arranging the class was painless and Agi was always happy to answer any questions. The directions to the class location were accurate and easy to follow. Agi and Andrew were great teachers and had us happily cooking and tasting throughout the morning. We made goulash soup with noodles, chicken paprikash with dumplings and apple cake. All of which turned out great and tasted awesome. Agi emailed the recipes to us after the class, and told us where to buy the paprika she used so we could replicate the dishes at home. Both Agi and Andrew are very personable and made us both feel very welcome. We continued to tour Europe for 3 more weeks and still my son says this cooking class was a highlight of our trip. I would highly recommend this class!

Absolutely Great !!!. After reading about Culinary Hungary on Trip Advisor, I emailed an inquiry. I heard back quickly from Agi and began to make arrangements for our group of six. (I had also sent an inquiry for several tours and another cooking class, but didn't hear back from them for 4-6 days.) From the market tour to cooking with Agi and Andrew in Agi's kitchen, our group had a great time. Both Agi and Andrew are very personable as well as being very good instructors. We loved the food we cooked and the class was definitely the highlight of our trip. We hope to do another class with them in the future. We highly recommend this class if you visit Budapest.

Great experience!. Our cooking class with Agi was a totally enjoyable experience. We met her at her flat and we then walked to the local market to buy what we needed to cook. For additional cost she will take you on a tour of the Central Market, but we felt this local market was actually more realistic since it's where she shops every day.She explained everything that we were seeing and even treated us to a langos, which is the Hungarian fry bread with sour cream and cheese on top. She also bought us a couple of packets of ground caraway to take home since it's a big ingredient in Hungarian cooking and hard to find in the US. Once back at her flat, she, along with her helper, Andrew, involved us in all the steps and preparation of cooking our meal. She suggested that instead of the Gundel pancake that we had selected to cook, that we make a cottage cheese pancake (Palacsinta) as it was much more normal Hungarian fare. (The Gundel pancake being a specialty of one of the restaurants in Budapest, but not something that is cooked at home in Hungary.) We made Goulash soup, cabbage rolls stuffed with pork, and the pancakes. Agi was very good at making sure that we understood how things were supposed to look and taste as we were preparing them. We would occasionally stop between preparations and have Pahlinka shots and wine while she explained about other aspects of Hungarian cooking that we were not covering in what we were cooking. She and Andrew also shared a good bit about their life in Hungary. Well worth the money and we also took home leftovers and warmed them up for dinner at our B&B. Really cute to have her 2 year old watch us while we cooked. This class was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to Central Europe.

Excellent experience and it got my teenagers interested in cooking!. My husband found Anges and Andrew via Tripadvisor and our family of 4 (including two teenagers aged 13 and 15) had a fantastic day. They were on time, took us on a personalized tour of the very clean Budapest market, bought our supplies (as well as some tourist trinkets - they were VERY patient) and headed off to Agnes' apartment to cook. They were exceedingly personable, very funny, patient with our newbie cooks, and we made some terrific dishes! We had a fantastic day and our kids were very excited to receive the recipes from Agnes when we got home. I know I won't be able to make the beef stew as good as Agnes did, but we will be trying :). Well worth the money and time spent.

Excellent meal, great company. We did the market tour and cooking class with Agnes and Andrew. The Market Tour involved sampling palinka (at 9 am!), langos, and several other Hungarian items. After the tour and buying a few items needed for our meal, we went to Agnes' apartment and started cooking. We make Fruit soup, catfish paprikas, and sponge cake. We enjoyed cooking and chatting with Agnes and Andrew and learning more about the Hungarian culture. When the cooking was done, we enjoyed a delicious meal. Even my husband who tries very hard to avoid the kitchen at home said this was a highlight of the trip for him.

Just great!!!!. We booked a market tour with Agnes and Andrew and enjoyed it A LOT!!!!!!!!!!They are such a nice and friendly couple and made sure we were having a good time and that we all could taste everything we wanted.We started with a little Palinka for "breakfast" und afterwards tried Langos and wonderful "potpourri" of different typical Hungarian dishes including blood sausages,Tarhonya,Gulash and other stews.We walked the whole market and they told us a lot about local food and habits.I really loved this tour because if I had gone to the markethall alone,I would never have tried and tasted all these things.I would have strolled through but probably much faster and in a more "touristic way".I highly recommend this tour to everyone who enjoys food and likes tasting all kind of things and all that in a very casal and uncomplicated atmosphere.

Fun and delicious way to learn about Hungary. If you enjoy meeting local people and learning about their culture and way of life you have to take this class. My friends and I had three days to spend in Budapest and we wanted to do something really unique to learn more about Hungarian culture. We found Agi here on Trip Advisor and were lucky enough that she was able to take us around and give us a cooking class the next day. Agi met us at the market and showed us around the different stalls, bought us samples of the different Hungarian delicacies to try while also teaching us a little Hungarian history at the same time. We picked up fresh ingredients for the meal we would cook and headed back to her apartment. Once we arrived at her apartment we got to work cooking our delicious meal.
