We made a delicious bean soup, chicken paprikash, egg noodles, a cucumber salad, and for dessert we made cottage cheese dumplings. Agi made everything very easy to learn and we did everything from scratch. The whole time flew by as we drank wine, and chatted about life in Hungary and in the U.S. while we cooked. My friends and I immediately felt right at home. We learned a lot of great cooking tips and recipes which I have already successfully made again. By the end of our meal we were all stuffed and very happy. This experience was the highlight of our trip and I would highly recommend signing up!

Warm Cultural Cooking Experience. Agi helped my girlfriend and me cook the stuffed cabbage, sausage and potato soup, and sponge cake. They were delicious! She guided us through each step of the process and explained it according to our skill level. Wine and traditional bread with pork lard was served upon arrival.

Fantastic experience. We did both the market tour and cooking with Agi. The market tour was a lot of fun, Agi spent time explaining about the things we were looking at.she had told us before comiing not to have too much breakfast and this was a good thing, she organised lots of samples of food for us to try.we had alot of fun. Agi then organised a taxi to take us back to her place. We spent time cooking, Agi was very patient with us and made the expeience lots of fun. She was very organised and made us feel really comfortable in her home. Food was amazing with a lot of help from Agii. We thank her very much for the most memorable time in Budapest.

Experience authentic Budapest catering. This experience was the highlight of a wonderful few days in this gorgeous city. From the minute we arrived in Agi's home we felt welcome and knew this was going to be a brilliant experience.  We were late (don't ask) but this didn't faze her at all, we were met with a glass of pulinka and canapes and after a short introductory chat we set to work. This was no impersonal industrial cookery school but the warm heart of Agi's home,In the 3 hours we were with her we made goulash soup, paprika chicken and Somloi Gluska for dessert. Everything was explained with lots of handy tips (we're both keen cooks but still picked up tips on when to season, how best to skin a chicken and so on) all accompanied with a very nice red wine. We then sat down to a long leisurely lunch when we chatted about the Hungarian way of life and learned about traditional customs and celebrations - so much more interesting than reading up on the subject!When we left we were surprised with a lovely gift (wont spoil the surprise) and as soon as we got home we had copies of our recipes emailed to us complete with more handy tips.This was a wonderful experience and one which we'd love to repeat both with Agi and in other cities.

Best meal in Budapest. This was the first thing we signed up for when we started planning our Eastern European trip. My husband and I were so excited and looked forward to it for months. And it was so worth the wait. We booked on line and handled all of the details via e-mail. This worked perfectly. Agi was prompt and detailed with instructions and options. Word of advice: do not hesitate to make your reservations.We wanted the full day class, the one where you go the market first them go back to make your dishes, but that was already booked for the days we had allocated to Budapest, Also the market is closed on Sundays so that day is not and option to begin with. But not to worry Agi met with us on Sunday and she had already done the necessary shopping for our dish choices. Both her and her husband met us that morning in their flat, we had a nice meet and greet, then he had to leave for errands. That's when the cooking began. Agi is VERY well organized. We did all of the chopping and dicing while she explained about the ingredients and history behind the.dishes. She knew about the wines she paired and showed us where they grew. She had suggestion about touring the wine regions and a tour guide lead. We did everything to prepare the 3 dished we choose and by lunch time it was time to enjoy the fruits of our labor. I must say they were fabulous! We even got to take the leftovers back with us to enjoy again. I highly recommend this activity, it was a highlight of our month long trip.

The highlight of our time in Budapest. We met Agi at the Great Market at 9AM and the next 6 hours were a blend of Hungarian delights. We tasted delicious foods in the market, saw hand made crafts, learned about the foods that make Hungarian cuisine unique. We visited all three floors of the market and experienced a part of Budapest that many tourists never see. Then we went to Agi's home to cook our Hungarian meal. Cucumber salad, Potato and sausage soup, Chicken paprika, and Poppy seed bread pudding were all on our menu. At her home we learned about Hungarian history, culture, and traditions.. Her passion for cooking and her desire to share traditional Hungerian cuisine was evident all day. This is truly an experience not to be missed while in Budapest.

A wonderful experience. The cooking class and tour that we had with Agnes was a wonderful experience. The market was amazing and Agnes' pride in her country and the knowledge of what was local was very much appreciated . The cooking class managed to suit two people with differing levels of experience and enthusium for cooking-both of us learned new techniques and hints for easier home cooking and we had a great time. I cannot stress enough how happy we were to have this experience and how much we were able to learn in the short time we had with Agnes about cooking and Budapest.

Welcome home.. Thanks Agi for a most enjoyable time and delicious meal and a welcome home to be in. The slippers and apron felt like we were at a relatives for a wonderful afternoon of cooking, eating, drinking and having fun. Loved the shopping together and felt like I was with my daughter and family. It felt so great to be a part of the "real Hungary". Can't wait to do it again and this experience would be on my must do list especially to see your new kitchen when you find it! Best of luck and Aloha.

Most Memorable Budapest Experience. My Sister and I were looking for an experience that would help us experience the culture of our four grandparents who immigrated to America from Hungary in the early 1900's. We had an enchanting day with Agnes who met us in front of the Central Market at 9AM and explained all of the different foods available as we gathered the ingredients for our lunch. Some of the items we remembered from our childhood of family meals cooked by one of our Grandmothers, but there were also many items new to us that were not common in our household. We felt like we belonged in Hungary as it all felt very familiar to us, the language, the food, but Agnes made us feel like native Hungarians. What a wonderful time we had and I hope we can return to Budapest some day so we can spend another day with Agnes and cook another delicious meal. Make sure you include this in your Budapest itinerary - it was the very best part of our trip!

wonderful experience. We were a family of four, with a 24 year old son and 14 year old daughter. We got back from Budapest a few weeks ago but wanted to share how much we enjoyed this cooking class. Agi had all the ingredients ready for us when we arrived at her lovely home. We met her husband and toddler, who were very gracious. After giving us some of her family Palinka, she proceeded to talk about Hungary and its customs while sharing some wonderful wine with us ( our daughter had grape juice, as determined ahead of time). We chopped, laughed, stirred, laughed, and had a great old time preparing our meal. If you want to try something different one afternoon, instead of hitting a restaurant, give this a try. Agi's instruction and the wonderful meal we cooked together made for great fun. She even had an unexpected surprise for us at the end, which was really kind and appreciated. Our kids were thrilled and so were we!

A wonderful lunch experience.. We did not take Agi's cooking class, but had the pleasure of enjoying one of her home cooked lunches in conjunction with a day trip tour we took with My Personal Budapest. The meal was excellent, and the discussion about Hungarian cooking methods, local wines, and shopping all made for a memorable afternoon. I would highly recommend any event with Agi.

Best Day in Budapest. What an amazing day we had with Agi! I can't say enough about what a great hostess, cook, guide and teacher she is. Our day began at the Central Market where we learned about different Hungarian foods (and sampled many), customs, holidays, lifestyle, etc. Then we shopped for the meals we would be making and then took a cab to Agi's home. There, after some homemade Palinka (a plum brandy made by her father) and appetizers, we began to prepare our meal. What a blast! It was also impressive to see how efficient Agi is in her kitchen. Everything was made from scratch and everything was delicious! My husband and I are not cooks and we are not really "foodies" either. I thought this would be fun and different based on the great reviews I read and Agi certainly did not dissappoint! I highly recommend this experience during your visit to Budapest!

Amazing Experience And Highly Recommended. You really do not have to be a foodie to do this tour. Warning!!! Do not eat a big breakfast as you will need all the room you can save in your stomach! Agi is an amazing guide and cook. You will see and feel how Hungarians live and eat. Agi takes you to the local market to shop and taste some of the local foods and delicacies. You will then go to her home where you might or might not meet her family. She will then have you prepare "hands on" what you have chosen from her menu and then you will sit down and eat the food you have prepared with some delicious wine and complete the meal with some Palinka. You will then need a crane to lift you and take you to your hotel!!!

Very enjoyable/educational time. My wife and I can't say how much we enjoyed the class. It takes place in her home and we had the opportunity to meet her family. We learned so much about the cooking skills but also about life in Hungary. Agi speaks excellent English and has a great ability to instruct. She shared her knowledge of food and about traditions of the area. I recommend travelers to take an enjoyable break from the sight seeing and learn about the food and the people. Looking forward to using our cooking knowledge when we return home.

Fit to burst. Wow, we have just spent the day with Agi and eaten so much we could burst. But we have that lovely warm glow when the food you've had is just so tasty and enjoyable,,,,This was simply a great way to spend the day - learning about food culture is great insight into a country. We adored all the food that we sampled at the market - especially the cottage cheese and chocolate treats.Agi is a lovely warm and generous person - she is also a patient teacher, so it doesn't matter if you are a foodie, or an inexperienced cook. You will leave with a full tummy and that sense of achievement of having made delicious food for yourself.We made bean soup, followed by stuffed cabbage and for dessert enjoyed making cottage cheese dumplings.It was all pretty easy to make, and Agi broke it down into easy stages. With a shot or two of homemade Palinka (plum brandy), the day passed quickly and we both had a great time.

"We will do it again in a Heartbeat". Fabulous, wonderful family, wonderful food, wonderful fun! The market tour with Agi is worth the price alone. She taught us so much. We learned and sampled the best of Hungary. Wow! The best quote of our family after the day: " I feel like I understand the country of Hungary more than I would have ever hoped and meeting this family and cooking will be hard to top. " All six of us agree, If---when---we go back...we will do it again in a Heartbeat. "

What everyone should do when they travel!. My son and I took Agi's cooking class yesterday, and had an absolutely wonderful time! We are both "foodies," so the idea of learning something about the local cuisine by making it appealed. I had done the same thing with my wife in Istanbul several years ago, and in Italy with my whole family a decade back. Every time, it's been a joy, and this was no exception. Agi's a great teacher, but let's you do the real cooking, which takes place in her own apartment on the Buda side of the river. We spent four hours creating bean soup with smoked ham, crepes stuffed with minced chicken and poppy seed bread pudding (but she has a broad menu you can pick three from, so you even get to choose what interests you most!). We chopped and stirred and sipped wine, and learned about the community and history and a nation in transition from a native. There's always more buildings to look at, but if you want to visit a country, it's more than buildings, and I can't recommend anything more than this experience. Wonderful!

A Real Hungarian Experience. If you want an authentic "Hungarian" experience, this is for you. Anybody can tour a museum or a church, but buying food with a personal guide at a giant open market and then taking it back to her apartment and using those ingredients to create an authentic Hungarian meal is a truly unique experience. Agnes was a good instructor - she explained what we were to do, showed us how to do it (e.g. cut the carrots this size) and then let us go at it. It was not only fun, but informative. We learned three new Hungarian dishes and how to make them. Amazingly, Agnes did not use any written recipes - she had it all in her head - skillfully timing the preparation as we moved from making the soup, to cooking the chicken, then preparing and baking the sponge cake, then back to preparing the palacintas and assembling the dessert cake. What satisfaction to sit down to a delicious 3 course meal you have just created! We also met her family: her husband, her little boy and her mom. It was one of our best experiences in Hungary - and there were many, considering the short time we spent there. Thanks, Agnes!
Most fun in Budapest. Agi is a wonderful host and terrific cook. We made delicious food and Agi shared so much about life in Hungary. This was a highlight of our visit to Budapest and a Must Do!!

A "MUST DO" in Budapest. This was one of the best experiences we had on our trip. Agnes communicated everything so thoroughly... from the possible menus to directions to her home to cooking the food itself. She greeted us from her balcony and ushered us into her home. Agnes & her husband Stephan welcomed us with coffee, water and some delicious appetizers. We chatted for a bit, introduced ourselves, and got to work. Everything was wonderful. Not only did we get some amazing authentic food, we also go to learn firsthand about the Hungarian culture. Being in a Hungarian home really added to the experience. Agi and her husband were such gracious hosts that we really felt at home. We even got to meet their darling son! We have done a competitor's class in another city, and altho it was good, Agi's class was so much more personal and rewarding. She sent us the recipes (she even got her father's recipe for sauerkraut for us!) and we will soon try them at home. If you enjoy cooking, or just eating, this is not to be missed. Thank you Agnes, Stephan & Zoltan for an absolutely wonderful experience!

"Wonderful experience!". This is a wonderful introduction to Hungarian foods, cooking, and lifestyle. The market tour was educational, as well as tasty! The cooking lesson was hands-on without being too technical or overwhelming.By the end of the day, I believe you’ll feel as I do that you’ve become part of a wonderful family, shared a delicious meal, and have made new friends in Hungary.

Awesome cooking class!. As a "foodie" myself planning my visit to Budapest, I wanted to highlight my experience with a cooking class where I could learn not only about Hungarian culture, some history of their food, but traditional foods and cooking techniques. Agnes was so very kind arranging the class; I knew when we met at the Central Market I was in for a fun learning experience! Touring the Central Market was educational and Agnes answered all our questions. We tasted traditional Hungarian foods, got to see their produce, meats, cheeses with all kinds of explanations to know how foods are prepared, consumed, etc. She was kind and allowed my friends to join with us, answering all of our many, many questions!The highlight, of course, was joining Agnes, her husband and son in their home. Agnes was so organized for our class. Starting the class with appetizers and Palinka, of course, we enjoyed Hungarian wine while we prepared our Ragout soup, Chicken Paprikash, traditional Nokedli noodles, which was sooo fun to prepare, a cucumber salad, and apple pie. Agnes also knew my friend, who loves poppy seeds, wanted to taste her poppy seed dessert. Agnes made sure she had ingredients so we could prepare this recipe, also, and bring home a sample for my friend! We took leftovers home for our friend to sample! Agnes left us with a gift of the Nokedli tool so we can prepare the noodles just like she taught us! I can't say enough about this opportunity and experience. I teach cooking classes, myself, at home, and this was amazing to be on the other side of the class. I learned so much, and mostly, was grateful to Agnes and her famiy for opening their home to us! Thank you so much!

Amazing Insight Into Hungarian Culture. We decided to book this class from the reviews here but being the first time we have done any sort of similar class we did not know what to expect. What we got was great food, fun preparing it and a fantastic insight into Hungary. The market tour is a great way to start it off. Agi took us for a snack and talked us through the different street foods and showed us some of the traditional crafts as well. The we headed down to the food, talking us through the ingredients as preparing a few samples too. Then you go back to her lovely apartment on the Buda side (which I think we would miss altogether otherwise). We chose potato and sausage soup, stuffed cabbage and the poppy seed bread pudding. All of them were excellent as well as the wine and palinka to drink. It was great to talk over food as well learning more about the traditions of the region. A fantastic day which I couldn't recommend more highly.

A must-do while in Budapest!. I booked a cooking class with Agnes while I was in Budapest the first week of March, and it was without a doubt one of the highlights of my trip. She is incredibly warm and inviting, and extends her knowledge of Hungarian cuisine, tradition and culture in a way that makes you feel like a friend, rather than a stranger. When I arrived she had delicious apps with sausage and paprika, a palinka shot (of course) and wonderful local wine! Our menu for the morning was bean soup, followed by chicken paprika, and finally poppy seed bread pudding. Throughout the course of four hours, Agnes explained each and every step used to make the dishes and in the end we ate an amazing spread of traditional Hungarian cuisine. My time spent in her company at her home was definitely too short and I'm looking forward to returning one day to not only see my new friend, but to cook more dishes! Deanna, France/Canada, March 2013

Great cooking experience wrapped in a fantastic cultural experience. Agnes made this experience wonderful. We did the market tour and cooking class, which I'd recommend. She taught us a lot about the food and culture of Budapest while being willing to answer all of our questions. It was great to get such candid exposure to what we were experiencing. The cooking class in her home was also a great experience. We made soup, stuffed cabbage, and a divine apple cake. I've taken cooking classes in China and Turkey, but this was my favorite because Agnes did a great job of letting us in to what life is like for her. I appreciated her honesty and authenticity. You will not only learn how to make some amazing food, you will also have a great time visiting with Agnes and her family. I would recommend doing this earlier in your trip so you can get some great tips on food and culture. Oh, and if you want to buy paprika, she has a great connection so get it from her.

Authentic experience of local food and culture. We visited just before Christmas when it was freeezing in Budapest! Aggi, her husband and their newest addition to their family greeted us warmly at the door. We were introduced to palinka and delicious canapes (hmmmm I'm salivating at the thought right now!) and felt at home instantly. Got straight to cooking and learnt new onion chopping skills, as well as how useful a pressure cooker can be! We had an amazing time and the food was incredible - we felt so proud to think that food that delicious was simple and easy to make! This is no group class, it is a personal, private session where you basically have a decadent 3 course meal with a local in their home. Aggi was incredibly generous, introducing wines and local spirits, cakes and canapes, so that by the time lunch rolled around we'd already been nibbling and drinking the past few hours! She was incredibly generous sharing stories of what it's like to live her country. Three hours flew by incredibly quickly and my partner and I felt it made a huge difference to our trip to Budapest - we would easily rank it on par with our visit to the Szechenyi spa in terms of "must do" in the city!

Personalized culinary adventure!. Began with an informative walk through Market Hall. Agi is a talented local foodie/cook. We wandered through the entire market sampling local foods and learning about the food and culture. Do bring your appetite as you will eat all day. After we picked up our groceries we took a cab to her apartment. Also learned the local rules on cabbing...wish we knew that our first day. Agi shared so many wonderful tips about the local area and culture. We then had some palinka, snacks, opened some wine and started cooking. The groups are always private so it was just my husband and I and she had him cooking...and I have pictures. You pick your menu. I have done several cooking classes and love to learn other dishes etc. This class was very special and while the menu was somewhat simple I learned many new tricks. I would highly recommend this if you want an authentic experience led by a warm, kind, talented cook.

Fabulous ! Yummy !. Over the Christmas holiday, we traveled to Vienna, Salzburg, Budapest and Prague. Cooking with Agnes (Agi) was hands down one of our favorite experiences. We met Agi at the Central Market and shopped for our ingredients, then took at cab to Agi's cute apartment (appetizers were waiting for us !), cooked and enjoyed a gourmet meal accompanied by wine. While the food was amazing, getting to know Agi was a real highlight. She is so much fun to be with and we felt like we were cooking with a friend. Agi lives in a residential area which is not packed with tourists and you get a better sense of the local lifestyle.My husband and I did the cooking class together. He does not cook at home but enjoyed learning about Hungarian cuisine. The Central Market was fun for him (it's vibrant, full of activity and unusual sights) and Agi kept him busy and engaged while we prepared our lunch. So - - don't be afraid to take your non-cooking spouse with you !While the website does a good job of explaining the experience - - the actual experience exceeds expectations in every way. The food is yummy. Agi is fun and her english is easy to understand. The hands on prepartion keeps everyone engaged. Wine with lunch made the meal seem like a party ! Our lunch conversation gave us a sense of what living in Budapest is like. When we returned home, Agi sent the recipes by e-mail and we're ready to try our luck back home !The hardest part for us was deciding in advance which recipes to prepare. We ended up preparing goulash soup, chicken paprikash with nokedli dumplings and somloi galuska for desert. These were perfect choices - - however - - after tasting stuffed cabbage at several Christmas Market stalls we wish we had tired preparing stuffed cabbage as well - - no problem - - Agi sent us the recipe !If we return to Budapest we'll cook with Agi again. Thank you Agi for a special day !!

Lovely stay with Agnes and family. We arrived in Budapest in the middle of a heat wave in July. Despite the heat, Agnes made our time together very enjoyable. She taught us the differences in paprika (never knew bell peppers were California paprika!) and shared information about her life in Budapest. It is one of our special memories in Budapest.

Another wonderful experience!. On our recent return trip to Budapest we made sure to save time for another day with Agi and Istvan. Since we have been to the Central Market numerous times we decided to meet Agi at her neighborhood market. Since there tourists were not around we got a better feel for the local lifestyle. As in the past Agi and Istvan opened up there home to us and took the time to not only prepare another wonderful meal, but gain more of an insight to Hungarian life and also Hungarian history. This is a must-do for everyone. Thanks again Agi and Istvan!

Great introduction to Budapest. The description of the agenda on the website is accurate, however, the reality is it will exceed all expectations and is a fabulous introduction to both Hungarian culture as well as the cuisine and history of paprika. We thoroughly enjoyed touring the Market Hall and purchasing the items for our cooking class. Agnes also took us to her local market and because her paprika vendor was not there that day, they delivered the paprika we wanted to purchase directly to our hotel. They really went out of their way to ensure that we had an amazing experience. I really love that they give you an option to pick the menu and we will definitely try to re-create these dishes at home. Istvan is very knowledgeable about Hungarian wines and made a wonderful selection for us to enjoy as well. This experience was definitely a highlight of our time in Budapest.

OK, another excellent!. My wife and I had a wonderful day with Agnes, shopping at the main market in Budapest, cooking at her home and learning about life in Budapest and Hungary. We are from San Francisco and this was a treat, it was one of the reasons we like to travel.

Different and delightful way to spend an afternoon in Budapest.. Agnes and her husband Steven open up their apartment home for a fantastic cooking session. We learned true Hungaruan home cooking. Made goulash soup, stuffed cabbage and poppy seed bread pudding. So delicious. And easy. You don't have to know anything about cooking. What fun. Great conversation. Wonderful break from visiting churches and castles.

Afternoon with New Friends. This was definitely the best part of our already wonderful trip to Budapest. My husband and I enjoyed every moment of the experience; Agnes and her lovely husband (and darling little Zoltan, too of course) are warm and friendly, the atmosphere is calm and relaxed...we felt at home immediately.We enjoyed preparing food from the very beginning, chopping and slicing and preparing all the portions that go into each dish. My husband and I both enjoyed the wine tasting and the couple's obvious enthusiasm for delicious food.Friendly, excellent service from the first email--they were kind and helpful when we got our currencies mixed up. Such a wonderful experience; definitely recommend.

Best Way to Spend the Day Ever. This was so much nicer than going to a big impersonal cooking school! I learned so much more than how to make scrumptious Hungarian food. It was a true cultural experience to get acquainted with charming Agnes and to meet her adorable family. It was such a warm and homey experience; I felt like I had known them for years. We created an extremely good lunch and she even gave me leftovers for my husband. I can't say enough good things about this!

Don't miss this wonderful experience!. I am of Hungarian ancestry and grew up cooking Hungarian cuisine so was a little hesitant about trying this in our limited time in Budapest. After all, wouldn't our time be better spent sightseeing? Wrong! From the moment we met Agnes at the market, we knew we had found the highlight of our visit to Budapest. As tourists, my husband and I would have visited the market and probably just quickly walked through. With Agnes, we gained a true appreciation of the marvelous foods and crafts the market has to offer and had an opportunity to sample many Hungarian delights. The cooking class was even more enjoyable. Agnes and her delightful family have a true talent for making you feel instantly welcome and at home. She is an incredible cook and very, very knowledgeable - I could not believe how much she taught us and the food we prepared was amazing! By the time we left we felt as if we were saying goodbye to friends and I could not wait to teach my children what Agnes taught me! This is truly something that you do not want to miss. Thank you, Agnes!

Agnes makes you feel at home! Great food, great host, great time!. This was definitely a highlight of our trip, a unique activity that gave us a real experience as a 'local' in Budapest. Agnes met us promptly out front of the market, carrying two shopping baskets, ready to go. She took us on a tour, pointing out various Hungarian favourite ingredients, crafts and specialties, and also helped me practice my Hungarian phrases (köszönöm szépen Aggie!). Upon arrival at her apartment, myself and my three travel companions (a Kiwi, an Aussie and French-Canadian) were treated to some schnapps and wine to get the cooking party started. Agnes was knowledgable, helpful and guided us through the prep of chicken paprika, ragout, and a delicious dessert. We had a fun filled afternoon with lots of laughs and a tasty meal with our warm and welcoming hosts.Truly a great additional to your plans while in lovely Budapest, highly recommended!!!

A fantastic experience, one of the highlights of my trip. As the title of the review says, I had a great experience learning authentic Hungarian dishes with Agnes. From the first contact (via e-mail) to the time we said Goodby, it was a great experience. Agnes was very prompt in answering e-mails and answering questions, she was also very flexible with regard to my food allergies. She also talked quite a bit about Hungarian food, which I found very interesting, as well as Hungarian culture. As we were cooking (I LOVE a hands-on cooking class), she taught me a few new things, though I consider myself an experienced cook. The food we made was delicious, the tools and ingredients simple and easy to find back home (though I did stock up on paprika). It was a true pleasure to learn from Agnes and spend time with her and her family (really nice, lovely people - I mentioned that I lost a converter and they immediately offered theirs, and the next day, Agnes offered to purchase one for me and meet up with me - that's truly above and beyond.)I would highly recommend a cooking class with Agnes, you won't be disappointed.

What a great time!. My sister-in-law and I love to cook and had an excellent day with Agnes , Estaven and of course Zoltan. The market tour was fascinating and the cooking class very interesting. We were inspired by our efforts to make a Hungarian dinner last weekend for the Canadain Thanksgiving Weekend and it turned out wonderfully. Agnes is knowledgeable and a very good instructor. I would not hesitate to reccomend the experience to anyone who has an interest in Hungarian food and culture.

Don't miss this one in Budapest. Agnes offers tourists a fantastic and unique foodie experience in Budapest. She is a charming young lady and very well versed in her Hungarian culianry heritage. My wife and I took the three hour class, culminating in a sumptious lunch which we cooked together. It was like having a private cooking tutor. Aside from the truly excellent cuisine, we enjoyed conversation in a private Hungarian home and discovered that our world is a lot smaller than many people can imagine. After enjoying lunch, wine, and a bit of homemade plum brandy (at 9:00 A.M.!), Agnus took us to her local farmers' market where I bought the most delicious paprika you can imagine, not something you pick up at the local super market chain here in the USA.. If you like to cook and want to hang with the locals, you can't do better than a session with Agnes!

Worth every penny. My husband and I LOOOOVED this experience. Everything everyone says about it is true. It seemed a bit pricy to us at first, but for the amount of food, the company, the education, and the experience you get out of it, it's actually a bargain.If you are tired of the usual sightseeing and souvenir shopping, this is the perfect antidote for you. Something different and a fantastic window into real Hungarian life.

Tasty Delight. Hands down the best experience I had on my trip to Budapest. I decided to do the market tour which is completely worth it and half of the experience. I met Agnes at the market where she toured me around, trying different Hungarian pastries, and food. She went out of her way to stop at her local market to buy the best paprika so I could take it home. We cooked for about 4.5 hours where we shared cooking, drinking wine, and sharing stories. The food was beyond delicious and a wonderful experience. I was in her course solo which was amazing to have the one-on-one experience. I 100% recommend this class. Yes it is pricey but you will remember this forever.

Lunch with friends..... When I met my cousin in Budapest for a long weekend, she had already planned on taking this cooking class and so I tagged along. I had not done any preparation or advanced reading on what the menu was or even what to expect; I trusted her judgment. We met Agnes at the market and began to get aquainted with a leasurely stroll around the market, stopping from time to time to sample various food stuffs of interest. Agnes was pleasant and welcoming of our questions about herself, her family, and Hungarian customs and cultures.I enjoyed the simplistic nature of the cooking portion of our day. It was casual, yet attainable. The atmosphere is in their home, so being able to use utensils, pots, and pans that are more commonly familiar allowed us to feel more comfortable in the actual creation of our Hungarian menu. The fact that this experience does not happen in a professional kitchen or resaurant leaves you feeling more confident that these dishes can be made by even the most incompetent of cooks. You leave feeling like you can actually make these dishes in your own home.By the end of the day, the experience left me feeling that I was not a client, but had just finished having lunch with friends. I actually had to remind myself to not help with the dishes! ;)As a tourist, it is difficult to have this kind of experience at any price. Thank you Agi, Pisti and Zoltan for sharing your home, your hospitality, and your food with us.

Wonderful "Behind the Scenes" Budapest Experience. The four hours we spent with Agnes offered, in addition to the "hands-on cooking" lesson, a rare peek into the daily lives of a young Hungarian family. Meeting Agnes and her husband and 7-month old son was such a treat! My husband and I are NOT gourmet cooks and appreciated the instructions on how to chop, slice and peel vegetables and meats as we prepared our goulash soup and chicken paprika. By the end of our class, we had not only prepared and consumed a delicious, authentic Hungarian meal, but we felt that we had experienced one of the few "non-touristy" activities in our two-week vacation. This class felt like a visit to a friend's home with lots of casual conversation (Agnes speaks impeccable English) over a special meal preparation. I highly recommend it!

A good introduction to cooking Hungarian Food. I came with my brother to rediscover Hungarian food such as we'd eaten in our childhood (we are half hungarian). Having lived in the Uk for all our lives, we'd rather forgotten the tastes of the food. Part of our trip was ro find out what various essential elements go into Hungarian cooking and how to put them together. Agnes was waiting for us at the Market, and took us around explaining all the ingredients and asking some of the stall holder all the ridiculously detailed questions I was posing. Finally, our food purchased, and the differences between parsnip and parsley root having been well discussed, we took a taxi back to her house - very near the wonderful Auguszt Cukrázda.After some nibbles and a glass of delicious Palinka, we settled down to cook. After an hour and a half, our wives joined us for a meal when we ate with pleasure. The girls - Agnes was joined by Maggie - helped us in some of the basic preparation, like the boring jobs of peeling the onions or washing up, were great fun to be with, knowledgable and friendly. After lunch, we left, well content with having re-planted our roots in hungarian food.

One of the highlights of our trip!. We really enjoyed learning about the Hungarian cuisine and cooking with Agnes who is very professional and friendly.on our arrival we were offered beautiful hors d'ouvres (sliced bread with salami and also with goose lard, scallions and sprinkled with paprika), then we tasted a homemade palinka (a local aperitif, very strong!) and Agnes showed us a book and explained to us a bit about the Hungarian food ethos.The class was very hands-on, we decided to learn goulash soup, chicken paprikash and apple cake. It was very nice to cook in her well-equipped kitchen. Loved the grater she used to make the fresh dumplings and she was very nice to give me one of which I already used back home!We truly enjoyed eating each dish prepared by us on a beautifully set table with Hungarian china. Agnes was very kind in sharing some tips of local restaurants and she sent us an e-mail with the recipes a few days after our class. This was def the best dining experience we had in Budapest!

Great food, great people!!!!. I had such a great time at this cooking class. Firstly when i met Agnes outside the market hall, she was easy to find and perfectly on time. She then showed me around the markets explaining different foods/meats. She also gave me things to try along the way, salami, chocolate and strudel (the chocolate bar was amazing, i actually stocked up before i left the Hungary as they were so yummy, i wish they were in Australia!!) Then we went back to her place. Istvan was there waiting with some yummy appetisers and palinka (yum!) for us. I am not a very experienced cook, so Agnes was happy to help and show me how to cut onions and peel the potatos etc. I did this class on my own, and i was a bit nervous before i got there but both Agnes and Istvan made me feel more then welcome, just like we were old friends. I had a wonderful time and the food we cooked was amazing. I have cooked the chicken paprikash a few times since and it tastes fantastic, the real test is in a few weeks when i cook for my hungarian grandma.... im sure it will be up to her standards. The left over food Agnes packed for me to take back to the hotel for my parents, it was so kind of her and they loved it. Also before i got to Budapest, Agnes kept in contact with me and also sent me some handy tips for being in Budapest. I am so thankful for this day spent with Istvan and Agnes. I would highly recommend this experience and when i go back to Budapest i will definatly be going back to learn to cook another meal.

What a Wonderful Morning!. This was one of the best things we did in Budapest. My mum & I contacted Agnes and were impressed with her prompt reply and her answers to all our questions. We chose the bean soup, chicken paprika and Somlói galuska. Absolutely no regrets there, everything was amazing.We caught the metro out to Agnes's place. It was a simple trip from the city centre, only took about 10 minutes. The trains were efficient, clean, and came regularly. It was easy to find our way from the train station - the McDonalds was a good landmark to reassure us that we were walking in the right direction.Agnes greeted us, and we immediately felt at home. We had lots of fun preparing the dishes. There was lots to do, and we both learnt new skills. I felt like no time was wasted - Agnes planned the class very well so we always had something to do, while another part of the meal was in the oven, for example. I had a lot of fun making the noodle dumplings, and Mum was impressed with the secrets of making the sponges for the Somlói galuska.We finished the class with a relaxed lunch, eating all our wonderful food. Each of the three courses was delicious. We shared a bottle of wine, and between main course and dessert Agnes showed us a Hungarian cookery book, and chatted with us about Hungarian culture.I would absolutely recommend this class to visitors to Budapest. We were so glad we did it, and it added another dimension to our European trip - something a little different to the usual bus tours and castle visits.

A Cooking Experience to Remember!. My trip to Budapest was a spur of the moment thing, so I contacted Agnes on short notice. Thankfully, she was able to accommodate me and the day started at Budapest's main market (not to be missed either). We toured the market, sampling a few delicious items as we wandered. My mouth waters every time I think of the savory strudel I sampled.Agnes helped me to find some good paprika that is now in my kitchen waiting to find its way into my next cooking adventure. The cooking class was, without a doubt, one of the best I have ever taken (and I've taken a few). Agnes is a wonderful cook, very personable, and a patient instructor. Now, I can't wait to try the tarragon soup and chicken paprika in my own kitchen. Thank you Agnes, for a day that I'll always remember fondly.

Hungarian Heritage. My 2 cousins and I took the market tour and cooking class with Agnus on July 5, 2012. Our mothers are Hungarian and we were excited to experience the culinary arts of our heritage. From the minute we met Agnus outside the Grand market, we knew we were in for a wonderful time. Agnus took her time with us in the market explaining and showing all the different booths and vendors it had to offer. After all of our purchases were made, including a beautiful embroidered blouse for me, a cab ride to her apartment was next.We entered a warm and gracious home setting and easily felt as if we had know each other for a long time as we sat down for some appetizers and palinka. We met her husband and young son and her cooking partner Maggie. Our aprons were put on and the cooking began. I can't go on enough about how wonderful this experience was for us. Not only did we learn many new techniques for food preparation but learned about life in Hungary. We shared our lives and family background as well and found many common threads. The food was awesome as well.This was the highlight of our trip to Budapest and we highly recommend it to everyone.

A great way to spend time with my brother!. It's difficult to write anything more eloquent than the review my brother wrote, but here goes. This was the portion of the trip I was most looking forward to. Being Hungarian, I was anxious to learn more about the cuisine - more than we had learned while dining in local restaurants. Being that my brother and I really like to cook, I thought it was a great way to spend time with my brother. Walking into Agnes and Istvan's home felt like walking into a home we had visited forever. They not only treated us like guests in their home, but also like family by offering breakfast "appetizers," wine and brandy while making our meal. They shared a bit of the history of their own families, the history of how they decided to start teaching cooking classes and finally, the history of Hungary. In fact, the book they referred to was a book that my brother had debated buying - I'm sure he will after this trip.The level of cooking was spot on. While I am comfortable in the kitchen, there were plenty of new things I learned during the class, especially patience! Everything we cooked during our time together was amazing. In fact, as I'm writing this, I'm cooking the Chicken Paprikash and dumplings we made that amazing day together.I highly recommend this to anyone who loves food and Hungary!

Fun day with Agi and Maggie!. How awesome to make new friends in Budapest while cooking a meal in Agnes' home. Everything was spectacular as we were greeted with Hungarian appetizers and palinka. We soon donned aprons and were busy preparing an authentic Hungarian meal. I would highly recommend this experience because it provides a true picture of life in Budapest. You cannot go wrong with Agnes!

Delightful and Delicious. What a fun experience on July 4. My daughter, son-in-law, grandson, and I signed up to take a Hungarian cooking class with Agnes Barath in her home. She and her family were so gracious that it seemed as though we had known each other for a long time. Cooking the food was a delight and eating it was even better. Now I know how to cook the rich gulyasleves, stuffedcabbage and I even flipped my own palacsinta. I can't wait to experiment with my own fillings.Tomorrow, I'm going to a kitchen store to buy a nonstick palacsinta (crepe) pan and then watch out. It will be palacsinta time for my friends. Now that I'm back in Dallas, I'm so glad for thatexperience with Agnes. If you are interested in people, cooking, and culture, then by all means sign up to to take this class with Agnes and enjoy.

could anyone teach me how to cook tradisional food in Hungary. hai , my name is Puteri Elsuraya Mohamed. i am from Malaysia. right now am stay in Budapest for a year already.. i would like to learn some of Hungary Foods. example Laougues, Goulash , Kurtoskalacs and Strudel Apple.i am really hope if someone can help and teach me how to cook some of the food. am really thankfull to youmy free day is saturday and sunday only. you can cantact me by email...melsurayamohamed@yahoo.com or my FaceBook Puteri elsurayamohamed. thanks you very much and i am really hope i can joint any class.or maybe i can teach MALAYSIAN FOOD to you also..if you like am happy also.here i am add few photos of Malaysian Food..

A great way to end our trip.. My sister and I scheduled our cooking class for the last day of our stay in Budapest. This being my third trip to Budapest I wanted to be able to cook some of the great food I enjoy when I am there. When we arrived on Sunday we were pleasantly greeted by Agnes and Istvan. We were offered wine and plum brandy along with appetizers. It instantly felt like we were visiting friends and not just learning to cook. I found the pace to be right-on for my level of cooking. Agnes and Istvan took the time to explain the proper way to prepare the items and stepped in briefly if we weren’t quite doing it correctly. None of the ingredients had been prepped ahead of time. I enjoyed this since the would not be when I recreated the meal at home. All the while they explained the history and culture of the Hungarian people, including their own families and also the small talk happened very naturally.A few hours into it our partners showed up and the atmosphere remained very relaxing and enjoyable. The food turned out just as I had hoped.I would definitely advise anyone that would like to experience true Hungarian cooking to take the class. It made my last day in Budapest very memorable.

Great experience. We were difficult customers since we do not eat pork but Aggie and Istevan were up to the challenge.We just did the cooking, no shopping, and ended up spending about 5 hours with them.cooking and eating were great fun as was chance to talk to some young Hungarians.Istevan took us to local shop t help us buy some items we saw there.

Warm, friendly and personal culinary experience. I, along with a friend, signed up for this cooking class on a Sunday afternoon.We were greeted by our warm and smiling ‘hosts’, Agnes and Istvan, into their home (not a commercial cooking facility). This itself gave the experience a real and personal feel. They had laid out a few canapés for us and very kindly offered us a taste of some home brewed palinka. After a brief chat over some local white wine, we were ready to get our hands dirty. I am vegetarian and the menu was planned and agreed accordingly. Both Agnes and Istvan provided clear instructions on what to do and liberally educated us on the culinary traditions in Hungary. While cooking, we weren’t spoon fed but weren’t left on our own as well. The quality of our cooking was very much like ‘home food’, rather than some fancy concoction of a Michelin restaurant, which is what we expected and desired. And as a parting gesture, the thoughtful couple gave us small gifts to make sure we practiced at home what we had learnt there!!! The whole experience was very personal and relaxing. Almost akin to cooking a Sunday brunch with friends over wine and chatter! I have done cooking classes elsewhere, but nothing as warm and personal as this. I would wholly recommend this class to anyone interested in taking a breather from the usual touristy things in Budapest and gaining some insight into the real Hungarian life.

Worth every penny.... My husband and I have just returned from a 2 week vacation through parts of Europe. One of the highlights of our trip was the cooking class with Agnes and Istvan in their home in Budapest. The market tour was fabulous which Agnes brought to life for us with explanations of the history and culture of the market. The preparation of the foods was loads of fun and I was surprised to learn new cooking techniques from Agnes. Istvan shared the history and geography of the Hungarian wines he introduced us to which were excellent. The food, wine and company was excellent but it was more than that. Thank you Agnes and Istvan for opening your home to us and for sharing your stories of what it has been like living in Hungary for you, your parents and your grandparents. You can't put a price on a day like we shared with you. Thank you.

Great Day With Agnes. Agnes meet us at the world market with a basket for each of us. After a leisurely tour of all 3 floors, we shopped for the ingredients of the meal we were to prepare. Agnes was very informative and answered all our questions thoroughly and introduced us to local tastings. After a short trip via cab, we arrived at their apartment which was warm and inviting. With a little snack and local drink waiting for us upon our arrival, we put on our aprons and enjoyed mxing, chopping, rolling & cooking our Hungarian dishes. It was lovely sitting down at the family dining table and having a wonderful meal and delightful conversation. Thank you Agnes for sharing your home and culture with two U.S. Southern ladies.

Fabulous market tour and cooking class. Agnes and Steven met us at the market and we spent 60 min there sampling foods, purchasing food for our class and having them explain what all the items are. we then drove to their apt where we had appetizers and then could eat the yogurts we bought. we then made goulash soup, chicken paprika w/ dumplings and, for dessert, samloi galuska - a sponge cake, chocolate devine creation! We had the best wine on our trip - a yummy red from Hungary. We were absolutely stuffed when we left! This really was the highlight of our 2 week trip in Budapest, Vienna and Prague!

Delicious Dining. Although pricey, we thoroughly enjoyed our time cooking with Agnes and Istvan, a lovelycouple. Not only did we learn to cook Hungarian style but we tasted some of thewell known wines and enjoyed learning about our hosts and their life in Hungary. Aftercooking our meal we all sat down to eat together which was like being invited to dinner.Great way to learn more about the culture of Hungary.

Thoroughly enjoyed!. This class is a great introduction to Hungarian home cooking. Myfriend and I took this class, and we really enjoyed getting to knowAgnes and learning a bit about Hungarian food. It was nice to get outof the tourist center a little bit and understand a bit more about theculture in Budapest. Our favorite recipes were the Chicken Paprikash and theapple cake.

Great way to meet the locals. We spent 4 hours with Agnes and Istevan in early Dec. It was such fun to meet them and learn about their lifestyle and how to "cook like a local". We made cold fruit soup, stuffed cabbage, and apple pie. It was all so good, and it was fun to meet them and learn how they cook; everything was from scratch....no microwave! Highly recommended to anyone going to Budapest.

Something different to make you feel at home on a weekend away!. On a cold afternoon in December, this was a great way to spend an afternoon, eating well and learning more about the place we were visiting from two lovely locals! After choosing the dishes we wanted to cook, it was an original way to sample the local cuisine whilst learning about its history in probably the most authentic setting possible! The ingredients were fresh, many of them homegrown or made by family members, which added an extra special touch. If you're looking for something a bit different, then this is a must for any trip to Budapest. Agnes and Istvan were friendly and welcoming and were more than happy to give us the added bonus of pointing us in the direction of the best attractions for the rest of our stay! The class is relevant to all levels, whether you're a beginner who wants to learn from scratch, or a more experienced cook (my partner is a Chef) who wants the opportunity to learn something new from the locals themselves!

Learned to Cook like Grandma!. What a wonderful experience. Food was awesome, and the conversation was great.I learned to cook like my grandmother.Home was very nice, easy to find and felt like I knew them forever. I hope I do.Must do, if you are going to Budapest!

Great Meal. Great hosts. Great Experience.. Visited Budapest with my mother, sister and son and chose to try the Culinary Hungary Home Cooking Class. So glad we did! Had the great pleasure of meeting Agnes and Istvan who warmly made us all feel at home and brought us the memorable experience of cooking (and eating) some great Hungarian food. For those that want to revisit the foods that your grandmother prepared...this is a sure bet. Would like to come back with my wife and daughter next year.

Good food and good company in Budapest. This was the highlight of my trip to Budapest. We didn't do the market tour; just the cooking, but she let us select what we wanted to make. We made a wonderful cream soup with lemon, chicken, and vegetables, stuffed cabbage and a poppy seed bread pudding. When I told Agnes that we couldn't get the cabbage already marinated as she could, she called her mother for the recipe. I highly recommend this for anyone visiting Budapest who wants to try their hand at cooking delicious food and enjoying a delightful person in her home in Buda.

One of the best ways to learn about living and eating in Hungary. My wife and I took the Culinary Hungary Cooking class with Agnes and Istvan during our trip to Budapest. It was the most memorable part of our visit to Budapest. We selected stuffed cabbage, bean soup and cottage cheese dumplings for our class. All of the dishes were excellent, but the stuffed cabbage was our favorite. It was just wonderful. It is a hands on cooking class, but Agnes and Istvan gave us plenty of help and instruction. They also shared background information on the recipes and ingredients. We took the four-hour cooking only class. The time went by fast, but we were not rushed. It was very relaxing. Agnes and Istvan are a delightful young couple and we enjoyed the conversation as much as we enjoyed the food and cooking. We were greeted with a variety of Hungarian hors d'oeuvres and wine. We think the best part of traveling is connecting with local people and we immediately felt like old friends. They openly shared stories of their experiences growing up and living in Hungary. Agnes and Istvan warmly welcomed us into their home and gave us our best memories of Budapest. We will always think of them when we enjoy the recipes we learned how to make in their class.

Even in English now. If you are serious about learning something about Hungarian cooking (Susan Derecskey's book is a great first step) with some prior praparation you can find several that you will be glad you did.Hungarian cooking is not complicated, neither is French, but the results are worth the effort.Inquire prior to your travel, plan well and you will not be disappointed - in fact, I'd say you'll be well rewarded for your efforts.

Wonderful Authentic Experience. This is not a cooking school. This is not a highly orchestrated tourism machine. This is being welcomed into someone's home. A real family, in a real neighborhood, sharing a very special glimpse into real Hungarian life. Our family enjoyed this evening immensely, and we highly recommend it for anyone seeking to learn more about Hungarian food, but even more for people who seek to learn about Hungarian life. Our hosts could not have been more gracious, and the memories our family created that night are among some of our favorite.

Any visit to Buapest would be incomplete without a day cooking with Agnes. My wife and I just spent an amazing day cooking with Agnes and Istevan. The entire experience, from start to finish was absolutely memorable. Today was about food preparation, cooking technique, chatting and getting to know Hungarian warmth and hospitality from this delightful couple. We learned how to prepare new dishes while engaging in stimulating conversation. Our menu started with delicious finger sandwiches followed by pea soup, chicken paprika and apple cake. I cannot find enough good things to say about Agnes, Istevan and this terrific program. Thank you for a wonderful day!

The highlight of our trip!. I surprised my mom recently with a trip to Budapest for the first time. It was a special trip as Hungary is the country her father was born in. I searched online for ideas on what to do while we were there and came across Agnes and Istvan cooking class. The reviews were all so good I thought we should give it a try. As neither of us had been to Hungary before we really only knew the Hungarian culture through the food so I thought this could be a great experience. I am happy to say that we were not left at all disappointed! Agnes and Istvan are a lovely warm couple who clearly enjoy what they do. The experience of walking through the market with Agnes and going back to their flat to cook and eat was highlight of our trip. I would highly recommend this class on your next trip! I can't wait to try out the recipes here with my friends in London.

If you only have one day in Budapest - spend it on this!. I was able to write a lot on this as I liked it so much.. the short version is first with more details below that for those who are interested!I am by no means rich, and I did think a lot before booking the course as €99 is more than I would usually spend. Once I had the experience though I can only stress that actually this price is cheap for the value you get. I got a 90 minute solo guided tour, a taxi through a non-tourist part of town that I wouldn't normally see for about 15 minutes, then I was invited warmly into a Hungarian home, had lunch, offered various Hungarian wines, water and homemade palinka.. lots of different knowledge of Hungarian culture, food and cookery, including a highlight for me which was learning how to make pasta very easily from scratch (flour, water, egg, salt + about ten mins from start to finish!) plus the tool to make the Nokedli pasta at home... Really the whole experience was amazing value when you consider all that and I wholeheartedly recommend it. For me this experience gave me more knowledge on Budapest/Hungary than the rest of the 8 days I spent there put together so if there is one thing you should do whilst visiting this amazing city it is this! Long Version:I chose the €99 option which included a market tour and then learning how to cook the three course meal of my choice. I attended the class alone and I was a little nervous before meeting Agnes of what to expect - I need not have worried as Agnes was very careful to make sure I was enjoying myself and I really had a great time but also learned a lot too. The day began at 10am at the Grand Central Market, Agnes who is a Hungarian girl in her early thirties was easily recognisable waiting outside the market with two wicker baskets. After introductions she took me on a very interesting tour of the market, interspersing natural conversation with entertaining facts. She was a great guide and it taught me so much more than going around the market myself with a guide book would have done. An hour or so later (time flew so it might have been longer) we took a taxi across the Danube into the hills of Buda where Agnes lives. She has a lovely modern apartment and after settling into the clean apron and slippers provided we proceeded to make a lunch of the traditional welcome snack of goose fat on bread (surprisingly very delicious), followed by yogurt we had bought in the market (some of the best yogurt I have ever tasted as it was freshly made). Agnes also offered me a glass of Hungarian wine and showed me the different wine regions in Hungary on a map when she could see I was interested. This felt like just chatting with a friend but afterwards I realised she had taught me a lot about Hungarian wine! Now we had our energy back we moved on to the cooking, I saw someone had complained in their review below how they had to prepare everything with Agnes (no idea why that would trouble you as that is surely the point of a cookery class but nevermind!)... for me this was the beauty of it and something I found refreshing about Agnes' cooking. Everything we made from scratch, so I knew exactly what was in it. If I didn't like something I could leave it out. During the preparation Agnes made sure I was comfortable and offered me soft drink/wine which is my way of cooking so that was good too!After everything was prepared we had a well deserved sit down whilst we ate the dinner and chatted some more. Again Agnes opened my eyes to Hungarian life in these informal conversations in a way no guide book or tour normally would. The meal had turned out delicious and I felt a sense of achievement and like I had learned a lot about cookery, despite me being a fairly decent cook. As there was food left after our meal Agnes put the Somloi Galushka trifle type cake into a container for me to take back to the hotel and share with my husband later so that was very nice.Agnes also made sure I knew how to get back to my hotel and gave me a map with directions marked on it which worked great. Her apartment is very close to one of the big tram stops and this was my first experience of the tram system so it was good to have a reason to use what was a very efficient tram network. I should also mention that I left my sunglasses on the dinner table and Agnes was kind enough to run after me down the road to return them. After the course Agnes emailed me the written recipes with plenty of instruction and reminders on how to do things. I have since made the Paprika chicken which turned out great but I was most excited to make the pasta again to make sure it wasn't a fluke as it seemed so easy there.. but no it worked great with the tool Agnes gave me and my husband was very impressed ;)All in all this is a first rate experience that anyone with an interest in food/eating/Hungary would enjoy!

Hungry in Hungary? Not at this cooking class!. We went on the market tour and home cooking class today, and what a treat! After meeting Agnes at the Central Market, we had a nice time walking around, buying things for our cooking class. When we were finished, we caught a cab to her apartment.Once there, we enjoyed some appetizers and Palinka before starting the cooking! It was a lot of fun, cooking traditional Hungarian dishes - and for us, a wonderful introduction to cooking with Paprika.Time seemed to fly as we chopped, stirred, whipped and fried our way through our menu. Lots of fun! (Ishtan? was the perfect "sous" chef - helping out where needed and washing up all the dishes! Agnes is a lucky lady - to have a hubby who can cook and clean!!!) Meanwhile, the cooking and conversation flowed - and we really did feel like friends by the time we left.I'd highly recommend this class - as it really is home cooking - and cooking we look forward to doing when we get back home! We can't wait to show off our new Hungarian cooking skills to our family and friends!

Great Food... steeped in the culture. It was just my wife and myself... Agnes gave us the grand tour. Beginning with the Central Market Hall where we picked fresh everything (Fruit, meat, vegetables). Homemade Polinka, great food, better stories and a noodle maker. My wife's Grandfather immigrated to the US in 1900 and this was her first trip to Hungary. So many great discussions about traditions, superstitions and culture. So many special touches... including Agnes went off menu to make breakfast dish... eggs and noodles. I have been to Budapest 8 times and I am recommending Agnes to everyone I talk with.

overrated and too expensive. we thought we'd add a culinary touch to our perfect stay in beautiful budapest : it turned out being a cooking class for beginners and not for experienced cooks.No information was added to our well prepared knowledge of the city/country.Level was too basic and knowledge too touristic;The market tour is not necessary cause anyone can visit the market on his own.....and 31 euro per person is an offence to tourists. the 100 euro fare is exagerated considering an average monthly salary in Hungary is between 250 and 400 euros. The ingredients were of very average quality while we noticed the better quality in the market wasn't expensive at all.Wine at disposal was a last glass of an open bottle and a very average rosé. For 100 euro per person you don't chop and chip but find ingredients already prepared.The cooking experience of Agnes is very basic, a bit due to her age, and a bit due to lack of passion for cooking. Agnes though felt our disappointment and proposed to refund us. So we decided to pay 50euro per person and got the rest promptly back.Tell the truth we decided to participate reading the comments on tripadvisor........and beingso expensive we thought it was a high level : to discover it is definitively on a beginners level.Absolutely nothing negative to comment on Agnes : kind and willingly to please and assistand help us to buy the right hungarian sausage. Level and fare should be adapted to the real value, this just cannot be the most expensivething to do in such a lovely city !

Fantastic and delightful cooking class. This cooking class is a must if you want to learn about Hungarian cooking and culture. Agnes was a fantastic ,gracious hostess and very informative about the local culture. I enjoyed cooking and learing about the local ingredients as well as the history behind Hungarian cooking. We also went to the farmers market just around the corner which was a great expierence. Was a very enjoyable afternoon and one of the highlights of my trip to budapest. I highly reccomend this class especially if you are a foodie or into culinary expierences. LT

Fantastic Local Cooking and Wine Tasting Experience for 2 Couples. If you want to have a chance to cook typical Hungarian food and meet a wonderful Hungarian couple in their home, consider taking a class with Le Cordon Bleu trained Agnes Barath and Istvan Laposi. Our husbands were as eager to learn some new cooking skills as my friend and I were. Our biggest accomplishment was learning how to flip crepes just like a professional and to make 2 layers of sponge cake in one pan. Each of the 3 courses was paired with a local wine (which appealed to our husbands). There was a lot of talk, & laughing as we prepared our meal. Agnes and Istvan provided instructions and information about their culture and foods while we all participated in the preparation of the 3 dishes. This was the highlight of our trip to Budapest, an experience we will not easily forget.Christy and Linda

Really terrific way to enjoy Hungarian cooking. We just took a Hungarian cooking class today with Agnes, and it was a fantastic experience that I highly recommend to anyone who likes to cook and/or eat!Upon making your reservation, Agnes will offer you a choice of one starter, one entree and a dessert. Check out the selection on her website. Agnes lives in a cozy apartment on the Buda side of town, an easy walk from several tram lines and the Red Line subway station. She had some nice appetizers waiting for us when we arrived, and we sat down to chat for a little bit before we started cooking.What's great about the class is that you are active participants in all phases of the cooking - from prepping the ingredients to cooking the actual meal. Agnes herself has taken some culinary classes and learned how to make Hungarian food from her mother. Her husband, Istvan, is also an avid chef. He wasn't around for our class, though.We really enjoyed the time we spent with Agnes, because it was like learning from a friend. While we were waiting for the food to cook, we had a chance to chat and ask questions about Hungarian life and even got to know Agnes better. She's only been giving these classes since May, but she is so professional and prepared that it seems like she's been doing it for years.We learned a lot of techniques for preparing the food, including tips on when and how to add ingredients so they don't end up lumpy. The food proved to be quite delicious, and Agnes even offered us wine and bread to accompany the meal. She also gave us a shot of homemade palinka - warning, this stuff is potent!All in all, we had a very enjoyable experience, and we'd recommend this to anyone who'd like to learn a little about Hungarian cooking and culture, in a very intimate and hospitable environment.

Don't Miss This One!. Whether you just love to cook or not, Agnes's cooking sessions are fun and easy to follow -- and delicious! Her charming partner Istvan also understands the intricacies of Hungarian cooking and wine or palinka drinking. We all chopped and stirred and braised together under Agnes's expert guidance.A chat over dinner with this bright young couple will show you a side of Hungarian life that you won't find in the more usual tourist attractions. Next time we are in Budapest, we will definitely go back to make more authentic Hungarian dishes.

On a Scale of 1 to 10 ... this is an Eleven! Excellent!!!. We just returned home to Italy from a seven-day visit to Budapest and looking back on this experience, our cooking class with Agnes (“Agi”) was without doubt the highlight of our trip. Not to be missed! Don’t get me wrong, Budapest is a fabulously beautiful city with so many incredible sights to see … but our day with Agi provided a personal glimpse of life in Budapest that was so touching and heartfelt, it will remain in our memory for the rest of our lives.We first contacted Agi two weeks before our trip to Budapest, based on the excellent reviews here on tripadvisor.com. We initially had no intention of taking a cooking class in Budapest … but then, why not? She responded promptly to our emails, our date was scheduled, and our main concern … we are two vegetarians … was accommodated to everyone’s satisfaction providing us with several menu choices.We elected to take the Market Tour + Cooking Class, which offered the opportunity to tour the huge Budapest indoor market. Agi arrived at the market entrance right on time at 10 AM with two cloth-lined woven baskets to help tote away our provisions. Agi is a very beautiful, bright and energetic young woman (late 20’s/early 30’s), with a warm engaging smile and speaks fluent English. Wives need not worry: Agi is an exceptionally pretty “girl-next-door” type … and not a young “va-va-va-boom” Zsa Zsa Gabor. ☺ But thank goodness she's also not the matronly schoolteacher type. ☺ She has a natural and easy manner that makes you feel instantly comfortable and we became good friends quite quickly. Her fiancé Istavan was working during the day of our cooking class and so unfortunately we were not able to meet him. But we asked Agi to pass on our message to him that he is a very lucky man to have her in his life! We hope he reads this! ☺Our vegetarian menu was set as follows: Appetizer – Cold Fruit Soup, Main Course - Mushroom Paprikosh with Nokedli Dumplings, Dessert - Cheese Dumplings with Sour Cream. After showing us the upper floor of the market hall which is loaded with fine handicrafts, we wandered through the huge produce section on the main floor. What a feast for the eyes! Be sure to bring your camera! Agi knew exactly where to go for each type of produce and it was apparent from her discussions with the local merchants that she has a good rapport with everyone. And I respected her when she moved on from any vendor who wouldn’t let her choose the produce herself. Agi was very receptive to our questions and specific needs. I mentioned to her that in Italy it is impossible to find pickles and she took us to a shop with a wide choice so now my “pickle craving” is fully satisfied. Agi has studied culinary arts extensively and is very well informed. Her approach is to always prepare a meal from scratch … no processed foods here! … which is always healthier and tastier.Once all our provisions were purchased, Agi called a taxi and we were whisked away to her apartment on the Buda side of the Danube. Her kitchen is very functional with room for active participation. It is important to point out that Agi’s cooking classes are arranged FOR YOUR IMMEDIATE GROUP ONLY, be it just one, two … or six people. You are never mixed together with strangers in a larger class setting. This makes for a more personal class, tailored to your needs. It also gives you more opportunity for active participation in preparing the meal. We were soon chopping and dicing and whisking and sautéing … and enjoying every minute of it! For us, one of the highlights of the class was the preparation of the Nokedli Dumplings, which I highly recommend. Using a special grater with wide openings, the fresh pasta (made from flour, water and egg) is grated into boiling water using a special trowel. Tossed together with the fresh mushroom sauce (seasoned with onion, pepper, tomato and sweet paprika) it makes a very impressive meal. Living in Italy, where pasta is king, I must admit that the dumplings prepared in Agi’s class were fabulous! We can’t wait to prepare this dish for our friends in Florence! The other dishes prepared for our meal were also extremely tasty. Beginning with a cold fruit soup (perfect for a hot summer day!) and ending with cheese dumplings seasoned with lemon and topped with sour cream (yummy!). Agi guided us toward what was (for us) a perfect meal.The table was set and then our chance to have lunch to sample our Hungarian creations from Agi’s kitchen. Everything exceeded our expectations. Throughout the meal there was a constant flow of stimulating conversation. Agi is such a kind and gracious host that we were soon discussing a wide range of topics as good friends. She was also available to answer our questions on specific aspects of life in Budapest, and even called her parents to ask suggestions for names of pre-WWII singers (one of my passions) so we could purchase a Hungarian CD.Our visit with Agi ended by 3 PM … much too soon. It was amazing how quickly the time flew by! True to her word, Agi later sent us the recipes for the meal we had cooked together, freeing us from taking notes during the meal preparation. Agi fully deserves all the praise she has received from other reviewers here on this site. On a scale of 1 to 10, this experience was an Eleven!l! Excellent!!! We heartedly recommend Agi’s Culinary Hungarian Home Cooking Class + Market Tour for visitors coming to Budapest!!! ☺

A Budapest Experience You Must Not Miss!. I found Agnes and the Culinary Hungary Home Cooking Class through TripAdvisor. The idea of learning to cook some of the most beloved foods of my family's heritage was really appealing to me. Even more interesting, though, was the opportunity to spend an evening in a Hungarian family home while learning.Agnes and Istvan did not disappoint! From the first timely e-mail responses to our evening together, our family was SO happy with the experience! The warm welcome and easy hospitality we received were delightful - they seemed to anticipate our every need and paced the evening so nicely. Watching our teen-age sons smile and laugh together as they chopped vegetables, made dumplings, and tossed crepes almost brought me to tears! And the food and drink were by far the best we enjoyed during our 4 days in Budapest.We arrived as guests and students, but left 4 hours later feeling like friends who had shared a slice of life and amazing plates of food together. Set aside an evening of your visit to Budapest to spend with Agnes and Istvan - we are SO glad we did!

Fantastic way to spend a day-a truly unique travel experience. What a fantastic way to spend a day! I found Agnes through trip advisor about 3 weeks before arriving in Budapest via river cruise and am so glad my girlfriend and I spent it with her. We traded e-mails back and forth a few times discussing timelines and availability, activity options, menu and finally meeting time/place. It was all so easy and not stressful at all (I can't say the same for her-she was booked entirely for the week when we eventually met up and must have been harried with my questions!). After meeting in the Great Market she showed us the shops and stands selling the various fare to tourists and locals alike. We picked up the items needed for our menu and were off to her kitchen! A very well appointed and organized kitchen; she had our menu ready in her head and easily dolled out the tasks to me and my girlfriend. She paused a few times to ask if we wanted to have things measured out or as she knows them: visually, by texture, consistency, and smell. We received the recipes and some pictures she took afterward via e-mail anyway and am glad I didn't see a single index card the whole time! The conversation and wine flowed easily at a comfortable pace...soon enough (though still 4.5 hours later!) We were enjoying soup, then dinner (we chose the chicken paprikas – Paprikás csirke) then desert (the floating island-delicious, easy and someone's favorite!) The entire experience was relaxing, informative and fun. A fantastic way to get away from the usually boring and traditional tourist activities, to see a culture as it is presently but enjoy recipes as they are passed on from generation to generation.

Best cooking experience in a three month European trip. I have been travelling around Europe for three months eatiing, cooking and writing about it and my evening with Agnes and Istvan was one of the most enjoyable of my entire vacation. The classes are private so it was just the three of us and I they are both so welcoming.
