I was able to select what I wanted to learn to cook rather than being forced to sit through a generic menu that someone else had picked. Agnes and Istvan were both very hospitable and I enjoyed both the cooking class but also the dinner table conversation about life in Hungary and the differences to Australia. I would recommend this class for anyone and everyone.

Great day out in Budapest. Until 9 th August this year I had no intention of taking cooking classes - I have a great cook as a wife?  But then we met Agnes at 10 am that day - she has this way about her that you don't even know you are being " taught", she just invites you to partake in the selection and purchasing of the ingredients, then chopping, dicing, mashing, stirring, toasting, boiling, simmering, baking and before you know it, you are sipping Goulasch soup, gorging chicken pancakes and nibbling Cottage cheese balls coated in bread crumbs and lemon garnish - all accompanied by a local drink that makes all pain go away and lovely local wines.  It's unbelievable that 5 hours disappeared in a new York second and we came away from a lovely afternoon in Agnes's company knowing a little more about Hungary and is food, with a craving to know more.  Thank you Agnes.

Such a Special Treat!!... a memorable experience the whole family can enjoy!. My family's recent trip to Budapest, Hungary was so sweetly enriched by our visit with Agnes and Istvan. They are warm, kind, hospitable, and generous peoople who welcomed our family of five with open arms. Prior to our trip, we learned about Agnes & Istvan through tripadvisor website, and we were very much interested. We sent an email to Agnes, and within a day we received a reply with all the answers to our questions. On our designated day/time, we met Agnes in front of the Central Market. Agnes gave us a tour of the market and we were able to experience in firsthand a small glimpse into the life in Budapest. It was informative and interesting to see/smell the local flavors - from ever present paprikas to variety of sausages, organic vegetables to homemade cheeses, local crafts to fine porcelain china, ... We also shopped for the ingredients for our cooking at the market.After the market tour, Agnes took my family in a taxi to her home where Istvan was waiting for us. For the next three hours or so, Agnes and Istvan were wonderful hosts/teachers. They were very patient with my children, explaning and demonstating step by step how to prepare vegetables to how to flip a perfect pancake. We really did ALL the cooking ourselves! We had a wonderful soup, a main chicken dish, and a dessert pancake - all very authentic Hungarian dishes. The entire meal was very delicious and satisfying. But the best part of it all was that we all laughed alot.... It was so much fun! - cooking, talking, chopping, stirring - Sharing a meal together with strangers (now friends) from the other side of the world...All three of my children (ages 17, 15, & 12) LOVED the experience! And my husband and I very much enjoyed our time together with our new friends in Hungary. Thank you, Agnes & Istvan, for your wonderful hospitality!!! We'll always treasure our time together in Budapest, Hungary... The Jo family from Florida

Feeling at Home in Hungary. We adored our culinary experience with Agnes and her fiance! Agnes is very sweet and hospitable in addition to being a great teacher who really understands how to make even the most inexperienced chef feel at ease in her kitchen. The time we spent in the open market shopping for ingredients and cooking and conversing in her quaint kitchen was engaging and interesting. The food was delicious - so much so that our teenage kids cannot wait for us to replicate the meal we had back in the USA for our family and friends! Take advantage of this unique and memorable experience to get out of typical tourist mode. This was certainly a trip highlight!

A fabulous introduction to Budapest. Our family of six (grandparents, parents, and teenagers) had a delightful first-day-in-Budapest, cooking with Agnes, Istavan, and friend Meggy. Agnes is an engaging and talented chef and teacher. Our trip to the market was such fun and the food we prepared was the best we had in Hungary. Back home, I've made the recipes several times to rave reviews. Book the cooking class--it will be a lifetime travel highlight!

Best experience in Budapest. One of the best days of the my 5 week trip. Agnes and Istavan were wonderful teachers but more like friends by the end of the day. The menu was amazing and the one on one teaching was much better than any group class. If you head to Budapest this class should definitely be on the to do list! The wines were delicious also and they let us take our left overs for dinner which let us enjoy the meal for a second time!

Personal Intro to Hungarian Cooking and Culture. I had a cooking class with Agnes on my last day in Budapest but I left wishing that I went at the beginning of my trip. This meal (I chose the menu: Goulash soup, Hortobágyi palascinta, Somlói galuska) was the Hungarian meal that I wanted to have my first night. I have never taken a cooking class so the one-on-one attention that I received was perfect! I was not overwhelmed but at the same time she allowed me to do as much I wanted to do and I had a great time.She welcomed me with a small appetizer, wine and palinka. Then we cooked for a few hours - she introduced each dish and provided insight into her culture, the city and the people while we chopped up vegetables, meats and cracked eggs. I learned a few Hungarian words and was pleasantly surprised at how delicious the meal was! I was even able to take a small piece of the dessert for my friends who live in Budapest and they told me it was the best Somlói galuska they have ever had!I would definitely recommend this to anyone traveling alone or small groups/families. It is one way to get to know a culture with a personal flair (and great food!).

Delicious food, memorable experience and a highlight of our trip!. It was a warm, enjoyable, delicious and fun experience. The hospitality was outstanding; it was such a warn and welcoming event. Agnes and Istvan made us feel at home and ensured we not only learned how to cook, but also learned how to flip the pancake like the professional !!! The ragout soup was so good that I must say it has exceeded my expectation and the flavour was unexpectedly delicious. The pancake was light and smooth without the fat that I had experienced with other recipes. Agnes' recipe is the best !!! I must also mention that the market tour was a MUST !!!! Love it all !!!!

Such a treat. Cooking with Agnes was such a fun time. We booked last-minute as there happened to be a cancellation for the day we were free – lucky for us! This was our first cooking class ever, so we had no idea what to expect. Agnes welcomed us in with prepared appetizers, wine and of course, palinka! We made two amazing dishes for lunch – a sausage soup and chicken paprika with dumplings. YUM. The lesson was focused primarily on preparation of the specific recipes but we also got a couple pointers from Agnes on how to better chop onions and de-stem peppers, which are tricks we will use the rest of our lives. It felt less like a class and more like friends cooking together and chatting about our different cultures – curiosity on both sides. For desert we made amazing cottage-cheese-lemon-breaded-dumplings, which were fantastic. Istvan joined us for lunch and we all enjoyed a tasty meal, wine, and good company. Unfortunately we couldn’t stay as long as we would have loved to since we had a guided tour to catch, but before we left, Agnes dished up our leftovers so we could enjoy round two of deliciousness later that evening on the banks of the Danube. Agnes and Istvan’s hospitality was wonderful and we can’t wait for our next visit to Budapest to learn and taste more dishes.

Fantastic !. I had booked the cooking class with Agnes and Istvan as a surprise for my parents. This evening was even better than I could have imagined and my parents had an absolutely wonderful evening. Agnes and Istvan were extremely organized and I enjoyed picking out the menu for the evening. It is a great way to really get to know a country (and its food and drink (Palinka !)) by spending time with people that actually live there. Agnes and Istvan are extremely friendly and we had a great time learning where they grew up, how they met, etc. This was a highlight for our trip to Hungary!

Can't say enough good things about this!!!!. The market tour and cooking lesson with Agnes and Istvan was one of the highlights of our visit to Budapest. They are both incredibly warm and generous people, it seemed like being invited into the home of dear old friend and not someone we had just met 60 minutes earlier. Agnes is a excellent instructor and is easily adaptable to our cooking skills levels, and culinary interests. The cooking lesson was informative and flowed at a pleasant pace. Not only did they provide cooking lessons, they provided excellent company as we shared wine and food in their home. We highly recommend the experience.

An Unforgettable Evening of Hungarian Cuisine and Hospitality.. No trip to Budapest is complete without a visit to Agnes and Istvan's friendly apartment! When I signed up for a cooking class I never expected that such hospitality, interesting people and great laughs would be part of the deal. Agnes is just a well of information when it comes to Hungarian food and products and she shared it in such a comfortable way that it never felt like a 'lesson'. The opportunity to choose the menu and the hands-on approach they have made me feel very much at home and confident to try new things... like making dumplings :)Istvan was the perfect host, keeping the conversation going, lending a hand with the cooking and keeping our wine-glasses topped up... What more could a girl ask for?I can't wait to go back and I will definitely include a market-tour in my next class.Thanks Agnes and Istvan, for a very special memory!

One of our best experiences of the week in Hungary. This was one of our best experiences of the week in Hungary. It is not only a wonderful introduction to the cuisine and culture, but also a great way to connect with a local. The Central Market where we bought the ingredients was the initial introduction to the food. You can do this on your own (we went back another day and had some terrific langos that’s sold on the upper level) but having someone who knows where things are and what to look for is a great help. The class was relaxed and well arranged, with plenty of time to cook, drink wine and palinka, talk, interact and take pictures. Agnes is a charming hostess. Afterwards we all sat down and ate the authentic Hungarian dishes we made. The delicious food gave us a great feeling of accomplishment!Agnes and her friend Maggie were very willing to discuss all manner of things of life in Budapest. This type of interaction is something that a typical traveler does not have, and gives you an insight into the country and the people. The day after we came home we tried the recipes; of course they didn’t come out as well as the first time, but with practice we know they will improve. Overall, a memorable experience that we highly recommend.

Do Not Leave Budapest Before Cooking With Agnes and Istvan. Had a wonderful authentic cooking lesson with Agnes and Istvan....so wonderful that I went back a second time! (agnes.barath@culinaryhungary.com) (www.culinaryhungary.com)Aside from learning these amazingly delicious Hungarian recipes, it was fun to learn about Hungarian culture through the food. And to also leave with a knowledge of Hungarian food that will always stay with yme along with new friendships! Not to forget, being introduced to different Hungarian wines and Palinka:)A very memorable experience!Leslie-Ann

Brilliant home cooking experience. Agnes met us on the Saturday morning at the tram station with two baskets in hand. First we were off to the local market to buy the groceries for the cooking lesson from local producers and then we headed for her apartment and the cooking experience.The cooking lesson was very well prepared, with easy to follow recepies, good tools. During the class we had time for cooking, tasting wines and learning about Hugarian cooking, culture and life in general. Agnes and Istvan were both very friendly and helpful and easy going. Do take the opportunity to ask Agnes and Istvan about anything you would like to know about cooking, Budapest and life in Hungary. All in all the cooking lesson was an amazing experience and a very memorable occassion and I'd warmly recommend it to people who like cooking, but also to people who would like to get under the skin of Budapest.

A Highlight of our Stay!. We chanced upon this attraction walking down a less touristy street to the river from the castle - and decided to have a look in. It was fantastic: steps down into 1 km of caves and marble quarries housing the prison where Dracula (Vlad the Impaler) was held, a pitch black cave 'experience' (optional), tableaux and music from appropriate Verdi operas, stone pillars, vaulted galleries, history lessons - amazing.

Creepy fun!. Couldn't resist visiting where they held Vlad Tepes aka Dracula on Halloween in Budapest. Pay extra for the dark tour with the gas lamps for the atmosphere but don't do it if you are sensitive to the kerosene smell. Smoke machine adds atmosphere but makes the air a little cloying. Skip this tour if you are afraid of the dark or claustrophobic but well worth it if you like a creepy chill!

One of the Most Unique and Enjoyable Tourist Attractions. Wow! I had so much fun here, that I came back two weeks later to take a friend. There is so much history and intrigue in the caves. You can explore and learn and face some fears. Perfect! I can't wait to go back.

Go it is fun and different. Draculas grave market, dark tour and a Opera soundtrack. It sounds odd but made a great little visit. The dark part is optional but good won't say more as it would spoil the suprise.

Unusual but worth it.... We weren't sure what to expect given the trip advisor reviews however we quite enjoyed this. It was a bit creepy in places and you can avoid the area which is in total darkness which people have complained about. I don't think the entrance fee is any higher than other attractions in Budapest. The caves are quite extensive and there is a fair bit to see. We would recommend a visit, not sure about taking really young children though...

Unusual and Enjoyable. I really enjoyed this, it was very atmospheric and I liked the freedom to explore. There is such a lot to see and do on Castle Hill that this was not my first port of call (I went on day 3 there), but I'm so glad I visited and had the experience, it was larger than I had anticipated.

Exploring the Labyrinth. I think the price is a bit high but if you want to explore some of the caves under the castle this is a good way to do that. There are some exhibits of costumed figures and some dark areas.

Meh. The visit into the underground walkway system was not what we expected. It was ok but really nothing special. They could do so much more with the space. Its interesting and Dracula historic information was cool but you could skip this attraction.

Expensive and not worth it. It cost the equivalent of $12 Canadian. They only accept forints not euros. When you first get in, you see some very badly kept mannequins dressed in opera clothing. After that, the rest of the labyrinth was wet and dark. So dark that I couldn't see a thing and felt I had to move close to a group of people in front of me who were equipped with 2 flashlights. After the intense darkness, you go into a foggy smoky area that is meant to set the mood for a Dracula exhibit which was only comprised of plaques on the wall describing the history of the count. If you like shuffling around in the dark waiting for something to see, this place is for you.

A repulsive place. If you like the pungent smell of mold, the darkness and slime, you probably would like the place. We (me and my two teenage kids) found this visit lousy. The text about Dracula written on the walls (Dracula was imprisoned in the labyrinth for 12 years), was completely nonsense.Go somewhere else instead :-)

A bit too expensive and boring cavehike. We were unsure what to expect from the Labyrinth, and while entering the chill cave I hoped for something more than what we actually found. The opera costumes on old mannequins were nice with the opera music on background and few fans moving the curtains, but after few of the scenes it got really boring. Almost all of the rooms in the cave had some rocks or pieces of old buildings in them. If one is really keen on history these might be of interest, for us they were just boring peaces of stone. The dracula exhibition was mostly posters on walls about Dracula, few of the rooms were full of mist and well illuminated and had really spooky feeling in them. I enjoyed those rooms.Best part of the cave was the completely dark path one could go through. We took each others hands and slowly walked through the path feeling the walls and occasionally searching a helping rope from the wall. The experience was partly ruined by other tourists, who walked the completely black cave with lamps on. Also there were EXIT-signs, which were illuminated by the lamps for a long period of time giving away the correct way to go too easily.We were confused about the cave after we left. There didn't seem to be any connection between the separate parts and overall it was too expensive for what it was worth.
Don't do it. Whole load of damp tunnels with little to see and very expensive for a family. There was no real exhibits or information on offer. Huge disappointment

Very expensive for the content . The lack of information on the exhibits was only matched by the lack of exhibits in general. Very overpriced, very uninteresting and very pointless. Part of the experience involved walking through a pitch black maze holding on to only a hose pipe as a guideline, this made up for around a quarter of the tour. This could be easily created in my basement. Another quarter of the exhibit had mannequins behind iron bars, to stop the mannequins getting at us or us at them? Either way quite boring. We did see some interesting things in there, at one point we stumbled across an old stone tomb/coffin, however this along with other interesting things we came across had no information explaining what it was or even suggesting what it might be. Sorry guys but I'd certainly spend your huf's elsewhere.

Get lost underground. This is a true cave labyrinth underground. The lighting is dimmed and somewhere there is no lights at all, so remember to bring your flashlight with you. It is not huge, but big enough to get lost. There is maps on the wall, but for adventure just go around. There is not much to see, but the experience is still worth it.

Lear more about Dracula while in a cave.. Interesting place to visit while in Buda. We took our 2 kids (5 and 8 years old) since they get a kick out of scary things and they enjoyed learning more about Dracula. There is one area (I forget what it is called) where you can go in and it's totally dark and you have to find your way out. My boys enjoyed doing that with us. It took us about 30-45 minutes to do all of it. I wouldn't say it's a must see but something to consider and that might be interesting if you have kids who are into that type of thing. The attraction has stairs which lead you into the entrance and then the floor can be uneven so watch your step. Also, photos are not allowed.

Interesting. Before you enter - make sure you have local currency (forints) - it is a steep climb down to find out that they don't take plastic or euros. We had to climb back up and find an ATM! A warning sign at the entrance would have been nice. Having said that it is an interesting walk through the caves, part of which is done in total darkness. You have a rope to hold onto and have to hope that the person in front of you keeps moving. The opera connection was sometimes a bit odd and there are several references to Dracula. I am surprised it is ranked as the 8th most visited tourist attraction as it wasn't very busy when we were there. Good to visit on a hot day, or in our case, a rainy day. Takes over an hour to do it all.

What just happened?. I'm into opera and weird caves as much as the next person, and by that I mean not at all. But if you took me to the opera i'm sure i would appreciate the art form. This however was not the opera, this was mannequins dressed as if they were in an Opera while music blared over speakers. The most creepiest thing may be the fact that they were in what looked like jail cells. Was this to protect the mannequins from visitors of the other way round? If you've ever seen an episode of Doctor Who or a scary movie you will understand what I mean when I say 'Don't Blink!'. I took pictures so I could try and explain this to people afterwards but my fear of looking back at the pictures at a later date and discovering the mannequins have disappeared from them and are now haunting my house was too great and I only got in about two pictures before making a break for it. There were sections of the labyrinth that were pitch black, this was interesting as it took quite a while to get though, this wasn't helped by the Well situated about halfway through that took out a large chunk of everyone's shins. After about 20 minutes we left the night of the living mannequins and came across the Dracula exhibit. This was probably even odder as they filled the caves so much with fog that we couldn't actually read any of the text on the walls about his life without the torch i had on my car keys. One thinks the operator of the Fog machine was having an argument with management as there was such a heavy fog we couldn't see where we were going or what we were looking at. They lead you to believe Dracula was either buried here or somewhere similar. Doing our own research after the fact we now know that he wasn't buried in a cave at all. I wouldn't be surprised if one of the exhibits descriptions explained about how he opened for Beyonce in 2008 and sung with David Hasselhoff at the Berlin Wall. Where as you may think I would not recommend visiting this "attraction", I do! We have never laughed more, screamed at each other in the dark or talked about a day more than this weird afternoon in a cave.

Worst thing I've ever done. Whoever had the audacity to advertise this place as the 8th most visited tourist attraction in Europe must have been smoking bath salts - it's probably not the 8th most popular thing on Buda hill.For what feels like possibly an incredibly intersting place, the bizarre and disjointed exhibits and extreme lack of information were very frustrating. My girlfriend and I went there after 6.30pm to do the lamp light tour, which sounded like quite a fun and unique element. I don't know if them having turned off all the lights led to us not finding any of the exhibits, but we wandered around for half an hour through empty rooms looking at mannequins dressed in old opera props (still have no idea why) and looking at lumps of stone with different stonemasonry techniques on them - still no idea where they were from or why they were there. It's annoying to know that the recent history of the labyrinths - i.e as a shelter in WWII are barely even mentioned, let alone promoted or explained. Basically, in summary, if you want to waste 2500 Florint and an hour of your life this place is ideal. There are significantly better things to do in Budapest - don't bother with this.

Interesting place to visit.. We booked a tour via victor to Budapest. And we squeezed in this little underground house into our free time. Not everyone will like it but we certainly did.There's a stairs leading you underground, pretty steep so please be careful.It will lead you to underground "cave" like where Count Dracula was held prisoner there.You require tickets to enter this attraction place.

Really nice!. Really enjoyed the Labyrinth. Have a lot of different feelings during the it. Awesome atmosphere. A lot of people are complaining about the light but I think that is the darkness that makes it even greater. Recommended. It's not that scary but sometimes you get goose bumps.
Worth doing. Nice atmospheric experience. One part was pitch black and this scared the wife to death. Nice and cool so a good thing to do on a hot summers day.

Not what we expected.... We were given the impression that this was just a wander through the cave system below Buda Castle. I enjoyed it at first, as you got to walk through the dimly lit caverns, but beware, if you don't like spooky stuff, or are scared of being in complete darkness (like me), the enjoyment doesn't last.... My partner loved it, though, so it really does depend on what floats your boat...

Love the Labyrinth. Enjoyed the Labyrinth. The wax opera scenes were unexpected. Found the conflicting information on Dracula interesting. Really enjoyed the pitch black tunnel. It was damp and stony and full of history!

Very interesting, could use a little more lights. Our visit to the labyrinth was very interesting, 2500 huf isn't too much for what we saw but some of the pass ways were dark, we used the mobiles flashlight to pass through some places. LED lights don't emit temperature and don't cost that much to be placed in the 8th most important place on earth to visit

Different but nice. It was a different experience from the usual tourist attractions, really bizare but Fun. You can see where Dracula was captive for 13 years. It is cold down there so bring a jacket!

Interesting but not fantastic. This says it is the 8th best attraction in Europe. It is not. Interesting seeing the labyrinth of caves but the exhibitions have seen better days. Wife liked it because not too scary. With some more effort with better lighting and responsive to movement it could be very good.

bring a light. The exibitions in there wasnt much to see, moldy old clothes ...But the labyrint itself was interesting. Some really dark areas though, so i would reccomend bringing a lightsource.The history of the place is rather interesting, and walking these tunnels thinking about what it would be like to be locked away down there is really creepy.

Not bad, but don't expect too much. Ran into this place while visiting the Bastion and decided to give it a try. Not many exhibits inside apart from the few stone pieces (no English translation on the description plates), and wax dolls concerning the opera. Expect many damp, dark, long tunnels and halls. Also I find it a bit pricey for the fact that it's offerings are somewhat poor. Nevertheless, we had fun but there are much better places to visit in Budapest.

One of the worst experience in my life.. First they take 2500HUF for one adult person. Then they make you follow rope attached to wall in complete darkness for about 15 minutes with water dripping on your head. After about 15 minutes you'll see some light and pretentious dressed mannequins. It is like walking in dark, damp basement for the price of lunch for two. Absolutely ridiculous.

Very different to other attractions, quite scary and nerve tingling. This was the caves in which Dracula was kept and it was very scary. There is a dark bit with no lights just a rope to follow. It freaked me out. Not good for children!

Enjoy a cool break underneath and the dark maze. Cost is 2500HUFF to enter. There is a dark maze (and a thread to guide you). The rest shows different pieces excavated as well as offers niches with wax figures wearing outfits from a Verdi opera. Today it was 90F out so we appreciated the temperaturw difference

Not great, but fun nonetheless. As an underground activity, it definitely ranks below the Hospital in the Rocks. The "exhibition" part of the attraction is not very interesting, but the labyrinth experience is overall interesting. After 6PM they turn of all the lights and provide you a gas lantern - and that's when the real fun begin. At least if you are into this kind of fun... I admit that getting lost in the dark, in a wet place is not the best definition of fun for most people, but if this is the kind of thing that you think you might enjoy, go for it! Great for young couples and for children...

Budapest Labryinth/Labirintus. I visited the Labyrinth underneath Buda Castle in Budapest during Summer 2016. It is worth pointing out straight away that this is difficult to access, so I would advise caution to the elderly or disabled.The Labyrinth itself was a pleasant, if a bit scary as most of it is dimly lit to add to the atmosphere and has water dripping from the ceiling at points. The Labyrinth tells the story of Dracula and how he was imprisoned in the dark chambers, via plaques on the walls and also an opera, which has mannequins behind bars telling the story. There is also an opera/spooky soundtrack throughout.The Labyrinth can be completed in your own time and took me around 45 minutes. Recommended to people interested in local culture and are not scared of the dark!
disappointing . Not at all what we were expecting. Looks like an ad for the Opera House. The fog was so intense you couldn't see any of the displays. Would not recommend.

Don't do this alone! But it's amazing!! . I can't believe I did this solo! With just an oil lamp through the entire labyrinth where Count Dracula was kept and others tortures. It has history so it is scary! It's wet down there too and huge! So much fun ! I wanted to go back again! A must do!

Left me quite disapointed. Not really worth a visit if you are short on time. I was expecting to see a lot more like the ivy room, the face in water, the wine fountain, the kings's tomb - but instead found Dracula's story and wax statues and nothing really historical.

Amesome Subterranean experience. The labyrinth was immense. My kids had a great time exploring it. The fog and the eerie atmosphere created in some parts of the labyrinth was really awesome.Not to be missed unless you lack the curiosity for adventure.

A typical yogic challenge. If you are ready to prove yourself, go to the labyrinth! In order to overcome the fear of the most complete darkness of a little part of the labyrinth itself, please keep costantly an hand in contact with the handrail otherwise it is really dangerous or please bring with you a torch. In this way you avoid to crash your head against column. But with an hand in strict contact with handrail it is a good help and good yogic challenge with your own Inner fears! I would like to repeat this experience without the torch!! :) Children : for them it is better to avoid the dark path.

So much potential.... Read a lot about the labyrinth under Buda castle, with interesting things to do there including wine tasting. Turns out the management of this space has been changing around and now it's explored by another company that uses it as an "house of terror", with the "Dracula Tomb" theme.It has interesting parts, a well made atmosphere, nice soundtrack, and they create a psychological fear from time to time. But other than that is mostly empty dark rooms. A bit disappointing. And if there are noisy groups at the same time the atmosphere and experience is further ruined. Although only 2000 forints, it's not worth the money. Do only if you have money and time to spare.

An interesting experience . We didn't real know what to expect when we arrived. Wasn't for the faint hearted, was quiet scary with a totally darkness maze and Dracula's chamber. Did have totally random parts throughout with clothing from the theatre. Was an interesting place, I would advise taking a touch.

Great experience. I really liked the labyrinth. It is really well done - the athmosphere at some points is truly haunting and even thought it is quite big the caves have different feel to them. You should really go and just wander around in the foggy, dark and misty caves. The air in the caves is a bit bad so would not recommend for people with for example asthma.

Nice attraction.. We didn't have much time while we were in Budapest, but still made a decision to not skip the tunnels under the Buda castle.What to say..It has this "amusement park" spirit...It might be, that I expected too much of it. It is interesting,it is fun. At some points could be a little frightening and claustrophobical experience. Must admit, that we "cheated" at the "100% dark" area, I panicked a bit...so..it would definitely be better to calm down, took our time and use our senses. I think that would definitely made our experience better.

Best thing you can do on a hot summer day. The caves are incredible experience especially during hot summer day. Definitely worth the admission price. Didn't contain that many historical relics or information on them, but the atmosphere was something else. Some kind of torch useful, the worse the better.

Great place for . We had great time in the dank cellars of labyrinth. My friend spooked some random visitors in the dark recesses of the labyrinth. Perfect place to visit with friends if you have imagination. Also if the weather is hot outside the place is really good to chill and not sweat like a pig. Just don't hit your head on walls and stuff. Not for claustrophobic people and people with bad feet.

An different experience. This is under the Buda Castle and has some links to Dracula, as Vlad the Impaler was imprisoned (and murdered) here.This was recommended by friends and we liked it a lot. It is different experience, with cool dark misty corridors and caves, wax figures, displays, and a fully-dark scary passage my wife hated! I had avoided it on previous visits to Budapest but was glad that we followed our friends' recommendation this time. Try it, you will most probably enjoy it a lot.

Nice way to spent an hour. Nice way to learn a little history of both Dracula and Budapest. Some fairly scary bits if you are afraid of the dark but you can cheat and use the torch on your phone as my wife did.

Wet, dank, dark and scary. This was very interesting to me and I found it so much fun, but there were other tourists there who clearly were not enjoying it as much as me. I must admit that there were a few places I was scared of going on my own, but if you don't scare so easily you probably won't enjoy it so much.

The worst thing you can do. The place is really dark, cold , foggy and on top of that there is lack of signs and arrows, we got lost there till we met another lost young couple, my kids are 10 years old and we all thought that will not make it to the exit after ending up with 5 deadened paths,,,, and by chance we finally made it to the way up :(Not a fun experience at all, needs a lot of work to improve the place first then reopen it as a tourist site !

Worthwhile to include on visit to castle hill. We visited many of the main highlights of Castle Hill on the first day of our visit to Budapest, but weren't aware of the extensive caves that lie beneath. After doing a bit of reading afterwards, we decided to go back a few days later to explore the cave aspect and found both this exhibit and the "labyrinth" caves to be worthwhile second visit activities. The Labyrinth was purely entertainment as a self guided walk though caves with various exhibits including one that featured Verdi's opera A Masked Ball with recorded music (always great in caves, right?) and "wax substitute" figures of the characters; another that covered the history of the real Count Dracula (not a vampire, but was supposedly at one point kept prisoner in these caves); and another one that allowed you to walk some distance in full darkness using only a thin string along the wall to find your way (a sign at the entrance encourages you to meditate on what it is like to experience absence of light but unfortunately this experience was somewhat ruined for us by several groups of millennials who either failed to read or ignored the sign and passed through using their cell phone flashlights to break the darkness!). The Hospital in the Rock exhibit provided a nice historical tour on the use of the caves as a medical facility during WWII, during the 1956 uprising, and later as a potential command center in the event of a nuclear war.

Review. It gives you the chills if you visit it and don't use the flash light. But I didn't do that. The interior is like a cave underground the light is poor and the humidity is high. The special effects also make a foggy atmosphere and the music is creepy. When I visited it was a Dracula exposition and if you do not get scared easily you will must likely enjoy it.

Definitely worth doing. This is a must do when in Budapest.
It is underground under Buda castle - in caves
Bits are a little scary but not so bad.
Lots of history about Dracula but the attraction would benefit from maybe an actor in costume telling short stories as you walk around

Very different experience - give it a try!. I was aprehensive this would be some amusement park-esque experience, with fake scares. I'm so glad it was not, in fact it is very interesting to walk about with an old-school lantern in a cave. As it's deep in the rock, temperature drops considerably the further you go - can't help but wonder how it was for the people who were actually imprisoned there in the past. Go for it, it's actually more interesting than it sounds at first.

Disappointing. I'm a huge fan of horror movies but this place was a bit disappointing, mainly because there is not much to.. it didn't feel worth the money, being mostly a series of empty corridors and rooms, interspersed with some cheap wax figurines representing an opera...

An unique experience that is creepy and fit for adventurous souls. Want to experience walking through a historical space that evokes and entertains all senses? Consider taking some time to visit this underground labyrinth that could only be experienced in this authentic complex. Contextualized as a space where role play and spirit can be appreciated, you are brought in challenges that make you think, "Am I really doing this?"Set up for self-paced touring in a secret place with no natural lighting, you gain an appreciation of the stories shared on signage in English and can travel home to live to tell about the tales of what could be considered phenomenon activity.

Better than the Hospital in a rock!. We visited both the hospital in the Rock and the Labyrinth in the same day and we much preferred the Labyrinth! There are pro and cons to both but senior citizens, families with young children and individuals with mobility issues will enjoy the hospital much better.For backpackers, couples, and young adults this is far better than the hospital ( and less expensive as well). No mandatory tour guide rushing you along so you can really enjoy exploring the darkness, viewing the various sections dedicated to eras in which the tunnels were utilized. TIP!!!! Bring along any kind of a small penlight! Or make sure your phone is well charged to provide a light. We spend a full hour and a half exploring all the chambers and tunnels which are still very original! Dripping water everywhere, with some small puddles and lots of darkness. Do this in the middle of the hot day and you'll love the escape into the cool underground chambers. You can walk down the long staircase and look around a little bit with out even having to pay until you actually get into the tunnel system. If your not sure at least make this quick trip down the stair to see if your interested. This is the Buda side activity I'm going to be telling all my friends they need to do!

Surprisingly scarier than you may think. When entering the Labyrinth, you may think it's something tame with these weird dummie things but actually when you walk further you come to the maze of darkness! Enter at your own risk...ha ha. This is ONE of the best parts of the Labyrinth.Read on to find out more.If you enter the maze of darkness congratulations (for being brave of course) because then you will know what it is like to stay it pitch darkness. When you enter you will feel a rope that you hold on to all the way till you see a speck of light. As you walk through you can't see a single thing! Don't go in alone.Anyone who goes in the maze may get goosebumps. It's true.When the maze of darkness is finished you walk many steps and it gets misty..and mistier...and mistier....and then so misty you can't hardly see a thing! Then when you past that part you'll come to a room where there are all these things about Dracula and how his wife died and stuff and then you come to this room with there are there heads on a stone wall and you may get creeped out at that point because the next room has blood under three rotted nails- I'll not tell you why because i don't want to spoil it all. When you finally come to the end you may feel like you want to go in it again but will it feel like it did on the first time you went round? You may either feel the exact same again or feel more scared or feel more brave.Have a guess what you'd feel on your second time round.Olivia Age 10

Not really much to see...should be more interactive!. My boyfriend and I visited the labyrinth last Saturday afternoon on the night of museums in Hungary so we only actually paid 1500 HUF each to visit unlimited museums. Normally it is about 3500/4000 HUF to get in which for what is is, is a bit overpriced.This one was a bit disappointing mainly because there is not much to see, literally, in some parts of it! The dark cave tunnels are probably the most fun bit as you can't see a thing and spend a while trying to work out which way to go. Not good for people who are scared of the dark or of small spaces!There are random waxwork figures in parts of which there was no explanation of why they were there. There are a few plaques to read about Dracula and the labyrinth.It is slightly cold in there so consider wearing a extra layer! Also I wouldn't go wearing sandals or any nice pair of shoes you may own as it is very wet and clay-like in most parts. Just a warning!It would be much better if they made it more interactive and maybe had some live actors in certain parts! There was only one member of staff actually walking around the museum - and he was dressed as Dracula and wouldn't say anything to you!
Fun break. We decided to try the labyrinth and I did enjoy it. Nice in cool in there when hot outside. Be sure to try the part with no lights. There are some cheesy parts but we enjoyed
Super interesting!. Peaceful, a bit creepy bunker labyrinth with details of Vlad the Impaler and Dracula, comparisons about their lifes... Super interesting, the best part of our Budapest trip!

Impressive but...... An impressive, long route undeneath Buda's Castle but...definitely not recommended for people who suffer from claustrophobia. My only objection is that I don't know whether the place is sufficient monitored, in order that the staff will be able to intervene in case a visitor feels uncomfortable or experiences a panic attack. . During our visit we met only the cashier sitting in front of a small number of monitors, and he was sleeping instead watching them.The ventilation is also inadequate.

Creepy and Fun. Fairly tucked out of the way. We visited after 6pm and took the lantern tour, guiding ourselves round a large labyrinth with a paraffin lamp. Definitely eery investigating Dracula's chamber in the dark. It was quiet when we went so I think we were the only ones there, which added to the creepy atmosphere. Very fun but must watch where you're walking. Might be different with the lights on but it felt like we were exploring the past in a chilly mist.

Find Dracula!. It is a lot of fun to walk around the labyrinth underground, especially the part with the grave of Dracula inside a white cloud.. The completely dark part is rather long but fun for groups. Kids have to be attended though since its not difficult to get lost inside the long corridors of labyrinth.

Spooky... But cool, read about it... The whole concept is good but it needs more supervision inside the cave.. Kids screaming and switching off phone lights takes out the charm and the true feeling of the walk.. It an option. It is slippery and mind your head..

labyrinth is impressive but the tour was disappointing. We took the evening lantern walk. The labyrinth in itself is quite impressive, but we expected more from the tour. We expected a guided tour, but there was no option for a guided tour and the information presented along the rout of the labyrinth wasn't satisfying.

Unique experience that seems to have divided reviewers. People either seem to love or hate the Labyrinth - and I think the cause is that as an attraction, it is hard to classify.First off, many websites will say it is closed. This is not true any more, it was very much open when I was there. Most days it is open from 10AM-9PM and for an adult, the price is 2500 Ft. though some hotels will give cards for a discount. I went at 6PM and was given a lantern to explore with - the whole labyrinth has little to no lighting of its own, and with the generally low number of entrants, makes the whole place very atmospheric. Inside is a mish-mash of themes and information, from Budapest's history (particularly about King Matthias), to waxwork dioramas of famous operas, examples of masonry and stoneworking, pictures of famous caves around the world..... and most famously, stories about Vlad the Impaler's (Dracula's) relationship with Budapest.The whole cave system is somewhat spooky, with two (optional) sections being particularly tense - the completely black maze of darkness and the foggy Dracula's crypt. If you've played Amnesia: The Dark Descent, you'll have a vague idea of what to imagine. It's not a horror maze however, so there are no jump scares.For what it's worth, I enjoyed the experience. It's relatively short (~45 mins) but memorable. Don't expect a museum, a historical site or a ghost ride, but a little bit of all three and appreciate it for what it is: unique.
Good fun. Great fun going through the pitch black part following just a line of rope,good atmospheric lighting and sound around the rest of it. Great for the teenagers we had with us

Great spooky fun. A really creepy experience walking around this site of Draculas imprisonment back in the 1400's. The totally darkened tunnels which you had the choice to follow or not, with its moist damp stone floors & walls, foggy atmosphere, silent pathways, old cells & unexpected scenarios of its past victims gave me the chills. I was glad I was not alone! It is an awesome place to visit but could have more informative signage. The old stone archways and labyrinth of tunnels under the Buda Castle area are amazing.

Great time. The labyrinth is the old tunnels below the city. You pay a 8 euro entry but definitely worth every cents. Is around 1 kilometer walking that you can see different ancient stones, the prison of Dracula and some opera characters. Make sure you have a flash light especially in the dark areas. A bit scary in the dark areas with the classic music and the fog. Great 1 hour. Estimate approx. one hour in order to see and read everything.

Labyrinth without any value. According to posters and commercial, this place is the 8th most visited place in Europe. It is not. We were almost alone. There is an intresting system of old watercaves approx 20 meters under the ground. The theme is Dracula.... Really lousy theme. It looks like they have some left over garbage from the local museum to show. We paid 7000 huf for 2 adults, 1 child and 1 teenager. Not worth anything I would say. The place could be wort visiting if the theme and the concept was totally changed.
Dastardly Dracula. The Labyrinth Caves were an unexpected diversion we found while shopping back streets in the Castle district. Fascinating history.

Lack of direction. I'm not sure that the Labyrinth knew exactly what it was trying to be! With scenes from an opera and music playing which end abruptly to plunge guests into darkness and then you come out on the other side with information about dracula. Parts of a building from a museum are scattered throughout and the experience ends with information on other caves you can visit. The caves were a great setting for something incredible but a like of time and effort means this attractions falls short. Would not recommend

One of Best Things to Do in Budapest. This 15th century underground maze of tunnels and chambers under Castle Hill is a great fun to explore and learn it's history. Parts of it are completely dark, thread on the wall being your only guide. Some chambers are decorated as scenes from Verdi's opera "The Masked Ball" (Though I did not understand the connection to the labyrinth, it was still impressive). You get a lot of information about Vlad the Impaler (Dracula) and Matthias I. We had a lot of fun going through it.

Great experience!. The labyrinth here in Budapest is a must see in my opinion. You have to be prepared for a long staircase and it might be a little cold. It can be a little scary at times, but NO JUMP SCARES :)It is a very interesting story about this labyrint and they have done well "decorating" it.You can walk through this in half an hour, but you should reserve one hour and a half if you want to see and read everything.

Best of Budapest. NOT Closed (April 2016). Other websites which state it is closed are outdated.Tucked away in the Castle district, this is a must see, in my opinion. It is promoted as Dracula's prison but actually has a dark and intriguing history. The labyrinth of tunnels has been in existence and used by man/hominids for nearly 300 000 years and was of course used in WW2.In medieval times it was a prison for the infamous Vlad the Impaler from Transylvania. The Dracula connection of the Labyrinth is therefore historical derivation from which the vampire legend is borrowed.The Labyrinth is just 2 minute walk from St Mathias Church and costs 2500 Florints.It takes about 30 minutes to walk through the tunnel which is about 30m deep and is accessed from a steep staircase. The tunnel itself has sufficient light, is flat and a close study of the map shows it is easy to find your way around (if you ignore the little alcoves). There are displays of Verdi's the Masked Ball close to the main entrance and I have been told that some performances take place in these tunnels.The first of two eerie sections is an unlit 'maze'. It was so dark I could not see my feet but with the help of my wife's phone we walked through it and I did not bump my head on the ceiling (Some sections are slightly under 6 feet high)The second exciting section was filled with smoke from dry ice and led to 'Dracula's tomb'. The music here was that of a church organ with a suitable crescendo as we approached the tomb. I would strongly advise that you do not visit this part of the tunnels, or indeed the whole Labyrinth, alone.

Interesting cave visit. The cave entrance is the steepest part to enter (there's a very steep staircase. After this the rest of the cave is very level and flat. There is a maze of darkness section in the cave. Be prepared for this part, I thought it would be a very short section, but it took me about 10-15 minutes to get through this part in total darkness using a rope to find my way through! It did make the tour much more interesting though! Most of the rest of cave has exhibits with wax figures about an opera (which didn't really add anything to the cave tour in my opinion)Other parts of the cave had artificial fog added near the Dracula parts to make it more atmospheric.

Amazing . It's so good, it's where Dracula (Vlad the Impaler, the real Dracula) was imprisoned. I know that's what they are about but we got lost down there, it's really dark and creepy. There is a part where you can walk through just holding onto a rope and it's pitch black. We made it about 15m before we had to use the lights on our phones and it was still scary with them. I wouldn't of liked to be imprisoned there but I'm really glad we went. The pictures don't do it justice. It's too dark to take them further in and there is a white mist/fog that makes your camera flash/phone light worthless.

Can't stop laughing. I hate going to "horror houses" in carnivals but this was recommended by a friend so my husband and I tried it out.Note that you need Hungarian Forint (2,500 per adult) to get in. They don't accept euro nor credit cards.Read the texts on the walls before going in. They will hand you just 1 lamp wherein after just a few minutes in, you would pray that the kerosene doesn't run out. I used the flashlight on my iPhone but it doesn't help much when the misty air starts kicking in. I don't want to tell you what happens throughout but it was definitely eerie and fun at the same time. Hubby and I couldn't stop laughing after the whole madness was over.Not for the faint of heart, claustrophobic, those scared of the dark, etc. I don't know if they are equipped to handle an emergency.The labyrinth map was downright useless. Just be alert with the arrows and don't let panic or terror take over. Good luck and have fun!

Totally bizarre. We were expecting this attraction to showcase the underground caves as it described in our guidebook, but instead the caves have been turned into one of the strangest tourist attractions I've ever visited. A combination of wax models dressed in costumes from the Hungarian Opera, peculiar background music and smoke machines make for a puzzling half hour underground. The maze of darkness section is quite amusing as you walk through an unlit section of the caves following a rope attached to the wall, but slightly dangerous due to the pitch black and damp, sticky conditions. It is, as the name would suggest, a labyrinth and the worst thing is the lack of provision for those who might panic in the corridors and want to get out - there are no members of staff inside and we only saw one map during our visit. Every corner looks the same and with no emergency exits you really do have to keep going until you happen to see the way out. Definitely not recommended for sensitive children or the claustrophobic.

Ok but Not Recommended. It was a bit disappointing. The attraction includes the "Medival Stonework", "the Masked Ball of the Black Count" (wax dolls from an opera), "Dracula's Chamber", "Marvellous Caves" (introduction of other caves all over the world by panels) & "Ghost Labyrinth" but we couldn't find the Ghost bids.For the Dracula's Chamber, I expected many more wax dolls would be there to demonstrate his brutal history but what they had were basically explanation panels (the panels themselves were interesting but we wanted more of thrills.)To be fair, the labyrinth itself is a natural creature not artificial and it was where the Dracula was imprisoned so it is a historically important place, but the place could have been better on the whole.Cannot be really recommended.

Funny attraction. . I went there because the tourist guide ,who showed me Buda Castle, Saint Matthias Church and Fisherman's bastion, recommended me to go there. I will highly recommend it to people who enjoy Dracula stories. I really enjoyed myself.

An unusual underground attraction. Slightly pricey but couldn't resist the tour of Dracula's underground prison. It has got a very interesting history and not for those who don't like the dark. In the great Buda village area so can be combined with many other sites. Quirky is the best description.

Scary but fun. The tour starts with some figures and opera music which make you wonder what on earth this is all about. As you progress into the tunnels it gets very dark and eventually dry ice fog makes it very scary. There are stories of Dracula which give a historical perspective to his life and his imprisonment in the caves - very spooky.All in all great fun not for the faint hearted or anyone with mobility issues though.

A little kitschy, but very spooky!. I was attracted to visit the Labyrinth due to its promotion as the place where the actual Count Dracula was imprisoned in the 1400's. Although there were several parts of the caves that were a little on the kitschy side - wax figures playing 18th Century music (which I didn't really understand the purpose of) - the Dracula portions of the caves were really spooky. It was very dark and foggy on the day that I visited. It was a little tricky finding the way out, but I'm glad I did it. A good scare!

Find a mini card for discount.. Some hotels have a stand full of mini-cards, look for this venue to receive 200ft off entry price. One card per person.This is near the fisherman's bastion hidden away. You walk down several deep steps into the start of the chamber, no signage thus far, you can walk around this chamber for free before you have to pay entry fee.The labyrinth is a large circle that takes about 40 mins to get around if you read every plaque. It's cool/damp throughout with some areas having mild fog.It's strange at points as there's wax dummies reenacting parties or daily life with opera music in the background but no explanation as to why they were there. Did they party in the caves? Who knows.Later on, you'll start reading about Dracula and I think his grave is in one of the chambers, again, it's unclear and strange. Throughout is random pieces of rock of which I assume are old artefacts found in the cave. Eg, a windowsill. In one section you can experience what it was like in 'no electricity' times and walk through a dark maze. It's pitch black but they have a rope (wet hosepipe) attached to the wall to guide you. There's a lot of low ceilings, dim lighting and uneven and wet flooring in here with little warning. At some points, there was fog? Which was difficult to see through or where to safely walk.It's a bizarre experience but its a cave nonetheless and has historical elements, you just need to find them out beforehand.No WiFi (obviously) but toilets available.
Very Scary. The Labyrinth is well worth a visit with wax work figures, dry ice clouds and pitch black sections. Not for those who are afraid of the dark!

Great fun, especially if you like something a bit different!. This was a fun, if slightly bizarre, experience and I would definitely recommend a visit. It includes a pitch black maze, dracula's chamber, and wax works and strange opera music at various intervals. It was pretty empty when we went - maybe because you probably wouldn't even notice the signposts unless you were looking for them. Great for a rainy day.
Interesting . Interesting to go and imagine what it was like in the pitch darkness. Dracula section is creepy and the dark maze is scary! Eery place but interesting.

The only thing in Budapest that disappointed us. This place was very dark, there was nothing to see, it was very creepy and scary.Nothing beautiful from nature, only some artificial stones and puppets.At some points it was even dangerous as you could hurt your head against the walls and ceilings. My wife wanted to get out, but it then really looked like a labirynth, no overview at all how you could easily find your way out. We wished we would have stayed outside to enjoy the magnificent beauty of the environment above these caves !

I loved this place!. This was one of the highlights of my trip. Me and my Mum went in here not knowing what to expect. It is slightly random and a bit creepy. Then we got to the bit called 'the maze of darkness'. It was terrifying! There are no lights at all and you can't even see your hand in front of your face. It was such a giggle as me and my mum were both terrified! You just have a rope attached to the walls to follow. If you are considering a visit, please do. it is so much fun to be absolutely terrified like that. In the end (after about 10 minutes only, and only going a few metres hahaha) we tagged on to a couple who were obviously scared too and they were using the lights on their phones... We stuck with them to find our way out as we were so scared.It was fun!

Don't waste your money. Expensive to get in and really kitschy, the information provided was just wall plaques with conflicting information. Underground was full of random stone carvings with no explanation of what they meant, and weird dummies dressed as opera characters. Waste of money and time.

Short and Empty. Based on a travel guide, my wife and I visited this attraction on our holiday in Budapest. The price was steep compared to most other museums and attractions in the city and didn't feel worth the money, being mostly a series of empty corridors and rooms, interspersed with some wax figurines representing an opera and examples of Medieval stone carvings. I gather from the official website that there was once much more to see, but a police raid in 2011 resulted in closure and re-opening in its current form.

Dark n` Scary!. Really scary and surprisingly dark, and not a lot of people was there, so we were lucky! We were handed a lantern, so the ambiance was complete. Kinda weird with all the dolls in costumes, was not a lot of information about those, but recommend it for those interested in the scarier parts of Buda Castle and hungerian history!
Great but creepy experience. The labrynth makes a great visit for adults and children although might be a bit scary for young children. It's also a great place to cool down if it's very warm outside.
Very interesting . Great atmosphere and very interesting. Entrance a little bit away from the castle but that was good as it was much quieter.

Okay. I did learn some information about Dracula, and enjoyed the very short pitched black maze. However, overall I would say its not worth the money. Me and my friends got bored and decided to leave before the 'Labyrinth' before it had even ended.

Atmospheric well explained attraction. Really enjoyed this attraction. The entrance fee was small. It indicates that your visit should take about 30 minutes. We took about twice this time as the exhibits and cave formations are explained really well on large boards in several languages, including English. The totally dark maze is awesome! I really enjoyed the misty areas housing the Dracula exhibition and tomb! Great fun and educational too!

Rather for small kids. The Labyrinth can be found in a small street (Uri utca 9.) of Buda Castle. Not in the main ones, rather hidden, but there are some signs to show you the way. To get to the caisse you have to go down a lot of steps, from street level to a deep cellar. Make sure you have cash in your vallet, since they do not accept cards. Entry fee is 2500 HUF for adults, but they offer discounts for children, teachers, pensioners, groups and they also accept some coupons (Hop-on-hop-off, Minicard). Guides are not provided, but there are signs, maps and plaques to help you. The place houses several exhibitions, most of them are really only for effect. The inprisonment of Dracula to this very cave is an extremely interesting historic event, however, it is shown as a lame vampire story. The waxworks in costumes are just rottening puppets instead of characters from Verdi's A Masked Ball (no suprise they are rottening, humidity is pretty high there). The Caves of the World exhibition means nothing more but a couple of photos. The Labyrinth of the Darkness where "you may encounter yourself" is a simple corridor without lights. The medieval carved stones are interesting but something is missing. There was a room where old movies were shown but without explanatory notes... It was very disappointing for me, but I am a grown-up person with expectations. I wouldn't really recommend this place unless 1. it is heavily raining outside and you are right at the entrance 2. you have to babysit for 10-15 small kids. In this latter case, take the advantage of that the place organizes games where spiders, wizard hats, skulls etc.have to be found among the exhibits. Kids like stuff like this.

Interesting but a bit scary for my girls!. My wife and I found this to be a interesting, fun and enjoyable experience. The weather was very wet so an underground attraction seemed ideal. My 7 and 10 years old daughters found it to be a little scary but they survived and lived to tell the tale!

Make sure you see it all!. Fantastic, atmospheric cave / cellar complex including Buda Castle dungeon where Dracula was imprisoned.Local language and English boards explain the history clearly.There are many ways round and the direction arrows don't really help. So do ensure you see all of it if you're enjoying it. Especially, Dracula's grave and the torture cage.Toilets are at the end (not start) which takes at least 30 minutes. We took over an hour.There are some moth-eaten displays of manikins, wearing opera costumes, near the start. Whilst the opera music somehow fits the atmosphere the displays definitely require a makeover.If you're feeling brave, make sure you take the dark route and don't cheat with your mobile phone torch!Definitely worth a visit, and of course perfect for any wet days.2,500 HUF per adult.

Treated like a criminal. The labyrinth experience would probably have been fine (if slightly overpriced and - asthmatics beware - STRONG use of smoke in some areas), however it was totally marred by our experience at the gate. There was no one at the ticket stand when we walked up, so while we waited I took a photo of what may have been a security TV in there because it looked extremely spooky and cool. Immediately a man came out and rudely ordered me to delete the photo and let him watch me do it. He reacted as if I had lifted something from the desk. I apologised, showed him the photo, then seemingly out of nowhere there was a second man behind me closing me in, offering to "delete it for (me)" I had to explain i had already done it for his colleague. I said i hadn't seen a no photos sign, however i noticed one on the way out which had no explanation of the following rule: they said I could obviously take photos inside, but obviously couldn't take one of the ticket desk. I hadn't heard of this rule before. I felt really shocked walking in, and a bit upset. Never been treated that way as a visitor before.

Slightly creepy . Visited with my boyfriend, wasn't planned but we walked past the entrance and were intrigued.It was a very different experience but definitely not for people of a nervous disposition! Parts of the walk are pitch black and it's not well signposted-even the torch on the iPhone couldn't get us out.The history of it and the plaques were an interesting read.Be prepared to be a little bit uneasy the whole was through the course but I would recommend, was certainly a talking point afterwards!

If you do anything while here do this. We were confused as before we went to Budapest it said it was closed permanently, so when we stumbled across this while walking around Buda and it being open we were confused, but this appears to be a separate one to the Castle Labyrinth that is closed.However its so cheap to get in and apparently Vlad Tepes was imprisoned here, it is both a bit of fun, weird and can scare the pants off you if you dare to go into the pitch black parts and feel your way out by using the damp walls a s a guide.The wax figures are really weird and I am sure if you stand there long enough they will move or follow you around the caves.Be warned it is a steep stairway to get in and out, but just do it for the experience

Eerie but fun!. Myself and my SO went to this after 6pm, where there were no lights, and we had an oil lamp to guide ourselves around. A truly unique experience, it was very fun trying to find our way around and reading information about Dracula's imprisonment. Some of the information was lost on us, such as the fact that the Labyrinth also had information about Opera, and this was confusing. A lovely time though, and well worth doing after six if you want something a bit different than the daytime visits.

Great sight but the parking is a scam!!!. The place is beautiful.. First 30min parking is free, the next is 525 forint and if you are there over an hour you have to pay 5250 forint!!! That's around 20€ and the parking autonat only take 1, 2, 5 or 10€ notes or forint.. No chance to exchange your money... The parking is a SCAM, I suggest you go there by foot or by bus (16)

Slightly scary, but interesting.. These are real caves, although they don't look so much like it now, but they are also quite far below ground. So you go down some stairs and down some more stairs and then down some more, finally you reach the entrance. There is a map of the caves and lots of information about the history of the caves. There is an option to follow through an unlit area of the caves, with a guide rope to see you through, however after a few steps in, just far enough to find the rope, I was too scared to go any further and we used the detour. You aren't obliged to go through the unlit section.We followed the arrows and came to the section with the history of Dracula. This was really interesting but you're then directed through a dead end series of ever decreasing arches with ever decreasing light, with some very tense mood music! I declined and sent my husband on ahead, I'm really not one for scary films and the atmosphere in here is fantastic in that it really draws you in. Once my husband had been to check it all out I followed him down to the end of the tunnel and saw for myself what was on display. Back up to the main tunnel and I was able to laugh and agree that it was indeed good fun.Back on the main tunnel pathway and then you're directed through what seems to be another dead end, the path is descending and the ceiling even more so and suddenly the floor is also wet. Again I didn't want to proceed so waited for my husband to check it out first. He came back and assured me that there was indeed a way through. At this point though, we were the only visitors, there were no more of the odd tableaux to distract us and I really started to feel the oppression of the meters of rock and buildings above us. I forced myself ahead.Almost full circle and there is a display about caves elsewhere in the world, be sure and read the one about South Africa!This was a great experience. I didn't like the mannequins, but the lighting and music deliver great tension in just the right places, it was a bit scary without being terrifying, but good fun. You'll need to put on a brave face if you take children with you though!There are toilets towards the end of the cave route.

Great experience, well worth a visit!. My partner and I visited this attraction in the evening, after 6 when all of the lights in the tunnels are turned off so you must guide yourself through with only a lantern (some people used their phones but what in the hell is the fun in that?!).It was pretty scary, but really enjoyable if you don't mind a bit of a fright! There are some mannequins and other bits along the way for you to stop and look at, and some plaques up with information about the Labyrinths, Dracula and the city at the time the tunnels were being used!It suggests that the tour takes about 30 minutes but we enjoyed it so much we were in there for about 50! Most definitely worth a visit if you like a thrill and if I remember correctly, priced at about 5000 forints for both of us.. It is well worth checking out!

Best part of Castle Hill. The Labyrinth is part of the Castle Hill complex, and well worth seeing. It is a fascinating combination of natural formations and man-made. It has been in use for centuries as a prison, torture chamber, and hospital. There are a number of displays set up. It can take quite a while to see it all, if you take the time to explore. Some of it is unlit, but there is a rope along the wall that you can follow. I used the flashlight on my phone to explore. There is a Dracula display there as well, as the historical Vlad was held prisoner there in the 1400's. This was definitely a highlight of my trip to Budapest! Highly recommended!

Underground dark, but great experience. When you enter the cameras need to adapt to temperature :)It is underground and humidity is very high. Labyrinth walk was great! We didn't really understand wax figures (there was explanation, but were to exited to stop and read).One area of labyrinth was in complete dark (not for everybody), bring some light with you (cellphone for example). Very cool!Dracula room is also the best.Would recommend it to everybody!

Nice labyrinth..not too long but still good spend time. Never been in labyrinths before and this was a nice experience. Dark, scary music, people talking but can't see them..was really nice and we not regrete the time we spent.

Fun, random art installations and a bit creepy. There were 4 seperate art installs, carved stone, Dracula torture, opera and a pictures of caves with music. My favourite Dracula tunnel and history boards as it is was fun creepy but still informative. It was 2500ft for an adult today and provided us with fun, laughter and information. What was missing was more history about the labyrinth, it's creation and uses over the years, also the toilets were not the cleanest.

A curious place to visit. The maze is under the Buda castle mountain. Lots of alleys that walk around. There's a part where you have the maze and you're completely in the dark. It's a nice experience. You can also read information about how Vlad the impaler (AKA Dracula) was imprisoned here and some other interesting stuff.

Great, bizarre ridiculously cheap, spend about an hour here. Simply great, first its quite cheap to get in but for some reason we only had to pay 1/4th of the original price for us all which was great. And then you are left on your own to explore. Normally you have to be in a group and you get a boring or rushed tour around, but this place is different you can go where you want and spend as long here as you want. You have to persevere through some creepy models dressed in old style clothes in scenes from some sort of opera but then there is a really fun and quite scary DARK MAZE. And at first I assumed this would only be scary for young children but boy it was scary for us adults. You have to find your way in pitch black thorugh parts of the cave and it seems to go on forever. Don't cheat and use a torch also ruins it for those who are already searching through the maze. At points there was a rope on the wall but the best way is to have your arms out ready to stop you walking into things. Once you exit the maze you feel an amazing sense of achievement. Then you get lots of information on the tales of Dracula and see his tomb. And you end with information on caves around the world which I have added to the Bucket list.

Entertaining attraction. Although it isn't the most exciting thing to do in Budapest, it can be an entertaining way to spend a few hours, especially on a rainy day. It would also be a fun thing to do to entertain young children. The models are a bit creepy but this adds to its quirky charm and the maze of darkness (pitch black tunnels, get your phone flash light out) was fun!

Too scary. We found this place whilst exploring the area behind the Fisherman's Bastion. I thought it would be similar to the Dungeon places in Britain but it's a maze of caves under the ground. The idea is that you go through a lot of it in pitch black holding on to a rope but this was simply terrifying. We tagged along with a group of young girls who were using their phone light to go round. It felt like it was impossible to get out of it and I totally regretted going in. Couldn't wait to escape. Definitely don't go if you are at all claustrophobic. I'm not and I hated it. We weren't charged admission on the day we went (don't know why) but normally there would be an admission charge

Bizarrely interesting!. If you are exploring Buda it is worth a look here. It's a bizarre network of tunnels and caves that has you walking in absolute pitch darkness for some time whilst holding a hand rail. Dracula's tomb was a highlight for us! For a couple of pounds it was an interesting hour spent.

Ruined trip. After reading on the internet that it closed in 2011 we were saddened by this as we wanted to visit, however finding out that it was still open was honestly the best feeling I've ever felt, we excitedly made our way to the labyrinth only to find it was shut before its closing time. We were completely devistated and were unable to get out of bed for the rest of the duration of our trip. Completely ruined Budapest for us.

Complete waste of time. The Dracula grave was a little fun but I have got news...I don't think he was ever here (Bram Stoker to confirm !). Maybe the kids might enjoy it, but from an adult point of view this is 30 minutes of my life I will never get back.

Odd but fun. If you're after some insight on the historical use of these caves, go somewhere else.If you just want to wander round some damp caves, see some bits of old masonry, and get some fun facts/fiction on Dracula, then come on in.I expected this to be a bit educational with historical facts about the use of the caves by smugglers or as prisons, maybe with some set scenes showing usage.Nothing like that at all.The first few spaces were filled with scenes from an opera, complete with long descriptions. I gave them a miss, thinking the historical bit would be just round the corner.It never arrived.There is a short area where you are invited to go through in pitch black with just a hand rail to guide you. That was fun. We didn't cheat and went round without turning on phones for a light source. If it hadn't been in a tourist attraction and therefore confident that nothing was going to hurt me, I would have been nervous. Then there's the fun facts about Dracula.It want a complete waste of time, but I won't be telling friends to rush to see this.

Brilliant. This was really surreal and creepy. If you don't like mouldy/damp smell don't go, but it adds to it. (Also steep stairs in and out).There was complete darkness in part of it to shuffle thru. We enjoyed it. Very different.

Free and unique. This was free when we went ( don't know why but it was after 6) we were given a paraffin light, took forty five minutes to go around. All pitch black and a bit odd but interesting all the same!!!

Unnerving, but fun!. My friend and I visited after seeing advertisements for the Labyrinth around Budapest. The connection with the historical Vlad the Impaler intrigued us, so we set off one afternoon to visit. The entrance is accessed by several long, very steep flights of stairs. To my knowledge, this was the only way in and out, making it difficult for small children or those with physical limitations to access.After debating and hesitation, we opted to pay the (rather high) fee and began wandering around. Their was Phantom-esque music playing, and the first few rooms were filled with characters from the Opera which was based on this infamous prison. (The name of the opera escapes me.) That part was a bit cheesy. Further on, things got eerier and quieter, (we were the only visitors at that time), and in one section, you had the option of advancing in total darkness through several rooms, guided only by a hand rail! (We opted to pull out our cellphone flashlights.) It was rather terrifying.
