Rooms further on were shrouded in (manmade) fog, with creepy music playing and some Dracula type decorations about.All in all, we enjoyed ourselves, and found it to be a bit more scary than anticipated. This makes for a good cold weather/rainy day activity. If you have people easily scared in your group, they may not enjoy it, nor would children, I think. Read up on the history beforehand, if you go. The informative signs were rather limited on the specifics about Vlad the Impaler.

Nothing interesting to see or do unless you absolutely just want to see what it is. It is just an underground cave, not even a labyrinth. The layout is a central circle with dead-ends leading away from the centre. When I and other tourists got there, all the artificial lights were on, and we were just following the arrows to go around the central circle. Then some staff appeared and hand over lamps, and hastily tried to go ahead of us and look for the switches of the lights with a torchlight in his hand. This was very confusing and it seems that they were very unprepared and disorganized. So, save your money and time unless you really need some time in a dark cool place wondering what you are doing on earth.

A bit freaky. Found this place on the off chance. The electric was partly down at the time which meant it was free and very dark! Found all the info on dracula interesting and must admit did get a bit freaked out walking though the dark tunnels alone. Worth a visit if you're in the area.

Interesting.... I read about this in my guide book and thought it sounded interesting... it was but there were far too many rocks (ruins) placed about the caves than anything else and I felt it was a bit sparse in content. It was a big gimmicky and lacking in much content. That said we had fun but wouldn't re visit.

Prison Cave of Dracula. This is a creepy place! Dracula was held prisoner here for 10 years. There are certain parts of the cave that are pitch dark so bring your cell phone for a little light or you will be feeling the walls and following sounds to get out. There are opera mannequins which I didn't understand at all. I don't know what they have to do with this cave but they looked totally out of place. The entrance to this labyrinth is not in the Buda Castle but on the street by the castle. It is not easy to find. We found it by accident but glad we went.

Meh. It could be so much better!We went there twice. The first time it was closed (with no information on the website or on the door). We came back the day after because I was very excited and wanted to go there at any cost. We went downstairs, we paid and we didn't know what to do. We followed the arrows. Nobody gave us lanterns, there were artificial lights. The wax models were odd, they were covered with dust and spider webs. I'm not sure why they were there... At first I thought that maybe they will move or do something to scary us but then they were there doing nothing. I don't like wax models, I think they're creepy :DWe definitely expected more. Not such a great experience as we thought it would be. It has nothing to do with Dracula.Sorry to say but it's a waste of time and money.

Spooky and well worth a visit!. We visited the underground tunnels and caves in Budapest during a short break. The atmosphere, music and information provided was excellent, though it was a bit difficult to find your way around to the things you wanted to see...part of the point though! There is a section with absolutely no light, which is signposted and well worth a spooky stumble! (It helps if you have a flashlight app on your mobile). I thoroughly recommend it!

Not open and no word of warning or any info. We visited this attraction on the day we spent on castle hill, this was one of the things we really wanted to do as I understand it is where Dracula was held prisoner. However unfortunately it was closed. There was no information on the website to say that it was or why it was and no sign outside. The doors were just closed. We relied on a Hungarian couple who shouted down through the open grate in the door and spoke to someone, to exlain to us that it was closed because they were having problems. But it would be open tomorrow. The following day it was raining and so we decided we would return. We paid the 1800 fr each for a return ticket on the funicular, went to the gate and it was closed again, with no sign of life. We shouted down, only to have a shirtless fat man appear and shout "closed" at us. so we had to leave again, what a complete waste of time and money. Very annoying and disappointing.

Waste of time. I am not sure what this was meant to be, but it came across as a big con job. It is basically just a series of tunnels with half baked 'tableaux' dotted around. These depict scenes from Verdi operas, using old costumes from the Budapest opera mounted on dummies. They even try to attach the tunnels to the Dracula legend with wall posters and a 'grave'. There is a blacked-out stretch called a maze, which is potentially dangerous as the rock floor is very uneven. If you like dark places, and maybe it is pouring outside, you may feel this worthwhile-we did not.

Not worth the visit!. This cost 2000huf which in comparison to other tourist attractions was a lot of money and certainly was not worth the money. The experience was confused as I'm still not sure if it was suppose to be a take on the London dungeons, a labyrinth or a museum to operatic costumes! Could be something really good but has not been very well thought through.

Most bizarre place I have been!!. This really is the weirdest place I have ever been!! I'm not even entirely sure what it is supposed to be even now. It has some opera scenes with Verdi playing in the background and lots of masonry on plinths. The Dracula bit is quite interesting and really creepy!! I both hated and loved it at the same time. So so odd but for the price I would definitely go again!! Hilarious!!.

An attraction for the senses. . Right, this place, was everything that you read about. If you are the sort of person who likes educational or culturally enriching experiences, this is not the attraction for you. My friend and I just laughed our way through it. It was a maze of opera stuff, a loose Dracula link, a dark maze, and masonry on plinths. The sure ridiculousness of the place is what made it for us. Bring a fully charged phone for a torch and leave educational expectations at the door.

sooooo eeire but really cool. I say excellent because this place was sooooo creepy and weird. but that made it cool. like nowhere I have ever been. it had like an aura about it I dunno. we did it randomly and it was def worth it. make sure your phone has charge to use your light cus you can barely see a foot in front of you with the light they give you

i am not sure why there are opera dolls in the labyrinth, however it was fun. it said that this is where Dracula was kept, I am not sure about this fact, however the place is fun. I am not sure why there was opera figures inside the cells, and if you can't read Hungarian you cannot understand because the english version of the explanation is not clear...seems like they used google translate for this purpose.

Random Fun Break from the Heat. I had read about this somewhere, but then when I looked it up online, the website said it was permanently closed. When we went to explore in Castle Hill, we found it. We happened to be in Budapest during a heat wave, so we were glad to find it open, as it’s underground and cool! I must say, if you’re looking for a state of the art experience, this isn’t for you. But if you have a sense of humor, a sense of adventure, and no fear of the dark, this is a great place for you. It is so random. There are wax figures, music, but no real description of what’s going on. There are dark pathways with no lighting, some with very little lighting. All of a sudden you start learning about Dracula. If you find a set of steps, go up them, because there’s a fun surprise of the movie Dracula playing. There are also restrooms here, but you have to make it through most of the labyrinth to get there. Honestly, because of who I was with, and the fact that we stumbled upon this, this was one of my favorite memories from Budapest. ☺
Fun experience. It's a fun activity, specially if you go with kids, alhough it's clearly a "tourist" atraction and the vampire thing is quite ridiculous.

A lot of fun. The Labirintus underneath Buda Castle Hill is a fascinating experience. This maze of tunnels and caves manages to combine some genuinely interesting history, a real extra sensory experience, some good old cornball by way of the link to the history of Dracula and some moth eaten mannequins representing vague historical facts. Just about everything you could hope for in one experience.The Labirintus is very old and has been used for everything from storage to shelter to dungeons. The adaptation over time of what was a natural cave system into an interlocking series of rooms and tunnels is fascinating.There is one lengthy winding section that has no lighting and you are encouraged to go through using only a rope tied to one wall as your guide. It's impossible to describe how dark it was being underground with no lighting. This was both terrifying and exhilarating. We talked about it for quite some time afterwards.There is some history here about the real Vlad the Impaler being imprisoned in the caves at one point, and this has been cheesed up with some corny fake heads on sticks, a false tomb and some eerie figures down passage ways.The less said about the mannequin displays the better.An enjoyable way to spend some time if you bring the right attitude along.

Fun way to fill an hour, on Castle Hill. We found this by accident and went inside, we were not disappointed! Fun and sometimes a bit scary way of seeing the labyrinth of dungeons where prisoners, and even Dracula, were kept centuries ago.

An interesting place but marred by strange additions. Make sure your phone has a flashlight app. You can get lost in it--at least for a little while.Maybe the curators of the Labirintus don't think a network of tunnels beneath Castle Hill is enough of a draw on its own. It's history as a natural cave formation, prison, military hospital, wine cellar, and harem is perhaps inadequate to pique interest, so the story of Dracula (a 12 year inhabitant of the prison) is used as a primary draw. Further, the initial part of the complex is piped with opera music and many chambers feature costumed figures with 19th century costumes. i never got the explanation for why... One chamber looked to be inhabited by aliens, another by holographic ghosts. Also...why? The story of Dracula takes over (covering myths vs. what is actually known) as he was a long term resident. At last we start to learn more about the history and geology of the complex. It ends with a photographic tour of other noteworthy caves around the world you might want to visit. We had a young child in our party that was scared by the music (pretty haunting in places) and the darkness.

A unique experience. The labyrinth is a subterranean museum/experience that is found within Castle Hill. There are exhibits from the Budapest opera, stone fragments and plinths scattered along the pathway, a section dedicated to Dracula, and a photo gallery of other world-famous cave systems. It is an interesting and unique experience, well lit - except for an OPTIONAL section that is pitch dark for those who want to experience that. The only downside is some areas there is water seepage, so it is damp, and musty smelling.

Do not go if you're claustrophobic . Not as good as the advertisements made out. The wax models were dirty and their clothes poor quality for the most part but that can be forgiven considering they are underground in natural caves. But it really didn't have anything to do with the caves. It was just an opera. Dracula's cave bit was fairly interesting just to know he was actually there but really there was very little to see and I just ended up feeling very trapped due to confusing directional signs. It was quite creepy though and after 6pm they do a walk with all the lights out guided by lanterns so I can imagine that would be fun if you wanted a good fright! Not worth the 1500HUF for the student entry though

Labirintus (Dracula PANOPTIKUM). The cave system of the Labyrinth is 10 to 15 metres below ground level. On a 1200-metre stretch. Real fun getting lost and scared in the dark !Mind your head at some points the roof is low. Take good shoes with you, some wet floors because water dripping from the rocks.Its really humid down there, I suggest to take a jacked with you its about 15°C in the cave.Took about 45 Min. to found the Exit.

Catacombes under Budapest. The Catacombes are situated just off the main square in the castle.Apart fro a welcome relief from a very hot summers day, the Myths surrounding Count Dracula are explained!If you have never been in absolute pitch darkness the caves provide this strange sensation. so take a walk along the passage ways and If you dare venture off into the darkness for a short walk in absolute darkness!
Creepy. Very atmospheric and creepy even if the wax models are a little cheesy. Walking through the tunnel of darkness very creepy.

Is different but very nice to visit!. If you are thinking in take a walk in Buda district, this is one of the museums you can visit. The museum is a group of natural tunnels used by Dracula, and there are a lot of informations that explained his history.

Weird, could be so much better. On a really hot summers day this does provide a welcome escape from the heat. However it was a strange place. The network of tunnels is interesting in itself but there exhibitions are strange. Yes opera did take place down here but the strange scenes taking place with wax dummies everywhere is a bit surreal. The dracula section is of interest. There is also one bit you can try and navigate in darkness, we failed

Lots of fun!. Was very excited to visit the Labyrinth! You get a real burning lantern to help guide your way through!The waxworks/dummies that you come across every so often are a bit random but I enjoyed making my way through in the pitch black!
Worth to visit. Exciting!. Great place for horror and opera lovers. I would recommend to visit a dark tunnel, it' s really thrilling. Mind your steps and be careful with your head.

Wait until 6!. After 6:00 pm they turn off all the lights in the labyrinth and give visitors good old fashioned gas lamps - VERY atmospheric. Take a small group and explore dark alleyways and learn about Dracula - this is one adventure we'll never forget! They close at 7:00 for entry though, but the hour we spent was well worth it!
Underground grotto. Weird statues from operas gone by. Walking around in the dark with an oil lamp. A Dracula room with shackles. Perfect for a rainy day.

Sort of strange (but cool on a really hot day). Not sure what we were expecting but the signs pulled us in. Undergound caves were life savers during wars (WW II comes to mind) and Germans often hid in such subterranean places. And this is a big one.The "tour" costs 2000 HUF per person (not a lot at any rate) and it will give the heat weary a nice quiet dark respite from outside and above. So here's the scoop: (1) it is Dracula-themed in places, (2) Verde Opera and lavish costumes on wax figurines occupy many of the "cells", and (3) there are 15th century masonry pieces on display. It is dark down here! Some areas are traversed in total darkness, save for the slightly sticky and gummy railing (hello, hand held sanitizer!) and there is a possibility for getting lost. At the end of the tour, you come to find out they do have monitors to check the area. Well, let us all hope they actually watch those.My impression: it is much cooler than upstairs in the sun, it is much darker, it is damp, there is the potential to get lost (as we did, from time to time), and it is a nice afternoon diversion.There won't be any brochures to take home and, as the cashier says, "everything is printed inside" and indeed it is. There is enough lighting to read (although dim). At some point in time (in the final analysis), Count Dracula was imprisoned down here and, while imprisoned, his wife commited suicide. I guess someone loved him. To our absolute delight, we did find our way (unaided, thankfully) up and out of the maze. It really is big. Historically, these caves go back a very long ways to pre-civilized times. It was a nice break, read about Vlad and then go see a recreation of the Verde Opera (music included) ad then go see relics of ancient stone cutters tools. Did I mention that this is a major underground cave? Like in stone, dripping, dark walls? Yup. But no creatures scurrying about. The sign says no photos but we did not see that until we exited the maze so I guess my photos are the first you will see? I'll bet not. And did I mention how awfully hot it was up there, outside? Humid up there, too. This refuge was well worth the price just for the relief.

A Bit Different - but Beware of Trip Hazards. There are so many beautiful things to see in Budapest so why not do something a bit different? Once we got past the very unfriendly cashier we enjoyed this. The first part has scenes from operas in waxworks which were quite good. I went through the totally dark piece alone (wife stayed with almost 4 year old in lit area) which I liked BUT at the end, the rope finishes and you walk towards the light. There is a large rock in the middle of the pathway which I didn't see and walked into. Ouch! The bit with the mist, mood music and Dracula's tomb was cool. Here the light is minimal and my wife tripped over a raised piece we couldn't see. There is an also an exhibition about caves which is quite good and I guess most people miss the little theatre up some stairs that you can watch opera in,Overall we rather enjoyed this - and nice to get out of the scorching heat for a while.

A surprisingly fun place for kids. This place took a little while to find, but it was fun for the children. It was also very cool here so was nice to escape the heat of the day outside. The underground passages are well lit (except for a section where you are supposed to walk through holding onto a rope in the pitch dark - which kids loved) and well marked out. It really is amazing how extensive this is!

A fascinating trip. Stunning place, really interesting. Very poor signposting so we nearly walked past but having seen similar attractions in other cities decided to take a look we were not disappointed

Nice cool place during a heat wave. The catacombs were an interesting experience with a lot of informatino on how the histtory has treated the people of Budapest. I quite didn´t understand all the dressed dolls in the rooms. Especially Dracula seems to be a little misplaced in Budapest......

1 pro, dozen cons. The good thing is that they have a scary part which is in complete darkness and you have to follow a rope on the wall to get out of the dark. It's very thrilling and that is the only interesting thing about Labirintus. The wax figures behind bars along the cave just don't make any sense. It could have been a beter use of space for something else, perhaps an escape game (which you should also try while in Budapest).

Interesting scary and fun experience. I didn't know there is a underground below old Budim where the count Vlad Tepes - better known as Dracula - was imprisoned and executed... Gothic music and atmosphere, little bit scary but fun and interesting experience, especially for my 11 years old son!
Interesting but not great . We definitely expected more. It was interesting short break from visiting monuments but not such as good experience.

Cool air, fun walk, a bit scary for little ones. This was a great break from the summer heat in the cool underground tunnels. The young kids were a bit scared of some parts but overall it is not a scay place and you can avoid the scary parts - a Dracula tunnel with fog and spooky music, and a dark maze with no lights through the tunnels. There are some wax sculptures of opera scenes but mostly the kids just liked going through the tunnels.

Cheese over history. The place has some authentic history to it, of which you'll find informative walls of text. Most of the old stuff inside is gone, however, with only some parts of stone objects scattered around the "labyrinth". The empty parts have been filled with fictional stuff like wax puppets, fake skeletons and a mock Dracula's tomb accompanied by fantasy music. Could appeal to families with kids but it didn't really feel worth it in the end to my friends. Oh, and don't touch the guide rope at the dark cave, it stinks.

Interesting experience, not for those with allergies/asthma. The Labyrinths is a fun and spooky attraction. But, if you suffer from mold allergies or have asthma, bring/take your meds first. Like some wet caves there is a moldy stuffy air to the place. It is quite cool so even in summer bring a light jacket if you tend to get cold. It is easily found by following the signs just down from Matthias Church. Guests journey down a few steep staircases to the final entrance. The journey back up the steps could be strenuous for some.

Spooky place. Found this place while wondering around in the Castle district. I wasn't expecting much, and by the entrance the theatre/opera scenes demonstrated by wax statues are ok. Once you pass them it gives you the feeling that you are actually under the castle and houses and this is a real old labirint. You find some very interesting information about Dracula who groow up here and that part is made a bit scary with smoky bits.The place doesn't have any fire/emergency exit as it is a real dungeon. It is very dark in some parts and although there are signs to direct you it took us quiet some times to find the exit.Good fun to have a break from buildings and other historical places.

A nice break from looking at gorgeous architecture all day :-). It was a scorcher of of a day and the cool of the labyrinth was a welcome change. The tunnels are interesting. The piped music added atmosphere. There is a section in total darkiness you get through by following a rope. And a dracula section complete with dry ice mist.....don't get lost ;-)A warning that this is not good for anyone with reduced vision.....my 83 year old father sat this one out. A good choice as it turned out.

Inside Budavári labirintus (labyrinth under Budapest). First of all, despite confusing information and websites stating that it is permanently closed, we went back to see it on 12th June 2015. After our previous attempt in October 2014 when it was closed indeed, this time we found it open. We walked down the steep and long steps deep under the castle hill and paid the entrance fee of 2000 forint each (approx. 7 Eur). This was my second visit, but still like it and find it amazing, even though some areas were closed off and didn't find the wine fountain. Still worth visiting the dark tunnels, carved rooms and interesting exhibitions deep under the cobbled streets of the Buda hills.
so much awesome. This was great, they have a lighted route, but you can go off this route. We went into the heavily fogged Dracula area and I was literally terrified.

Interesting and spooky. Atmospheric to walk around with spooky sections and moody lighting. It was well displayed with written information dotted around. There were several displays within the route with dressed up mannequins (some of which were not in good condition or clean) trying to depict the goings-on within the labyrinth during its main usage.

Don't read any more reviews and just visit!. As the title says, stop reading reviews of this place and just visit it. By chance, saw the adverts whilst up on castle hill. They seemed to suggest a London Dungeon type experience. Oh how we were wrong. So much more. Don't cheat and take a torch. Just immerse yourself and enjoy. Visited it today after paying 2000 huf with no knowledge of what to expect 5/5 for this place. Your mind goes into overdrive and does a lot of the work. If I had read reviews of what to expect before visiting then I would have given it 3/5. Therefore with this attraction, ignorance is king. You have been warned!!!!

very odd place. Visited as it looked like an interesting experience, hugely disappointed, don't waste your money. Lots of odd wax models relating to operas, bit bizarre and out of context. Odd area of dry ice around limited Dracula display. Signposting very lacking in places. Lots of bits of stone on plinths. Dark labyrinth OK.

Not worth the money. If I remember it wasn't very expensive maybe £5 equivalent but, it's just a an underground tunnel with strange statues in, I learnt very little from my first ten minutes along around, so much so that I then just continued to walk to the exit without stopping at other displays. I felt my time would have been better spent elsewhere

Great atmosphere after 6.00pm with paraffin lamps. Like other reviewers,, we were a little bemused by the opera figures.We can highly recommend the evening entry- between 6.00 to 7.00pm all lights are switched off, and you wander around with (very safe, enclosed) paraffin lamps.This greatly adds to atmosphere and makes it a fun and slightly scary experience, as you bump into other groups and surprise each other. The "total darkness" challenge where you follow a "rope" around also has good potential to scare each other.A lot of laughs were had.

AWESOME!. Amazing and wonderful exhibit. First start out with a walk into the underground labyrinth, exploring Verdi with the opera singing in the background. You must go on the maze which is a walk through complete darkness following a lifeline through the maze. Then visit the archeological findings from Buda Castle. Down to Draculas tomb, a very scary smoke-filled area with colored lights - very scary. And on the way out, a photo museum of the world's best caves. Really a one-of-a-kind tour and well worth the admission price.

A wonderful diversion. I enjoyed my hour or so in the labyrinth.It was a good diversion from all the hustle and bustle around Buda castle. I must say i get lost easily,so this was not the best place for me to visit. It was 32 outside and about 12 inside.So be prepared for the chill.I found if you didnt stray too far from the opera singers you would be ok.Very novel and worth a visit.

Great place if you have teenagers. We had a great time wondering through the underground labyrinth. Yes, there are moldy costumed wax museum people from scenes of an Opera...that does not appear to have anything to do with origin of the labyrinth...that made it all the creepier. I loved reading all the Dracula history...just to get you more creepier. There is a section that is completely dark...please don't ruin it for others by using your cell phone flashlight through the entire black out section(like the ones in there with my family). You can wait and not go into this section.There are a couple of maps to help you find you way out. It was a hoot!

A strange experience!. We were very disappointed with this attraction and couldn't understand what connection the opera costumes, which were interesting to see, had with the caves. The Dracula connection was also very tenuous. Signposting was confusing or non-existent. Definitely not worth the entry fee.

NOT CLOSED. Worth Visiting!. Although the top website on Google says this has been closed since 2011, it is still open. This is the actual website of the labyrinth that is still open. http://labirintusbudapest.hu/english.phpWe went for the night visit which I think made the experience all that much better. For the night visit they turn off all the lights and your group is given one lantern to guide you through the labyrinth. Night visiting hours start at 6pm and the last entrance is at 7pm. I haven't been when the lights are on, but I can only imagine it would not be as cool! Costs 2000 HUF for adults and it took us a little over an hour to walk through the labyrinth.

Avoid at all cost, unplesant, unsafe, insulting staff, please read.. Still extremely disturbed after the Labirintus experience.Not only because it was an extremely creepy and unplesant place, but because how rude the staff was, and unsafe the turistic operation is, that this peope are running.I, as part of a group of five people, went to visit this place after paying 2000 HUF per tourist.we started (no guide), after the staff gave us two petrol flame lights, and the advice, to "follow the arrows..." I challenge this people to present a valid emergency plan to get out of the building, quality of the air was terrible, an extremely unpleasant experience. By the time we manage to find the exit (not an easy task) there was'nt a single person at the entrance, we were left with the two flame lamps, all alone, and after going up the stairs, we have found a closed door. After we opened the door, to show our selfs the way out, a member of the staff appears from another closed door, insulting us, and after to trying to talk with this large man (I really thought he was joking) the insults just kept on going until he slammed the door in my face.Keep in mind that at this time there were (at least) one couple of tourists inside the "Labirintus" maze that we came across a few minutes earlier.Places like this should not exist, they just just give a terrible image of a such a beautiful country as Budapest.I'm more than welling to discuss this experience with someone in charge at "Labirintus" (feel free to email me at nqhorta@gmail.com) and not only to try my money back.Avoid at all cost.

Wonderful expereince!. If you have the time, do visit the caves called Labryinthi.Its in the castle district close to the St Mathias Church.The ticket pricing is little more than the other usual attractions but well worth it. My kids loved it!!
Gave me the creeps :). We visited Labirintus in the evening and we were the only people there along with one couple. That was spooky! Worth visiting if you like this kind of stuff!

A nice suprise!. This place seems like a horrible British spook show place but it was a nice surprise. Yes, there are wax dolls, but the are nice. The cave system is pretty big and has one section where you are in complete darkness for a few minutes. Nice place to scare your friends!

Interesting experience in Buda Castle. The Labirintus is a good experience. Learning about Dracula was awesome and scary at times as some of the caves were completely dark and there were a few creepy surprises along the way. The opera music and costumes threw me off a little but they were beautifully exhibited so I did not mind them too much.

Different experience. went there to see what the place was like. Surprised by the extent of the caves, and tunnels. The dark Room is a good experience, although some people turn their phone torches on to find their way. Better to just follow the rope as the guide. Must have been hard living down there. The story fo the imprisonment of Dracula ( count Vlad) is also interesting.

Spooky. Went there as my partner read a lot about the history of this place. It's a rather large labyrinth so to ensure you know where you are they have put Verdi's opera on. When you get to a point where the quote is from Dante's hell please think twice. I might be a scary cat, but what they don't tell you is that the blackened room is not a room. It's several rooms- it takes a good few minutes (it felt like 5 min to me, but again, I was scared). It's pitch dark and you follow a rope fixed to the wall. It's away fro the other rooms so it gets very quiet. The rooms had ventilation so you might feel a breez at the back of your neck. Very spooky - but be assured that there are no live actors at any point! Just remember, people lived there for an extensive period. - it's interesting

Too much like a cheap halloween experience. The concept of this was interesting, but the experience was somewhat ruined by all the things that had been added to the caves. Opera music was playing in the caves, with scenes from operas depicted by mannequins in various locations. I don't really understand why or what relevance this had. There was a large and rather silly section about dracula, in which a smoke machine had been used. Unfortunately with nowhere for the 'smoke' to escape, this made it an unpleasant environment to breathe in.The maze in the dark was quite fun and worth doing. It was also interesting to see stone artefacts around the caves - I would have liked to see more of this and learned about how the caves were used during history. The caves of the world section was also interesting.If you're after a scary experience this is one to do - you can even visit guided by an oil lamp after 6pm. If you're interested more in the history/formation of the caves it's not really worth the entry fee.

Exciting experience. This is something a little different. An exploration of the labyrinth underneath the castle. Creepy, interesting and compelling. It was a great way to spend time around the castle

A bit of fun. It was interesting to go down into the dark maze, with lots of funny, freaky mannequins, and added mist effect to make it more atmospheric. Just as you would imagine a maze of caves to be - dark and confusing.

Interesting...something to do once. There was a part that was all darkness and there was a rope on the side that can guide you along. That was kind of scary. Thank goodness for the flashlight feature on a smartphone :-). The labyrinth had arrows that you can follow but sometimes it leads you to a dead end. If you want to learn about Dracula, this is the place to go to. All in all, good fun for about 30 minutes.

Maybe worth a quick look. The labyrinths themselves are quite interesting, but it's a shame they're full of terrible mannequins and loud music. The maze in the dark was a highlight, apart from the people who can't stand to be in the dark for 5 minutes without the torch on their phone.It was hard to work out what was historical fact and what was touristy exaggeration. The exhibition of photos of caves from the world at the end was interesting, but be prepared to get dripped on!

Lots of fun. I had a great time running around down in the dark and reading about how the caves were used. The wax figures are a bit odd but make for an interesting visit. I'd recommend taking the "labyrinth" section where you walk in complete darkness with nothing but string to guide you; a bit spooky but good fun.

Weird but good, better than expected.. We found this place by accident when we were wandering around the castle area and decided to go in. Just wandering round the caves/cellars was quite interesting and as it was quiet when we were there it was pretty spooky walking around on our own. We went into the dark "enter at your own risk" area and ended up putting our torch on as our 10 year old got freaked out by the opera music which you could hear in the distance and the pitch darkness (I was quite happy to put our torch on mind you as total blackness was creeping me out too). There was nothing scary there really, just good old imagination in the darkness! The Dracula area was not very frightening and the information there was contradictory but we enjoyed the exhibition. I would recommend this as a little bit different when you have had enough of the more traditional castles and museums.

An excellent thing to do with children. I presume this is another name for the Labyrinth, located in the Castle Hill area. We spent an exciting 1.5 hours exploring the labyrinth. Even more excited to dicover that Dracula was buried there!

Spooky,dark,fun!!. On our visit to the castle we gave the cave a try. It is a dark humid labyrinth 15 meters below the ground. In the beginning there is enough light but it gets darker as you go on until you enter the chamber of darkness and your only guide is a rope against the wall.Many mannequins with costumes inside and the highlight dracula's coffin. avoid if you have breathing problems as it has 90% humidity.

Not really worth a visit. Looked much better in the leaflets and posters than it is in real life. There is not much down there, some wax models, some bits of building, a bit about vampires and a dark area where you're supposed to hold onto a rope to find your way, and some photos and information about other caves? I was scared at times because I am a huge wimp. However really it is not worth wasting your time and money,I'd recommend going somewhere else instead.
Awful. Really awful and creepy. Not worth it money, you should get paid to get in there. The only thing we regret doing in Budapest.
Its a waste of time. If you have once been in a cellar, you don´t need to visit the Labyrinth. Its really nothing special, just dark rooms and creepy wax dolls.

Spooky. It was a bit difficult to find. At first we thought it had shut down, as that is what it said on the internet. We managed to find, and went on the tour. It was very eery down there, but was good fun.There are plaques on the wall, which give some history of the place.Vlad the impaler was apparently kept captive there. He was married to the kings niece, and when rescued from the Turks, he was kept prisoner. I don't recall the reason.Definitely worth a visit.

Quirky, awesome and ridiculously terrifying. We LOVED the labyrinyh!!! It is weird and wonderful, hilarious and terrifying. Don't miss the dark bit or Vlads tomb and don't expect to be historically educated. Definately in my top 5 things to do in Budapest. Don't leave without going to this bonkers extravaganza. Just make sure your tongue is firmly in your cheek Enjoy =)

Creepy but fun!. Visited as we saw advertised. As you descend into the cave there are many opera costumes and music for you to view. Then brace yourselves as you walk through the pitch black cave with only a rope to guide you!!! I must admit as this was were drakula was inprisoned I was freaked out. You can't see anything and can here water dripping from above. You can't tell whether or not the cave is getting smaller. If you are clostrophobic I wouldn't recommend. You can miss this section out if you don't wish to venture in. The drakula section was eery but good fun and all guests were scaring eachother which was a laugh!!! Excellent and interesting! One of the best museums in Budapest. I can imagine if you were in a group you could have some great fun!!!

Weird and cheesy...but fun. I have no idea if there is any truth to their claim that Dracula was actually imprisoned there, but the cave complex is fun to walk around in, and its extra fun to imagine that he might have been a prisoner there. The pumped in mist and colored lights adds a little cheese factor, but so be it. A few artifacts are scattered around, along with some nearly pitch black sections (which you can skip if darkness is not your thing).Although there is a long flight of stairs to get down to it (if you are coming from the castle complex) once down the cave itself is stroller friendly, mostly flat with a few low ramps.

Creepy, but good to see. i made the mistake of visiting this during off-season on a rainy day in the morning. Needless to say, I was the only one in the labyrinths. That made it extra creepy! You should go when lots of people are there. The highlight is the fact that Vlad the Impaler (Dracula) was kept there for a time. They really spook that area up. It's also cool to just walk through these underground areas. It is located in the Castle Hill area and is something you could do if you are up there. It took me about 20 minutes to see the whole thing.I'm a teacher too and I got a discount ticket. Bring your ID teachers!

Good fun. Not a maze that you have to find your way out of but a pathway through the caves. Still it was good fun and the lighting and music made for some very eerie moments! There is the option to go though the cave of darkness but I opted for the lit arrowed pathway! I imagine it is a bit of fun to do it in the dark but I scare far too easily! There is an expedition on Dracula down there which adds to the creepy vibe. English language plaques on the wall give lots of information about Dracula and his imprisonment in the caves. Interesting way to spend an hour.

Strange but amusing. This is definitely not what I was expecting when we went down to explore the Labyrinth! It had to be the single strangest experience of our entire 2 week trip around Europe. It was a total hodgepodge of things. When you first go down, there are wax figures in fancy outfits and opera music playing. Although there was some signage trying to explain what was happening, it was really unclear what the purpose of having this down there was. Then you go through this "tunnel of darkness" where it's pitch black and you hold onto a rope to find your way through. Despite a sign basically saying "go at your own risk" and "you may meet yourself in the darkness, never return, etc," there were no scary surprises along the way. There is also some info and legends regarding Dracula (accompanied by creepy music of children going "lalalalala" and some heads on stakes). Then there is random architectural and archaeological info (lots of rock like objects). Although the labyrinth rooms and walking through itself is neat, I would have appreciated some more history (i.e. a more informative, less bizarre experience). Overall, very strange but at least we got a lot of laughs out of it!

Quattro giorni a Budapest. "Budapest " Una bellissima città.Abbiamo avuto Eva come guida una persona molto preparata e molto gentile. Abbiamo trascorso delle belle ore insieme. Grazie Eva per la tua gentilezza

fantastica budapest. abbiamo avuto il piacere di avere Eva come nostra guida privata durante la nostra permanenza a Budapest. siamo rimasti incantati dalla bellezza della vostra città e dall affascinante storia che la circonda. ottimo servizio e guida molto preparata!!

Budapest con Eva. Abbiamo passato un ottima mattinata in compagnia di Eva che con il walking tour ci ha fatto visitare sia le belezze di Pest ( opera-piazza degli eroi-storia della corona ungherese...ci ha addirittura aiutato ad acquistare i biglietti in Parlamento) sia quelle di Buda...dai bastioni dei pescatori alla chiesa di Mattia, alle varie chiese che di li si vedevano...ci ha anche dato la ricetta del vero goulash. Persona qualificata e gentile Eva e' veramente molto appassionata del suo lavoro e trasmette la sua passione in maniera ammirevole....consigliatissimo!

VISITA PIACEVOLE CON UNA GUIDA MOLTO PROFESSIONALE. Grazie Eva, per la bellissima giornata trascorsa insieme. Ho potuto apprezzare la competenza e la flessibiltà di una guida davvero gentile e competente che ha saputo personalizzare il giro sulle mie esigenze. Ho potuto apprezzare la città che è meravigliosa e qualche tocco in più di cultura ungherese. Consiglio senza riserve

Bellissima Budapest. Bellissima Budapest, anche con l'aiuto della "nostra" guida Adam...Veramente una magnifica sorpresa... anche in poco tempo abbiamo visitato il meglio della città... spero di tornare.

Budapest nel cuore. Il simpatico Adam ha accompagnato noi, una banda di sbandati, alla scoperta di una favolosa città.Eravamo un gruppo eterogeneo, da ragazzini a persone più adulte ma la nostra guida ha saputo coinvolgere tutti con la sua simpatia, la sua intelligenza e la sua enorme cultura. Ci ha raccontato la storia della sua città, ci ha spiegato la sua lingua e cercato di insegnare alcune parole per noi impronunciabili, ha cantato per noi e si è gentilmente offerto di scattarci delle foto di gruppo.Bellissima esperienza! Grazie Adam da parte della Banda Musicale città di Staffolo.
Gita scolastica meravigliosa , grazie Adam!. Gita scolastica a Budapest di 3 giorni con la guida più brava ! Adam ci ha regalato delle bellissime giornate, bravissimo e grazie ancora!

bellissima città e fantastico Adam. sono arrivata a Budapest un pò diffidente e invece ho scoperto una città meravigliosa, affascinante e vivissima. Ad accompagnare il nostro gruppo in giro per 4 giorni c'è stato Adam...BRAVISSIMO! completamente diverso dalla "guida" classica...appassionato del suo lavoro e della sua città, ci ha raccontato tantissime cose e fatto scoprire tanti angoli e risvolti di Budapest. GRAZIE ADAM! Sicuramente tornerò e certamente ti chiamerò!!

ADAM BOTTA "UNA GUIDA CON UNA MARCIA IN PIU'". siamo da poco tornati da budapest la bellezza della città è indiscutibile, conoscerne la storia e tutt'altra cosa sopratutto se si ha la fortuna e il piacere di conoscere persone colte , preparate e appassionate come la nostra guida italiana adam botta . incontrare adam e' stato un piacere parla benissimo l' italiano ha una grande professionalità' è gentile ,garbato disponibile con lui ci siamo tuffati nella storia ungherese con travolgente passione,intrecciandola anche con la nostra storia italiana. non sono mancati confronti e paragoni Ho gradito particolarmente la sua esposizione storica iniziando da piazza degli eroi come ho trovato piacevolissimo il filmato a fumetti in 3d sulla storia dell' ungheria . grazie adam per tutto cio che ci hai trasmesso da. carla, rino mario, tina, mimmo e vanna

"COMPLIMENTI ADAM". Il mio gruppo formato da 26 persone mi prega di congratularmi com ADAM il quale, oltre ad esserre una guida che sa far apprezzare le meraviglie di Budapest, è una persona molto valida sotto tutti gli aspetti. Per quanto mi riguarda non posso che ringraziarlo e complimentarmi per come sa gestire anche gruppi eterogenei come il mio.Leonardo
Visita Budapest.                                                 città stupenda e Adam perfetta guida e simpatico AMICO!!! tre giorni bellissimi da rifare, contattando ovviamente ADAM!!!

Adam una guida eccezionale. Sono stata in vacanza a Budapest ho avuto come guida Adam Botta, una guida molto professionale , gentile , molto disponibile, lo consiglio a tutti , un ragazzo serio e competente , parla benissimo italiano

Budapest ancora più interessante con Adam. Insieme a 9 colleghi, abbiamo organizzato un viaggetto "fai da noi" a Budapest. Senza avvalerci di una agenzia di viaggi, ci siamo prenotati tutti i servizi dall'Italia sfruttando i consigli di internet ed in particolare Tripadvisor.Abbiamo deciso di prendere come guida locale parlante italiano "Adam Botta" che Trip advisor decantava molto dalle recensioni. Insomma l'attesa era alta ma il mitico Adam è riuscito ad alzare l'asticella della nostra aspettativa rendendo la città di Budapest ancora più bella ed interessante pur avendo utilizzato solo mezzi pubblici come da nostra richiesta. Insomma caldeggio vivamente Adam che oltre ad essere una guida preparatissima, umanamente è una bravissima persona sempre attenta alle esigenze del suo gruppo.

Molto più di una guida. Ho avuto il piacere di avere Adam Botta come guida durante il mio viaggio a Budapest, è veramente bravo e coinvolgente, racconta la storia della sua città con passione e condisce il tutto con aneddoti di vita vissuta, da lui e dalla sua famiglia, veri archivi storici viventi. Molto gentile e disponibile, ma anche simpatico e divertente. Non c'è che dire, un'ottima guida dal tocco "personale".

Competente, gentile e disponibile. Ho avuto il piacere di avere Adam Botta, quale guida nella mia vacanza trascorsa a Budapest.Adam è stato molto competente, gentile e disponibile e ci ha portato in giro (anche fuori dai circuiti turistici) facendoci assaporare il vero sapore della città.Persona culturalmente preparata e con un'ottima conoscenza della lingua italiana, si è dimostrato puntuale e preciso ad ogni nostra richiesta di informazioni.Lo consiglio a chi vuole una guida seria e competente!

Una guida importante per una città fantastica.. ....non ci sono parole per descrivere Adam Botta! Una persona fantastica, una guida esperta ed instancabile. Abbiamo trascorso una giornata piacevolissima in sua compagnia apprendendo cose, su questa fantastica città, che non avremmo neppure lontanamente immaginato, visitandola da soli.Oltre ciò, resta in fatto di aver incontrato, in una città nuova per tutto il nostro gruppo, non una fredda guida, ma un amico vero.Grazie Adam.

VIAGGIO  A BUDAPEST. “Italiano a Budapest”Dobbiamo ringraziare Adam per averci introdotto nel miglior modo possibile la nostra breve visita a Budapest. Con il nostro gruppo di 12 persone avevamo programmato una visita guidata per 4 ore ma, vista la ricchezza di informazioni e l'interesse suscitato dalla nostra guida, il tour è stato prolungato di altre 2 ore . La cosa che ci ha colpito maggiormente è stata l'appassionata spiegazione della storia e del carattere del popolo magiaro, presentataci da Adam di fronte la maestosa Piazza degli Eroi. Il tutto, ci ha dato una chiave di lettura interessante della città anche quando, nei giorni successivi, abbiamo girato Budapest da soli.Adam, in un italiano perfetto, ci ha anche fornito inoltre utili notizie per l'uso dei mezzi di trasporto, luoghi da visitare e ristoranti dove apprezzare la cucina e la musica tradizionale Ungherese. Consigliamo vivamente questa agenzia.

Budapest. >“budapest - una guida indispensabile”abbiamo visitato Budapest. Adam lo abbiamo contattato facilmente grazie al numero recuperato all'agenzia turistia vicino a Deak Fèrenc Tèr. Ci ha accompagnato per una intera giornata illustrandoci la città, ma accompagnando le spiegazioni con calore e partecipazione personale. E' innamorato della sua terra, la conosce alla perfezione non solo nei luoghi, ma nei costumi, abitudini, curiosità della vita di tutti i giorni e ti comunica questa passione quando ti racconta storie, curiosità, eventi. Ottimo l'italiano e quindi ottima la sua compagnia che definirei quasi amicizia, empatia. Tornassi a Budapest lo cercherei di nuovo per ascoltare ancora qualcuna delle mille storie della città e dell'Ungheria.Di passaggio a Luglio 2015 ho ancora usufruito delle indicazioni edei consigli ricevuti daAdam 3 anni fa. Erano ancora valide.

“Pasqua a Budapest”. Ho soggiornato a Budapest durante le vacanze di Pasqua insieme alla mia famiglia e, consigliato da amici, avevo prenotato Adam come guida; devo dire che la scelta è stata assolutamente azzeccata. Professionalità, cortesia amore per il proprio lavoro fanno di questo "Gigante Buono" una persona davvero "speciale". Ho visitato la città in lungo ed in largo in posti che forse nemmeno gli abitanti del posto conoscono, ho mangiato in ristoranti consigliati da Adam davvero eccellenti e ad un prezzo onestissimo....che dire per me consigliatissimo!!!!!! Visitato ad aprile 2015

Due giorni con Adam. Appena tornati da Budapest.Abbiamo avuto Adam come guida per due giorni .Preparato, paziente ( avevamo 3 bambini ), con un italiano fluente, appassionato del suo lavoro, della sua città, grazie a lui ci siamo avvicinati e fatti avvolgere da Budapest.Consiglio Adam a tutti come riferimento in questa città.

Miglior guida in assoluto. Da premettere che noi viaggiamo molto ed ogni volta prendiamo una guida in italiano per un giorno - Miglior guida turistica in Italiano a Budapest! Abbiamo conosciuto Adam l'anno scorso durante una vacanza con la nostra scuola d'inglese. Adam ci ha portato e spiegato tutte le attrazioni principali di Budapest ed è stata una giornata indimenticabile! Professionale, gentile e simpatico...non si può chiedere altro!

Capodanno a Budapest . Adam é molto gentile e ci ha portati in giro con molto entusiasmo, passare delle ore con lui ci ha permesso di conoscere la storia della città e molte curiosità. Lo consiglio perché guardare le varie attrazioni o semplicemente passeggiare per le strade con la compagnia di un ungherese colto e disponibile é tutta un' altra cosa rispetto a farlo con una lonely planet alla mano.

La migliore guida di Budapest. Adam è una persona veramente competente, sensibile ed appassionata ella propria città. Con estrema gentilezza e disponibilità vi accompagnerà attraverso le maggiori attrazioni di Budapest utilizzando autobus, metro e funicolare, insegnandovi ad orientarvi anche da soli una volta che il tour sarà finito. La città in breve tempo non avrà più segreti non solo nei suoi dettagli artistici, ma anche nella sua storia, che è molto interessante ed indispensabile per comprendere molto di tutto quello che andrete a vedere. Oltre a tanti aneddoti, segreti e storie, Adam conosce indirizzi e trucchetti molto utili per un turista che visita per la prima volta Budapest. Noi ci siamo trovati molto bene e certamente lo richiameremo se dovessimo tornare. Grazie Adam, a presto!

“Splendida passeggiata all'interno di Budapest!”

. Siamo stati accompagnati per un tour a piedi della città dal responsabile Adam Botta che ci ha fatto conoscere ed apprezzare moltissimo di questa magnifica capitale europea.Consigliamo a chi ha intenzione di apprezzare davvero la città di contattare questa guida che ha suscitato in noi passione per la città ed i posti visitati (moltissimi a dire la verità). Quando si lavora con passione e con dedizione si nota e lo si trasmette anche agli altri.Consigliatissimo!

Perfetta guida in tutto!!!. La casa del terrore a Budapest offre solo audio-guida in inglese. Su tripdvisor ho sentito parlare molto bene di Adam Botta e l'ho contattato tramite e-mail per accompagnare me e la mia famiglia nella visita della Casa del terrore. Serio, professionale e disponibile già dalla prenotazione mi ha fatto un'ottima impressione. Puntualissimo, durante il tour ha curato tutti i dettagli e soddisfatto tutte le nostre esigenze, è una persona oltretutto preparatissima culturalmente ma molto a modo, gentile, si vede che nel suo lavoro ci mette l'anima..ci siamo appassionati a tutto ciò che ci diceva e l'abbiamo seguito con molta attenzione visto che la sua visita guidata era molto interessante.E' andato oltre accompagnandoci al centro commerciale ed offrendosi come interprete con la commessa di un negozio.Grazie AdamVe lo consiglio ampiamente perchè credo non possiate trovare di meglio siamo stati di gran lunga contenti e soddisfatti...Convenientissimo il prezzo.

Viaggio a Budapest. Ho visitato Budapest nell'aprile del 2015 con l'ausilio di un'ottima guida, parlante italiano, disponibile, puntuale, preparato e simpaticissimo di none ADam. Quando tornerò in questa stupenda città, mi rivolgerò certamente a lui. Lo consiglio vivamente a tutti i navigatori di tripadvisor.

“Guida eccellente”. Ho conosciuto Adam 18 anni fa, non faceva la guida, ma ha sempre avuto questa passione nel DNA e finalmente ha realizzato il suo sogno.Tutte le volte che torno a Budapest lo contatto, perchè ha sempre qualcosa di nuovo da farmi scoprire.Lo consiglio a tutti, perchè parla un ottimo Italiano ed è pieno di risorse, vi farà conoscere la meravigliosa Budapest come nessun altro può fare.BRAVO!!!!!!!

Ottimo locale e piatti ungheresi di livello. non cercavamo assolutamente un ristorante con cucina Italiana ma il locale si persenta molto bene , tavoli eleganti,bella veranda al caldo e siamo entrati ...tutto viene preparato al momento sia carne che pesce , petto d'oca con verdure grigliate ottimo ( no italiano ) .....ravioloni al sugo stupendi...birra di livello , servizio IMPECCABILE con anche bellissime e professionali ragazze...il prezzo???? per tyre persone tot.euro 60....a Roma pizza x tre......ANDATE

Alla scoperta di Budapest. Abbiamo organizzato con largo anticipo la visita di questa città, splendida ed intrigante, che riesce a fondere la maestosità e la suggestione di un passato imperiale con una storia recente alquanto travagliata, per presentarsi come un naturale elemento di raccordo tra est e ovest europeo. E’ stata un’esperienza unica, e di questo dobbiamo ringraziare anche la nostra guida, Adam, che ha saputo portarci a spasso con competenza e simpatia tra luoghi, tempi e suggestioni. Grazie Adam. (Salvatore - Napoli)
Weird. If this is the underground beneath the church and castle, then it is fairly spooky. We walked through and it can really creep you out depending.
So fun! Professionally run . Would highly recommend this was extremely fun and great value for money. Felt in safe hands the whole time and will definitely remember this in 20 years time !

Best experience in budapest . The guide was so knowledgeable and has been guiding for 16 years. Its very intense but luckily the tour can be tailored to the difficulty level of the group. At one point we had to army crawl and tilt our heads to the side to fit through the space. Definitely not for anyone with a remote fear of small spaces. The big rooms are amazing to see though. The site is easily accessible, with the guide meeting you in pest at the bus station and taking you to the facilities. Transportation to and from the cave is not included. You will need 2 tickets. A must do! Great value too at only €20
Do Something Different . Had an amazing experience, it was difficult enough that you felt as if you accomplished something. The guide was awesome and it was a good group of people.

One of the two was in hungarian.. We had one rainy day, and decided to visit some caves on the Buda side. We had some trouble finding the right busses to get there. When we arrived we put signed ourselves up for the two caves. The first cave was an tour in hungarian. They gave us a paper where some english information told us about the different 'rooms'. When you are afraid of heights (like i am): there is an 7meters small iron ladder you have to take. Good luck with that!The second cave was my favourite. The guide was really nice. She did the tour in hungarian, but translated it also in English. Nice rooms with stones that look like flowers. Loved it! Best way to spend a rainy day!
Good and fun experience with good guides.. Good and fun experience with good guides. We did a moderate challenging tour with plenty of crawling through narrow passes.

Awesome adventure . Awesome and informative guide. We really enjoyed the experience, though I did not find it to be a challenging as others had suggested. Would be great if gum boots/wellies were provided as your shoes are very dirty by the end.

Worthwhile adventure. Absolutely worthwhile thing to visit! It might seem to be a bit expensive, but it's worth that money! We were crawling, we were singing and what even more interesting we felt fear and overcame it. Our guide was brilliant and made no efforts to turn caving into real adventure!

Experience Of A Lifetime!. When I was planning my trip to Hungary, nowhere did I read about Caving or even remotely heard about it. Somehow the folks at my hostel recommended it and I thought it was perfect for a rainy afternoon. But the experience was nothing like I had imagined. One, I was actually 50 metres under the city and spent 3.5 out of 4 hours on my fours! Two, I met some fabulous bunch of people who by the end of it had created a weird connection. Listening to your guide is very crucial, and make sure you stick with the group. The caves are not the usual limestone caves and hence very rustic and dusty. While they give you a jumpsuit and helmet to wear, make sure you reach for this one in strong sports shoes. Must do bucket list activity for the adventure seekers!

Amazing adventure. It's a great experience for those who like adventure. Not recommended for claustrophobic or overweight people though. The guide was very experient and careful with the group. He expleined a lot about the caves and helped us passing through the narrow corridors. They provide us lantern and clothes. It was one of the highlights of my trip.
Loved it. Excellent, challenging, lots of fun and educational. Loved every minute of it.....something different

Great experience!. This tour is awesome. Sometimes it is a bit challenging, with tight holes and slippery surfaces, but it is great. The guide was funny and always there for help and advises. We were a small group of 7 people from all over the world and we had a lot of fun together. Thumbs up!

Perfect Adventure!. I had an excellent time at Caving Under Budapest. I wasn't sure what to expect when I first booked it, but it was a very active three hours underground. With the help of our lovely guide I wedged and shimmied my way through holes that I thought were far too small to fit a human being! I would highly recommend this as a first caving experience for those who are not claustrophobic or scared of the dark.

Amazing experience. . We went expecting a normal caving experience but had a real adventure sliding down holes and crawling through narrow spaces. Amazing guide and really tolerant of the more awkward guests. The tour was adapted to our fitness level and enjoyment. It was great. Totally recommend. But your shoes will get VERY dusty. Also only need a tshirt as even though it is 10 degrees down there you are getting hot pushing yourself through the tight gaps. And you have the overalls on.

Awesome Morning Adventure . So worth the money. This tour was a blast. Our tour guides name was Edith and she was awesome! I would 100% recommend waiting/trying to go on the adventure tour with her - even if you don't like crawling, you'll be on the floor bc she's laugh out loud funny.

So much fun!!!. This was so much fun and definitely the highlight of my Budapest trip so far. There were 9 of us caving today and I was the only one who came solo (there was a group of friends and a couple). Nevertheless the teamwork nature of caving made it less lonely and the guide always made me feel included. The guide was really funny and knowledgeable about the caves. The caving tour involved a lot of crawling through small holes and gaps (although none of it was too difficult) and she helped us through it by giving us suggestions about where to step and how to position our bodies. I would totally recommend this for anyone visiting Budapest!!
Amazing. Not too difficult to find, everyone was around the same experience level (low) and we all had an amazing time.

It's interesting.. the guide was very friendly but the whole tour was basically fanfiction and the only interesting part was when he shut down the lights and it was so dark and so silent. favourite part definitely.
Strenuous - you will sweat but sense of achievment. Bus not that frequent so allow time. There are lockers to put your things. It is cold down there but light clothes only as you are doing exercise.

3 hour adventure tour. I took the 3 hour adventure experience of the caves. It was 7000 forints. There are other smaller caves (45 minutes, with easier walking routes, even wheelchair access). I didn't go to those.This one included crawling through some really thigh spots, some climbing, an awesome guide, Leslie, that was cracking jokes all the time and memorised our names within minutes. It was my first caving experience, so I have no ground to compare, but definitely loved it!! Highly recommend!

Not many cities have an attraction like this!. Take a guided tour of the extensive network of caves under the Buda hills. You will not be disappointed by this 'cool' place to visit, especially when the temperature above ground gets too much.

Everyone needs to do this!!!. Honestly one of our favorite experiences of the Europe trip so far. Something everyone should see/ participate in if they visit Budapest. I am a little claustrophobic so was very scared at first but the instructor was extremely helpful and the whole group cheers you on so you can get through anything! We did the more adventurous tour and were really put into some tight places that required you to literally slide on your stomach. At first you think you can't do it but you feel like the team is helping you out and you get through it!! Totally recommended to anyone

throughly enjoyable. 3 of us have just finished a 3 hr caving experience. It starts by getting a helmet and light. Then its on with the overalls. These are big, red and tough. The excitement starts then. The caving involved some crawling on belly, but not too much. I'm 50 and my 2 early 20s children all coped well. Getting there is a bit of an effort but well worth the effort. The guide was funny, thoughtful and considerate. Impressively, he remembered everyones name almost instantly. The group had about 10 people. We always felt safe.

What an experience. This 3 hour long caving experience is amazing.The guide is fun and gave us good insights on caves and caving.Don't be afraid of crawling, climbing and sliding and get ready to get knee bruises. But what an experience! I would definitively recommand this for adventurers

Must do for people who love adventure. We did this caving tour last month in Budapest....I would say it was the highlight of our trip to Budapest ! My daughters aged 8 and 11 and also did it and throughly enjoyed it. Well yes at certain areas it did seem very difficult and tough....but then the guide was too good ! Made all of us feel very confident.....A must do if you like adventure !

PROBABLY THE BEST THING I DID IN BUDAPEST. I think like myself your visit to Budapest will be filled with walking, sightseeing, eating and drinking... Now all of these things are great but it can get a bit repetitive and you might be looking for something to break it up. Well let me introduce to you to caving!! The trip involves a 2-3 hour excursion deep underground where you get to explore the depths of some ridiculously interesting caves. One of their awesome guides will direct you though the winding maze where you will squeeze through body sized gaps or enter large open rooms. It's a lot of fun, it's active and it's a little different. I also met an amazing bunch of people who were in my tour group. My only negative is that they do not provide transport to the site. You have to take 2 buses and then walk 5 mins. I wouldn't have minded paying slightly more to have a mini bus take us up to the site. Anyway if you have a spare half day in Budapest I would 100% recommend this!

Loved it!. I'm really glad my husband talked me into this; we really enjoyed caving! The place was easy to find (we came by bus) and our guide was very professional and friendly from the beginning and made us feel safe. We were a group of eight and were all quite young and in good shape so he made us crawl and climb a lot. We could often choose if we wanted to take the easier or the harder route, but none of us wanted the easy way! You're probably gonna have some bruises too, but it's worth it. Not for claustrophobics :)

Incredibly fun and a bit scary . Incredibly fun activity for groups of friends, but probably not for young children or the elderly. They provide most of the gear you need, but do double check and pack sensibly. Most of the caving is fairly suitable for beginners, but people with claustrophobia should beware because there is one spot where the tunnel is very very narrow and you have to wriggle on your belly for about 20 meters. People with height phobia should also note that right at the start you have to climb down a pretty high ladder

Wonderful experience. We loved our caving experience. We were in a group of about 8 and everyone was very friendly. Our tour guide was very knowledgable, experienced and fun.The tour we took was very physically demanding. Lots of small holes and gaps to climb through but I am so glad that we booked and that we took the more extreme route around the cave. An excellent experience.

Awesome experience . This was a great way to spend a morning. Like a lot of tourists our time has mostly been spent in Pest so it was great to see more of Buda. The guide was very funny and made the trip interesting, challenging and fun!We stupidly missed our original booking time and the swapped us on to the next available tour no problem - much appreciated :) Meeting could have been a little more organised - a mini bus rather than shepherding 14 people onto two public buses at rush hour! Thanks to everyone there!

No words to descripe. We went caving for the first time in 2014 and it was just an amazing experience. We still think about at least monthly, so many great many memories for such a small amount of money. It was just thrilling. But at the same time we felt safe in the hands of an experienced guide - even though my fiancé got stuck in one of the "holes"! So that really can happen if you have wide shoulders or hips but not to worry, the guide gave very good verbal instructions and kept us calm and with a little bit of pushing he was free and able to laugh at the absurdess of getting stuck underneath so and so much stone. Please, if you are ever in Budapest, try this experience! You might even want to make a detour for this, it was maybe one of my best travel experiences ever. But, you do need to be fit and somewhat brave to be able to enjoy it.

Wonderful experience!. Definitely one of the highlights of our Europe trip! Visiting the caves was such a cool experience and we had the most wonderful guide, Szilárd, who made the experience that much more amazing. He was so knowledgable and incredibly helpful throughout. I was really impressed with him and the overall experience. I would definitely recommend this excursion to anyone visiting Budapest!

Wonderful First Caving Experience. Our guide was a nice lady named Edith that met us at the Nyugati station at the bus stop with bus number 26 and 126 (might be a little harder to find if you are not familiar with the area. Its beside the West End mall and beside a carpark) Had to get either a bus day pass or 4 single trip tickets because we had to take a bus to the outlying areas of Buda. You need to get this independently and will likely not be provided by the tour company. Took about 45-60 mins to get to the destination. Coveralls and helmets with lights are provided and are REALLY important, so get one that fits well and works. [For those that don't know, caves are really dark really silent places] Edith was a great guide, constantly counting heads and making jokes with us. We all felt safe with her as she knew the routes well and chose the route that was most suitable for our group. I.e. she picked a route that was exciting and challenging for us but not ones that were too tight and might have caused us to get stuck. It really was a wondrous experience for us caving virgins. Admittedly it was not a spectacular cave like the mammoth cave or the cave with crystals in mexico, but for a new person, this was well suited for us. 2.5 hours of trekking 50m under the ground was awesome. Its cold underground, about 10-14 degrees, but don't wear thick clothes. the exertion and the coveralls are enough to get me sweating even though I was wearing T-shirt and shorts. A warning, the caves are not for the claustrophobic or those that are highly averse to dust or mud, or those with weak ankles. It is dusty in the dry parts of the cave and muddy and slippery in the wet areas, and generally uneven flooring all around. Wear a reasonable pair of shoes with good soles that you are willing to get dirty. I made the mistake of using a dirty worn old pair of sneakers and it felt like i was ice skating on the slippery parts haha. I would definitely recommend this for those that are new to caving and are looking for some excitement in Budapest. :)

Caving Experience. Our caving experience was fabulous. Our guide Silad inspired us to complete the cave trek which initially seemed so difficult. We sang songs, learnt Hungarian language with him. Overall it was fabulously organized.

Very cool experience. This is a functioning church and it is absolutely beautiful. It was located right by our hotel so it was one of the first attractions we did. It even had a Polish dedication site <3 This attraction offers headsets in various languages so you can tour at your leisure. I think we spent 30-40 minutes at this attraction.

Mind blowing experience. Budapest like Marmite-you either do or you don't, fantastic place with something to 'discover' up each and every road-miss it all and you are deny yourself a unique experience.
Excelent!. Excelent adventure! Extremely recomended for those who want be part of caver team. The best cave system I have ever seen!

Fun, unique and exciting - go there!!!. It's a great experience, challenging but not that difficult and you will surely remember that for a long time. Our guide (Edith i think) was great , funny and very professional, the group was pretty small and it went very smoothly. We booked our tour by email and didn't pay in advance (you can find all the details in their site - I recommend in as it is cheaper than booking in any other site!!!)For people with health problems - you better check with the company (by email) if it's okay to come.

Some of the best fun in Budapest. Such a great experience for anyone willing to challenge themselves with a little physical activity, the guides are incredibly knowledgeable and hilarious and really give you an appreciation for the experience of caving. 10/10 would cave again.

Simply Amazing, Interesting, Safe and Fun for All.. The staff were great, made you feel very safe and uncomfortable, but also very funny guys. The Caves are a sight to see. Going nearly 100m underground, they range from small narrow sections to huge amphitheaters. Do not fear if you area bit unsure of yourself in small spaces, or your strength or fitness. As long as you are fit enough to walk a bush walk, you'll be fine. My bf was over 6 foot tall and had a bad knee, but was fine, as long as you go slow and listen to the guides. They are really qualified and helpful.Email the guys and they will tell you how to get there by bus.

once in a life. my best experience in my tours around the world . its fascinating and challenging
going under the earth and crawling through tiny holes the guide was excellent

Recommend this - family. Really interesting place. We were the only ones so we had the pleasure of a private tour. Good for children, teens and adults. Quite informative - not recommended if you're suffer from claustrophobia and in poor physical shape.

Rewarding experience . This is a must do in Budapest. I had no idea what to expect. I went alone and by the end of it, the group of like 12 people were all best friends. Now the caves themselves are beautiful, we had an excellent guide Anna and His name starts with L- sorry i forgot especially after he did so well to remember ours. I'm a bigger guy and was quite worried about some of the spaces but they guide you very well and can tell when you start to get anxious and talk you through it. At no point did i feel stuck but it was an adventure- it has to be done.
Hokey and fun. The tweets loved the adventure of the labereth of caves. Pretty dark in some areas, bring your charged iPhone for the light. Fun 30 minutes of cave exploration.
"Funny caving". - interesting- good guides- close to the city center(just catch bus 9 and 65A)- new experiences- missing a large beer after the tour in the pub that there is outside:)

This was intense!. We chose the Active Climbing Adventure thinking it would be slightly more challenging than the easier walking tour. Be prepared! This is an intense caving adventure where you are climbing through tiny holes, pushing yourself through using your toes! You will climb over, under, and through rocks. You will climb over steeply angled wet, slippery rocks and will likely think, "oh I could easily get hurt/ die in this situation." Now, this is an amazing experience and we are extremely satisfied with the guides and the adventure. Bring extra shoes and advil; you will be muddy and bruised, but it's worth it!

i cannot recommend enough!. if you are going to Budapest, you have to do this! it is amazing. the caves are so pretty but the experience is everything. this is not your everyday caving experience, you will be crawling through holes on your hand and knees and wriggling like a snake. so worth the money.

Do it! Definitely an experience you won't forget. . This was the highlight of my Budapest visit. It was challenging, fun, surprising, and absolutely crazy, in the the best sense. There were plenty of moments, often wiggling on my belly through a small tunnel, where I muttered, "This is insane." And then laughed because it was awesome too. Prepare to get sweaty and dirty. You definitely get a workout. There were also moments of awe and silence, just appreciating the beauty of the caves. Is this for everyone? No. If you're a relatively active person, you shouldn't have a problem. If you're scared of tight spaces and of being underground, probably not for you. But if you're looking for something away from the city and open to a bit of adventure, do it! Also, our guide was great and the location's not hard to get to via public transit.

AMAZING!. We booked this tour through our hostel, though had to pay at the caves themselves. It was a full on caving experience, and was very fun. I couldn't recommend our tour guide, Laszlo, enough. He told us the best way to get through every space, and also showed us many of the cave features (and had a great sense of humour!). The tour picks you up from a central location and then you get 2 public buses (for which you need 2 transfer tickets, which are actually printed out as 4 tickets). The caving itself was great fun. I would recommend taking decent shoes, but I managed in trainers. They provide you with a helmet and an overall to wear. Our guide did mention that they alter the routes to ability levels (as there are over 30km of caves and plenty of different ways to go around) so don't be put off if you think it might be too difficult! it is definitely worth it!

AMAZING!! Best part of our city break!. I didn't book this through trip advisor but with the company direct by googling it (saved myself £10pp).I am claustrophobic and I have to admit I nearly cried a few times! However such an AMAZING experience I cannot explain enough! The gaps are very small and tight but I managed it with some guts. Small groups - around 10 people- our tour guide was brilliant! knew so much about the caves and history, was good at giving pointers about how to get through narrow gaps and also had a sense of humour too. I wouldn't advise going if you are hugely overweight as it will be tight for you however depends how daring you are.Not for the weak or non adventurous, also wear decent shoes- preferably walking boots!

oh my God!. It was a creepy visit. It was very interesting though... They accept only cash and i can't understand the reason why. I would like to have some kind of group visit with a guide but it was not as an option

Awesome, but not for the feint of heart!. We booked through gotohungary.com, and had the choice between a walking tour of the caves and a "more active" tour. We chose the more active tour. Age limit was 55...we are 52, so figured it would be an easy tourist-like experience. Nope - full-on caving. Our guide, Laszlo, was really awesome - took his time explaining about the caves, taking breaks to help us catch our breath and helping when we were having trouble getting through a tight spot. First descending by ladder 15 meters, then several minutes down-sloping meters of pretty easy rock navigation in wide tunnels/caves. I am not claustrophobic per se, but it is a bit unnerving to think about being closed in so far beneath the surface. Then we had some serious squeezing and tight places. At one point my boyfriend felt stuck and had some anxiety but Laszlo was quick to help. When it was all done we felt like we had really accomplished something.
